The Park is an ideal destination for bush walking and fishing, along with swimming, kayaking, surfing and snorkelling at Four Mile and Hamersley Beaches.

properties.name: South Gregories Campground
properties.description: Francois Peron National Park is an ideal destination for bush camping, four-wheel driving, bush walking and beach fishing, along with swimming and boating within the Shark Bay Marine Park. The Park features four bush camping areas with basic facilities (toilets and gas barbecues) at South Gregories.

properties.name: Silent Grove Campground
properties.description:
Also known as Bell Gorge Camp, Silent Grove is located in the Wunaamin Miliwundi Ranges, known for its spectacular Bell Creek and Lennard gorges.

Silent Grove is the best area to set up a base for exploring Bell Gorge and Bell Falls, which are about 11 kilometres to the north-west.

The campground itself is suited to tents, campervans and caravans but is accessible only by four-wheel drive (4WD), with picnic tables and toilet facilities available.

Campfires are permitted in certain seasons. Bring your own firewood.

Campers are advised to bring enough drinking water for the duration of their stay.

For more information, please visit the Department of Parks and Wildlife's ParkStay website.

Tourists are advised to check for alerts and road/park closures before commencing their travel on www.emergency.wa.gov.au and https://alerts.dbca.wa.gov.au.

properties.name: Shoal Cape Campground
properties.description:
Located within Stokes National Park, Shoal Cape is very popular for diving, snorkelling and fishing, as well as for its spectacular coastal scenery which can be seen from the viewing platform. 

Shoal Cape campsite is adjacent to Fanny Cove in Stokes National Park. The camping area consists of 3 small tent sites and has a bush toilet.  It is only accessible by four-wheel drive.

Only metres from the beach, Shoal Cape is very popular for snorkeling and provides some spectacular coastal scenery. There is beach access via a staircase, and a viewing platform.

You must bring enough fresh water as there is none available in the park.  All rubbish must be carried out as there are no bins available.

properties.name: Shannon Campground
properties.description:
Shannon is a large campground close to the South Western Highway in the Southern Forests. Forty-one campsites on the site of the former forestry workers settlement and twenty-seven campsites in the adjacent pine forest. Campsite surfaces and sizes vary. Two campsites in the pine forest have small timber cabins with bunks. All campsites are unpowered. 

Check campsite details and the campground map carefully when booking.

properties.name: Seal Creek Campground
properties.description:
Seal Creek Camp is located in the Cape Arid National Park - a large and exceptionally scenic park best known for its stunningly beautiful beaches, clear blue seas and rocky headlands. 
Campers can enjoy swimming, snorkelling, fishing and bushwalking, as well as photography and bird watching.

properties.name: Rottnest Island Camping Grounds
properties.description:
There is no charge to use the dump point. Ask for the location of the dump stations at the office, they have two dump stations in total. Black & grey water disposal only.

Located close to the Main Settlement and just a short stroll from The Basin, one of the Island's most famous beaches.

The campground consists of 43 non-powered sand covered sites, newly constructed ablution blocks (with wheelchair access) and a camp kitchen with 4 BBQ plates and troughs. 

In addition there are 2 further free standing BBQs.

The new facility offers the following: 43 sites accommodating up to a maximum of 6 people and 2 tents; 
- ablution block with wheelchair access
- camp kitchen with cooking facilities
- Separate free standing BBQs
- Complimentary delivery of luggage direct from the main Jetty to the Camping Ground if correctly labelled with labels provided by the ferry operator.

properties.name: Northam Caravan Park
properties.description: Northam Caravan Park is situated on 20 acres of bushland. They are centrally located between the historic towns of Toodyay and York which places them in the heart of the Avon Valley. The Mortlock River runs through the bushland at the rear of the property and guests are welcome to take walks through the area.

properties.name: Natures Hideaway at Middle Lagoon
properties.description: Natures Hideaway at Middle Lagoon is a low-impact coastal camp offering stunning views over Pender Bay. It is conveniently located on the Dampier Peninsula, just two and a half hours drive north of Broome.

properties.name: Mount Ragged Camp
properties.description: Mount Ragged Camp is located in the Cape Arid National Park - a large and exceptionally scenic park best known for its stunningly beautiful beaches, clear blue seas and rocky headlands. Campers can enjoy swimming, snorkelling and bushwalking, as well as photography and bird watching.

properties.name: Mount Barker Caravan Park and Cabin Accommodation
properties.description: Welcome to Mount Barker Caravan Park and Cabin Accommodation.

properties.name: Miliyanha Camp
properties.description: Located in the Millstream-Chichester National Park, Miliyanha Camp is close to Millstream Creek and the Millstream Homestead. An oasis in the desert, dotted with spinifex and gum trees, the pools in the area are fed from the underground aquifer via springs.

properties.name: Margaret Cove Camp
properties.description: Located in Stokes National Park, Margaret Cove Camp is a popular fishing and diving destination. The cove is quite protected so it's also ideal for safe swimming and snorkelling, with a boat ramp also provided. Campfires are not permitted. Campers are advised to bring enough drinking water for the duration of their stay.

properties.name: Mandurah Caravan & Tourist Park
properties.description: A great family park.

properties.name: Home Valley Station
properties.description: Home Valley Station is located on the famous Gibb River Road, at the foot of the majestic Cockburn Range. It is engulfed by a landscape of breathtaking contrast, where travellers experience a humbling connection with an ancient, largely untouched land.

properties.name: WA Wilderness Catered Camping at Yeagarup Hut
properties.description: WA Wilderness is a catered camping service available in selected locations in WA's South West.

properties.name: Acclaim Goldminer Caravan Park
properties.description: Welcome to Kalgoorlie, the heart of gold mining in Western Australia and Australia's largest outback city.

properties.name: Bunbury YHA
properties.description: You'll feel at home at the friendly Dolphin Retreat YHA hostel. Walk to the city and beaches. Free daily breakfast, fully-equipped kitchen, common room and travel information.

properties.name: West Point - The Block Camp
properties.description: West Point Camp, also known as The Block Camp, is located in Dirk Hartog Island National Park, making it the perfect destination for a snorkelling and diving holiday. The camp is one of six designated campgrounds in the area.

properties.name: Crossing Pool Campground
properties.description:
Take a day trip from Karratha or stay awhile and explore the expansive views over red plains of spinifex grass and termite mounds. There are natural spring-fed pools to swim in such as Deep Reach and Python Pool. 
The Yinjibarndi people ask that you swim safely at Deep Reach as this is the home of Barrimurdi, the Warlu, or serpent. You can launch canoes, kayaks or stand-up paddle boards there too but remember to treat the place with respect and keep noise to a minimum. 
Visit the Millstream Homestead and learn the how pastoralists lived and how the Homestead was once a tavern! Follow the walk trails to learn a little more about the ingenious use of plants for food and medicine by local Aboriginal people.

properties.name: Credo Homestead Camp at Credo Conservation Park
properties.description:
In the past, Credo Homestead was run as a pastoral lease but due to dry conditions the property was destocked. Covering about 202,161 hectares, it surrounds the Rowles Lagoon Conservation Park and the Clear and Muddy Lakes Nature Reserve. 

Together, these two reserves include most, but not all, of the open waters...

properties.name: Cheynes Beach Caravan Park
properties.description: Cheynes Beach is a protected cove

properties.name: Centre Road Crossing Camp at Mount Frankland South National Park
properties.description:
Centre Road Crossing is a secluded campsite along the banks of the Deep River in Mount Frankland National Park, which is dominated by impressive karri, jarrah and tingle forests.

The campground also features a hut which may be used for accommodation.

Centre Road crosses Deep River at this point; however, in winter it is only passable by four-wheel drive (4WD).

There are many roads and bushwalking tracks in this area. Visitors can also launch a canoe/kayak and paddle from Fernhook to Centre Road Crossing.

Camping fees do not apply at this campground.

Bookings cannot be made.

properties.name: Burra Rock Campground
properties.description: Burra Rock Conservation Park is located 55 kilometres south of Coolgardie. The park is a popular daytrip destination offering visitors a great picnic spot with a pretty backdrop of granite rock which is surrounded by regrowth woodland.

properties.name: Bunbury Glade Caravan Park
properties.description: As an older style caravan park, we cater to the needs of grey nomads seeking to uncover the multitude of fantastic attractions in Bunbury and its surrounding areas.

properties.name: Bottle Bay Campground
properties.description: Francois Peron National Park is an ideal destination for bush camping, four-wheel driving, bush walking and beach fishing, along with swimming and boating within the Shark Bay Marine Park.

properties.name: Benwenerup Camp
properties.description:
Located in Stokes National Park, Benwenerup Camp is a great spot with access to Stokes Inlet for a range of water-based activities, including canoeing, kayaking, boating and fishing. Stokes Heritage Walk Trail is also accessible from the campground. 

There are 11 individual campgrounds, six of which are big enough for large campervans and camper trailers. All 11 can accommodate regular size caravans, camper trailers, large campervans and tents.

properties.name: Workmans Pool Camp
properties.description: Located in St Johns Brook Conservation Park, Workmans Pool Camp is situated close to picturesque river pools, making it a favourite for swimming and picnicking.

properties.name: Kalannie Caravan Park
properties.description: Kalannie Caravan Park is beautifully located next to farming land on the right side as you enter Kalannie Townsite. The area offers powered and unpowered sites.

properties.name: Blowholes (Point Quobba)
properties.description: Blowholes (Point Quobba) is a beach side camping location for self- contained vehicles. Maximum length of stay is 30 days. Bring your own drinking water, and chemical toilet.
properties.fees: AUD $11 Adult; Children under 16 are free.

properties.name: Dumbleyung Caravan Park
properties.description: Dumbleyung Caravan Park offers powered and unpowered sites and on site cabins. Facilities include showers and laundry area. There is no care taker on site. Bookings can be made by phoning the Shire.

properties.name: Kumarina Roadhouse Caravan Park
properties.description: Kumarina Roadhouse Caravan Park provides powered sites for caravans and RVs. Facilities include toilets and showers. Meals are available at the roadhouse. Wifi available to customers and free tea/coffee facilities, Telstra tower on site.

properties.name: Bolgart Caravan Park
properties.description:
Bolgart Caravan Park offers powered sites for tents and caravans. 

It has a RV Dump-Ezy point, green lawns and shady trees to enjoy. There is a new park with BBQ facilities and tourist information bay south of the town.

Facilities include toilets, showers, water and BBQ. Dogs are allowed. Bookings can be made by phone.

properties.name: Lake Yealering Caravan Park
properties.description: Lake Yealering Caravan Park offers powered sites for tents, caravans and camper vans. Facilities include BBQ, toilets, showers, wood fireplace and laundry area. Activites include swimming, canoeing, sailing, water skiing, and walking trails. Bookings can be made by phone. Camping fees can be paid at the Commercial Hotel.

properties.name: Yalgoo Caravan Park
properties.description: Welcome to Yalgoo Caravan Park offering travellers powered, unpowered or large drive through sites and new unit motel-style accommodation close to the modern camp kitchen and amenities.

properties.name: Mundrabilla Roadhouse Caravan Park
properties.description: Mundrabilla Roadhouse Caravan Park offers powered and unpowered sites for tents, caravans and large rigs. Facilities include toilets, showers,  and public phone. Motel Rooms,Pets are allowed. Restaurant and Takeaway food is also available. Bar and garden bar

properties.name: Murchison House Station
properties.description: Murchison House Station is located in WA. It is a seasonal campsite only open from April- October each year. There are unpowered campsites suitable for tents, caravans and camper trailers. There are toilets and hot showers available at the homestead. Bring your own supplies.

properties.name: Ballidu Caravan Facility
properties.description: Ballidu Caravan Facility is located in Ballidu WA. Campsites suitable for tents, camper trailers and caravans. There are limited powered sites. Facilities include picnic tables and toilets. Bring your own drinking water supply.

properties.name: Wagin Travellers' Rest Area
properties.description:
This is a shire designated stopping area for Campers and travellers. It is in the Showground and consists of a large grassy area with power and water hookups. 

There are rubbish bins, public toilets, and a dump station. It is a quiet area. 

At certain times of year the campground is closed due to the show grounds use for events - check with visitor center of planning a trip here. When not in use as an event ground, this is a quiet camp. 

All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Woodanilling RV Stop
properties.description:
This is a receational reserve the shire has set aside for a 24 hour stopping area for self-contained vehicles. It is a large gravel and grass area with shaded and open spots. 

No fires allowed and vehicles must leave no trace. 

There is a playground, dump station, rubbish bins, and tennis courts. 

This is a quiet and secluded area in a small and quiet town. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: York Visitor Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Murchison Oasis Roadhouse & Caravan Park
properties.description: Accomodation for campers and caravanners. New laundry facilities. Fuel, ice, fast food and grocery lines available at the roadhouse.

properties.name: Newman Visitor Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Rowles Lagoon Campground
properties.description:
Rowles Lagoon is a freshwater wetland in the Goldfields Region reserved for nature conservation. The lake and wetlands may appear very different depending on the seasons. During drought they can totally dry out, but then fill again to overflowing during seasons of heavy rain. 

Spend the day or stay a while and camp under the stars. When the water level is high enough, take a swim or explore the lake on your canoe. To respect the birds and tranquility of the reserve, motorised vessels and water skiing are not permitted. 

There is lots of wildlife here. 41 species of waterbirds have been recorded on the lakes, including eight protected species. The freckled duck, one of the world's rarest waterfowl, has been recorded breeding here twice.

No dogs (or other pets) allowed in this park.

Entry to Rowles Lagoon Conservation Park is free.

properties.name: Wallaroo Rock Campground
properties.description:
Located in Wallaroo Rock Conservation Park, visitors to this campground can enjoy an invigorating woodland experience, alongside dams, panoramic views and Wallaroo Rock itself.

Birdwatching, swimming and bushwalking are popular activities in the Park.

The campground itself is located at the base of the Rock and is suitable for tents, caravans, camper trailers and campervans.

Barbecues, toilets and picnic tables are provided as basic facilities.

Campfires are usually permitted between 1 April and 30 November but fire restrictions may be imposed at any time and without notice. Bring your own firewood.

Campers are advised to bring enough drinking water for the duration of their stay.

Camping fees do not apply at this campground; however, park entry fees apply at Wallaroo Rock Conservation Park.

Bookings cannot be made.

For more information, please visit the Department of Parks and Wildlife's ParkStay website.
properties.fees: Pricing: $12.00. Park entry fee, per vehicle (up to 12 passengers) per stay. No camping fees are payable.

properties.name: Jarrahdene Campground
properties.description:
Jarrahdene campground is nestled within a mix of jarrah, marri and peppermint bushland.

Jarrahdene offers a range of camp sites suitable for caravans, camper vans, camper trailers and tents nestled within a mix of jarrah, marri and peppermint bushland
The site was originally a timber mill belonging to M.C. Davies dating back to the late 1800s. Remnants of the old mill, closed in 1913 can still be seen with an interpretive walk passing through the old mill site offering information on the milling industry from a bygone era.
Jarrahdene is in a central location between Margaret River and Augusta offering easy access to beaches, whale watching (seasonal) and wineries.
properties.fees: $15 night per adult and $3 night per child, concession adults are $9 per night. Must be booked and paid for online.

properties.name: Honeymoon Pool Campground
properties.description:
Honeymoon Pool campground, on the banks of the Collie River, has 20 individual campgrounds for tents and small campervans only. Four sites are suitable for a single small tent, three for two small tents, eight for a large tent and five for two large tents. Each has an adjacent space for one (or, in some cases, two) vehicles, which could be a small campervan.

Most sites have wood barbeques and picnic tables.

There are gas barbeques in the adjacent `day use` area for the use of all visitors.

properties.name: Shell Beach
properties.description:
Formed from billions of tiny shells, aptly named Shell Beach in the Shark Bay World Heritage Area is popular for swimming, beach combing and relaxing in the sunshine.  

Shell Beach is one of only a handful of places on earth where shells replace beach sand in such a dramatic and picturesque way.

The bay is very shallow and extends for hundreds of meters at about 1 meter depth. The water is saltier than the ocean so people are more buoyant and float better. There is a toilet here and some interpretive information.

properties.name: Python Pool
properties.description:
Python Pool is located within the picturesque Millstream-Chichester Range National Park, south of Roebourne. It is a stunning spot for a swim in a cool refreshing rock pool whilst enjoying the spectacular backdrop of the imposing rugged ochre cliffs.

If you intend to take the 142 to Tom Price you should be aware that the road is unsealed for about 200km and can be quite rough for a 2WD. It's the only way to experience this National Park though.

properties.name: Eagle Bluff
properties.description:
Eagle Bluff is a spectacularly high cliff that overlooks the Denham Sound in Shark Bay, Western Australia. It is located about 20 kilometres south of the town of Denham.

Eagle Bluff is a popular tourist destination for its stunning views and its abundant wildlife. From the top of the bluff, you can see the turquoise waters of Shark Bay, the white sand beaches of Peron Peninsula, and the Useless Loop salt pile. You can also spot a variety of marine life, including dolphins, whales, dugongs, and sea turtles.

properties.name: Charles Knife Canyon
properties.description:
Charles Knife Canyon in Cape Range National Park, located just 45 minutes from Exmouth, is a must-see destination. The park boasts sweeping views of this canyon, rugged mountain ranges, and stunning gorges that stretch out towards the Exmouth Gulf. 

Take the scenic route off the main highway to reach Charles Knife Canyon, one of the park’s most breathtaking gorges. The well-maintained road is accessible to both 2WD and 4WD vehicles, with plenty of spots to stop and capture the awe-inspiring landscapes. 

For a magical experience, visit between June and August when the park’s wildflowers burst into vibrant colour. Be sure to keep your camera handy for a chance to spot some of the area’s unique wildlife, including echidnas, kangaroos, emus, and rock wallabies.

properties.name: Newman Rock Rest Area
properties.description: This campsite is located at the end of a dirt track, approx. 1km off the highway. Newman Rock Rest Area, being the most attractive destination out of all 3 sites located along this road, is very large and has beautiful views. There are several waterholes and a lagoon to add to its scenic location and the surface is rather level with some chuckholes and overgrown scrub. There are no amenities and it's easily accessible by all vehicles.

properties.name: Miaree Pool Rest Area
properties.description: This spacious rest area is situated along the banks of the Maitland River. It is shaded and located some 200m off the highway. There are no amenities at this site, however the Pool is a great swimming and fishing spot.

properties.name: Karalee Rocks & Dam
properties.description: This well-signposted and level campground is located approx. 4km off the highway, by a dam. It has basic amenities and offers swimming and fishing. Climbing a nearby rock offers unobstructed views of the area and there are other walks available, too. Donations are welcome and a maximum stay of 72hrs applies.

properties.name: Warner Glen
properties.description: Warner Glen (Chapman Pool) is a small basic bush campground within Blackwood River National Park, operating on a first-come-first-serve basis. The area is easily accessible by 2WD and affords opportunity for bush walks, canoeing, kayaking and swimming. Pit toilets, picnic tables and BBQs are available. Bring your own drinking water. Fires are generally permitted in the fire pits, between April 15 and November 30.
properties.fees: AUD $10 Adult; AUD $2.20 Child; Park entry fees may apply.

properties.name: Cleaverville Campsite
properties.description:
Cleaverville Beach is a basic beach-side campsite for self-contained vehicles only. No facilities are available except sullage disposal. 

Fees apply only during peak season (May- September), off-season is free, but the maximum stay is 28 days.

properties.name: Ellendale Pool
properties.description:
Located along the Greenough River, Ellendale Pool is a naturally fored water hole. The campsite offers unpowered sites for vehicle based camping, camper trailers and caravans. 

Facilities include showers, BBQ, picnic tables and toilets. In the area you can enjoy swimming, canoeing and walking trails. You will need to bring your own drinking water. 

There is a 7 day limit. Fees can be paid at the Geraldton Visitor Information Centre of Shire Council.

Dump station on site is free to use for the public.

properties.name: Kurrajong Campground - Cape Range
properties.description: Situated in Cape Range National Park, Kurrajong campground is nestled between sand dunes offering some protection form the winds. Approximately 150m from the beach, there are 26 campsites available for tents, campervans and caravans. Facilities include toilets, and a ranger station. Drinking water is not available. Generators and campfires are not permitted.

properties.name: Martins Tank Lake
properties.description: Martins Tank campground located in Yalgorup National park has 30 campsites suitable for tents, campervans, caravans and vehicle-based camping.  Facilities include a camp kitchen with gas BBQs and wash sinks, tables, benches, and drop toilets. There are two communal fire pits. Campfires are permitted between April 1 and November 30. Firewood is not available. Generators are permitted.
properties.fees: AUD $10 per adult AUD $2.20 per child

properties.name: Benwenerup Campground
properties.description: Benwenerup, on the shore of Stokes National Park has 11 campgrounds, suitable for campervans, trailers,caravans and tents. Facilities include two camp kitchens, gas BBQ, dishwashing sink, and picnic tables. Campfires are not allowed or fuel appliances. Bookings cannot be made.

properties.name: Ellendale Lake Camp Area
properties.description: Large and grassy camping area with no amenities located off the highway, close to the water. There are scenic views and plenty of trees and shade. Suitable for big rigs with 24hrs maximum stay. Please note that this is a private land with a farming station and extra care needs to be taken not to disturb the cattle!

properties.name: Madura Pass Lookout
properties.description:
Madura Pass Lookout is a scenic lookout located on the Eyre Highway, approximately 65 kilometres east of the town of Madura in Western Australia. It offers stunning views of the surrounding countryside, including the Nullarbor Plain, the Transcontinental Railway, and the Madura Hills.

The lookout is a popular stop for both tourists and locals alike. It is a great place to take a break from driving and enjoy the scenery. The lookout also has a picnic table and barbecue facilities, making it a great place to have a lunch or dinner break.

properties.name: Ngumban Cliff Lookout
properties.description:
Nice lookout and freedom camping spot.

Ezy dump station. The dump station is located on the right side of the road as you drive into the rest area.

properties.name: Centennial Park Parking Area
properties.description: This is a designated 24 hour parking area for self-contained vehicles in Kalgoorlie-Boulder. It is a large dirt surfaced parking area in Centennial Park. There are some trees, but shade is limited. It is in a city so it is not secluded and will be noisy. There are toilets, rubbish bins, and a playground here. No generators. No camping (only self-contained vehicles). No dumping of liquids to ground. No hanging of laundry. All types of vehicles can access this area. Maximum stay: 24 Hours

properties.name: Torbay Inlet Camp Area
properties.description: This is a free campground 28 km W of Albany or 38 km E of Denmark. Turn S off Lower Denmark Rd 24 km W of Albany or 34 E of Denmark onto Perkins Beach Rd & Torbay Inlet Rd. Dirt road for 3.5 km. This is a small area that can fit 5-10 vehicles. Maximum stay 7 days. There is a toilet and rubbish bins, but no water. All vehicles can reach this area but larger vehicles may take up most of the space or have trouble with low hanging trees and turnarounds. It is secluded and shaded and quiet.

properties.name: Pallinup River Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a rest area 67 km S of Jerramungup or 15 km NE of Wellstead. It is a dirt-surfaced highway pullover with a turnaround for RVs and larger vehicles. There is a picnic area, barbecue, and rubbish bins. There is bush camping and some separation from the highway, but it is still noisy from the road. It is a busy rest area with many campers. All vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Moodini Bluff Rest Area
properties.description: This is an official designated 24 hour stopping bush camp rest area on the Eyre Highway. There is a dirt pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and bush separating. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables, and a toilet, as well as fire rings. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Tone Bridge Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest and camping area 1.5 km NW of Tonebridge, via Cranbrook - Boyup Brook Rd. It is a community maintained and built camping area next to the Tone River. This is a medium sized level grass dirt and gravel parking area. There is space for 5-8 vehicles before it becomes crowded. All types of vehicles can access this area. There is a toilet, covered picnic gazebo, picnic table, fire pit, rubbish bins, and rainwater tank. There are shady and non-shady areas. Even though it is next to the road, it is a lightly traveled country road that is quiet at night.

properties.name: Beasley River Rest Area
properties.description: This is a Main Roads Western Australia 24 Hour Stopping Rest Area 171 km E of Nanutarra Roadhouse or 53 km W of Paraburdoo/Wittenoom Rd jcn. It is a large dirt area with about 400 meters dirt access road that leads to the site. There is a large clear area with some tall trees providing shade, and tracks leading into the bush for secluded bush sites. The area is suitable for all vehicles, but in wet weather can be muddy. It is secluded, quiet, and shady. There is a toilet, dump station, rubbish bins, and a picnic table. Maximum stay: 24 Hours

properties.name: Albert Tognolini Rest Area
properties.description: You drive off of the highway down a sealed road for about 500m before you reach the campground. There you have the option to go to the campground or to go to the lookout. There's nothing provided in the rest area, but you are allowed to make fires. There are little areas in the rest area so if you want to you can have a bit of privacy.

properties.name: 14 Mile Campground
properties.description:
14 Mile is a medium-size campground adjacent to a recreation zone of Ningaloo Marine Park with access for launching small boats and kayaks from the beach (4WD only).

Booking:
Bookings are essential and can be made up to 180 days (approximately six months) before arrival and for one campsite only. The maximum stay in any park is 14 nights if any night is during Western Australia public school holidays, 28 nights at any other time.

Forty-six campsites varying in size, surface and distance from the beach.

All campsites are unpowered.

Check campsite details and the campground map carefully when booking.

properties.name: Little Lagoon
properties.description: Denham's Little Lagoon is a paradise for families, with its calm waters, sandy beaches, and abundant wildlife. Small children can splash in the shallow pools while parents relax on the shore or fish from the pier. Birdwatchers can keep an eye out for pelicans, swans, and other species that frequent the lagoon.

properties.name: Lake Thetis Stromatolites
properties.description: Visiting the remarkable Stromatolites at the picturesque Lake Thetis is an opportunity not to be missed. Enjoy a walk around the 1.2-kilometre lake and witness the earth's oldest living life form, believed to be over 3,000 years old. You will find the best examples of Stromatolites at the south-western edge of the lake.

properties.name: Hamelin Pool Stromatolites
properties.description:
Hamelin Pool is a marine nature reserve located on the western coast of Shark Bay, Western Australia, about 100 kilometres south-east of Denham. It is home to the most diverse and abundant examples of stromatolites in the world. 

Stromatolites are layered microbial mats that are considered to be the oldest living fossils on Earth, dating back over 3.5 billion years. They are formed by the trapping and binding of sediment by cyanobacteria, a type of algae.

NOTE: Boardwalk is currently closed

properties.name: Jasper Beach campsite
properties.description: 4wd only 4 single campsites only no amenities

properties.name: Bathers Paradise Caravan Park
properties.description: Lovely grassy and large sites and warm hosts. Great amenities and dog friendly!

properties.name: Discovery Parks - Pilbara Karratha
properties.description:
Looking for a true Outback experience? Next stop, Discovery Parks - Pilbara, Karratha (formerly Pilbara Holiday Park).

Karratha means ‘good country’ in the language of the local Indigenous community and you’ll be awestruck by the raw, natural treasures of the Pilbara in Australia’s North West. The massive gorges, crystal clear rock pools and waterfalls of Karijini National Park are a must-see. 

Just off the coast, the Dampier Archipelago and Mackerel Islands offer world-class boating, fishing, diving and snorkelling and the seasonal natural phenomenon, Staircase to the Moon, is extraordinary. 

Our holiday park’s excellent accommodation choices are perfect for resting up at the end of a long day.

properties.name: Sandfire Roadhouse Caravan Park
properties.description:
This outback caravan park is located at the family-owned Sandfire Roadhouse and offers a range of accommodation options, including motel rooms, budget rooms, and both powered and unpowered camping sites. 

Amenities include a camp kitchen, barbecue area, laundry facilities, and restrooms. Please note, there is no dump point on site. 

Fuel, LPG, and meals are available. No bookings are required, and there are no set check-in times.

properties.name: Water Tanks Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area 59 km N of Kalbarri turnoff or 69 km S of Billabong Roadhouse. It consists of two large rainwater tanks with drinkable but untreated water. There are picnic tables and rubbish bins but no other facilities. The area is dirt and gravel and mostly unsheltered and unshaded. It is near the highway so road noise is fairly loud. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Gladstone Scenic Lookout and Rest Area
properties.description: Gladstone Scenic Lookout is a scenic spot in Wooramel, Western Australia. It is located about 250 meters off the North West Coastal Highway.The lookout offers stunning views of the Shark Bay area, including the Hamelin Pool and Faure Sill. It is on a high scenic lookout point about 75 meters above the highway. The road up is only one lane, and only one vehicle can fit at a time. There are rubbish bins up top but no other facilities. It is a large area that can fit many vehicles. All types of vehicles can access this area. There is no shelter or shade and this can be a very windy site.

properties.name: Southern Cross Caravan Park
properties.description: Cheap sites and clean facilities. Possibility to check in after office hours.

properties.name: Busselton Seventh-Day Adventist Church Camp
properties.description: Bungalows and Campground for both self-contained and non self-contained vehicles. Tents allowed. Barbarque facilities, camp kitchen,  hot showers. Access to the beach. Gassy spots with plenty of shadow. Kids playground

properties.name: Moora Shire Caravan Park
properties.description:
The Moora Shire Caravan and Chalet Park can be found nestled amongst Salmon Gums on the banks of the Moore River just a 400m walk from the town centre. 

It provides a perfect base for those wanting to explore this spectacular region. The park is accessed from Dandaragan Street in Moora adjacent to the Moora Swimming Pool and Apex Park. 

The MILING powered caravan sites are located 43km from Moora in the township of Miling.

properties.name: Potters Gorge Campground
properties.description:
The site is situated on the shore of the Wellington Dam in a shady Jarrah and Marri forest setting. This lovely area is a spacious campground boasting 55 individual sites contained within three loops that caters for small, medium and large campervans or caravans. 

Many of the individual sites have their own tent pads making it easy to have another option whilst staying here.

properties.name: Camp Grace
properties.description:
Situated right on the beachfront in Geographe Bay, in the magnificent south west corner of Western Australia, Camp Grace is an ideal location for large or small group camps or individuals or families wanting a low-cost camping alternative.
The site includes powered sites, on-site caravans, tent sites and several bunk rooms, which together can accommodate up to 90 campers.
Camp Grace is owned and operated by Grace Christian School in Bunbury.

properties.name: Wellstead Bush Park
properties.description:
Really nice and spacious camp ground owned by a very friendly local farmer. It has a little cabin that has a flush toilet and a good hot shower and two sinks, one inside, one outside. There is also a picnic table and a fire place. It is a very clean campground, so keep it tidy and clean up after yourself.
Also very handy is the Wellstead Community Centre which is a 5 mins walk away across the road. It offers another free hot shower, a library with free wifi, a gas station and a grocery store with coffee, tea, fresh take-away food and a really broad selection of groceries if needed (more pricey than woolworth of course).

properties.name: Mesa Campground
properties.description:
Located in Cape Range National Park, Mesa Camp has access to a wide, sandy beach and Ningaloo Marine Park for swimming, snorkelling, recreational fishing, and launching canoes and kayaks.

It is possible to launch small boats from the beach but drivers are cautioned that there is a risk of vehicles becoming stranded in the soft sand.

Mesa is a medium size campground adjacent to a recreation zone of Ningaloo Marine Park with access for launching small boats and kayaks from the beach and is 4WD only.

Bookings are essential and can be made up to 180 days (approximately six months) before arrival and for one campsite only. The maximum stay in any park is 14 nights if any night is during Western Australia public school holidays, 28 nights at any other time. 

There are twenty-three reverse-in compacted gravel campsites, which are unpowered. There are no-flush pit toilets and picnic tables and benches.

No campfires at any time.

Dogs are not permitted.

Generator use is permitted at all campsites between 8am-9pm only.

properties.name: Warburton Roadhouse
properties.description: Warburton Roadhouse provides a convenient stop over with fuel, food and a range of accommodation. Camping facilities include toilets, camp kitchen and a coin operated laundry.
properties.fees: AUD $15 Adult; $10 Child; Children under 6 are free.

properties.name: Fig Tree Crossing Reserve
properties.description: Located on Chapman Valley Road, Fig Tree Crossing Reserve offers an overnight rest area for caravans and large rigs. Facilities include toilets, BBQ and picnic tables. There is an honesty box on site. Pets are allowed.

properties.name: Quagi Beach Campsite
properties.description:
Quagi Beach camping area offers beach camping. Sites are suitable for vehicle based camping, camper trailers and caravans. Facilities include showers, toilets, picnic tables and shelter. 

At the beach you can enjoy swimming, fishing and snorkelling. You will need to bring your own water and firewood. There is a self registration station on site.

properties.name: Goongarrie Homestead
properties.description: Located in Goongarrie National Park, Goongarrie Homestead offers an open area for tents, caravans, camper trailers and large campervans. Facilities include picnic tables and BBQ.  Between April 1 and November 30, campfires are normally permitted. You will need to provide your own firewood. Bookings are essential but cannot be made online.

properties.name: Millers Point Reserve
properties.description: Millers Point Reserve Camping area is a small camping area in Bremer Bay, WA. The campsite is suitable for tents, camper trailers and caravans. Basic facilities include toilets and picnic tables. There is no drinking water so bring your own supply. Activities include swimming, fishing and walking.

properties.name: Hammersley Inlet
properties.description:
East of the Fitzgerald River National Park, Hammersley Inlet camping area offers basic facilites in a coastal environment. Site activities include canoeing, kayaking, bush walking and fishing. 

Sites are suitable for vehicle based camping and camper trailers. Facilities include toilets, BBQ, and picnic tables. It is accessible only in dry weather. You will need to bring your own drinking water and a gas/fuel stove. Contact rangers to confirm seasonal closures.

properties.name: Robert Hindmarsh Rest Area Wannamal
properties.description: This is a rest area 26 km N of Bindoon or 59 km S of Moora, in the locality of Wannamal. It is a large gravel area with some dirt parking under the trees. It is a community maintained facility with male and female toilets, non-potable water, a barbecue and picnic area, rubbish bins, and information about the area. Short Stays only. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Avon Ascent Park Area
properties.description: Avon Ascent is a large park a few kilometers outside of York. It is a shady forested park with bush and trees and great amenities. There is a barbecue, toilets, rubbish bins, picnic tables, and water here. The park is very large and it is easy to find a secluded spot. The surface is dirt but is well graded. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Knobby Head Campsite
properties.description:
This is a camping area 35 km N of Leeman or 22 km S of Brand Hwy jcn on Indian Ocean Dr. 

It is a small dirt area with beachside camping. There is a long drop toilet but no other facilities. It is a small area that can accommodate 4-6 vehicles comfortably. 

There is some, but little, shade. It is quiet and peaceful but some road noise is heard from the highway. Maximum stay: 3 Nights

The Shire of Irwin no longer has any "free" camping, only paid camping. This means fees will be applied to all camping along Indian Ocean Drive within the Shire of Irwin.

properties.name: Dunham River Rest Area
properties.description: Quite a big rest area just about 100m off of the highway. There are several bins, public toilets and 2 sheltered picnic areas provided. You're allowed to make a fire. You camp on the side of the sealed road or on the gravel ground in between it. There are some trees around the rest are and the rest area is surrounded by bush and trees. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Lake Douglas Recreation Reserve
properties.description: This is a camping ground in the Lake Douglas Recreation Reserve. It is a large dirt area suitable for all types of vehicles. There are gumtrees and bush to provide shade. It is quiet and secluded, but a busy campsite in peak months. There are rubbish bins, fire pits, picnic tables, and a toilet here. Corrugated dirt road to reach this area, but suitable for 2wd. Maximum stay: 72 Hours per month.

properties.name: Sturdee Road Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area 12 km N of Mt Barker or 94 km S of Kojonup. It is a medium sized dirt pullover from the highway, separated by a bush median. There are some large trees providing shade. There are picnic tables and rubbish bins but no other services. Because it is close to road, it is busy and noisy. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Boondi Rock
properties.description: This is a camping ground at Boondi Rock. There is a 3 km corrugated dirt road that is passable with 2wd but could be worse in wet weather. The surface is dirt and there are bush camping sites, some shady and some open. This facility has rubbish bins, fire pits, a toilet, and non-potable water. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Harms Lake Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area. There is a short bitumen pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and bush. There are rubbish bins, picnic tables and fire pits but no other facilities. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Galena Bridge Rest Area Murchison River
properties.description: This is a Main Roads Western Australia 24 hour stopping area 13 km N of Kalbarri turnoff or 115 km S of Billabong Roadhouse. On the southern side there is a large bush area that could accommodate many vehicles that has fire pits. On the northern side there is a designated rest area with eco-toilets and dump stations, rubbish bins and picnic areas. The bush area is more suitable for smaller vehicles and the rest area is more suitable for bigger rigs. There is shade available at both. all types of vehicles can access this area. Maximum stay: 24 Hours

properties.name: Stanley Rest Area
properties.description: Rest area is located about 150 meters off of the highway. There are public toilets, three big sheltered picnic areas, a dumpstation, several fire barbecues and several bins provided. There are some trees around the rest area which you might get some shade from. The rest area fits a lot of vehicles and can get quite busy. The rest area is quite open and surrounded by a little bit of bush and trees. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Caron Dam Reserve
properties.description: Free camp spot at the dam. No facilities available. Located on Mullewa-Wubin Rd, 14km S of Perenjori or 11km N of Bunjil. Turn W at Caron Dam sign to get here.

properties.name: Karalee Rock & Dam Camping
properties.description: This is a camping area at the Karalee Rocks and Dam. There is a corrugated dirt road to access this site, but 4wd is not necessary. The area is a typical outback bush camp - dirt surfaced, with bush and sparse trees. Shade is available. There is a toilet, dump station, fire pits, picnic tables, and rubbish bins. Donations appreciated. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Yurlu Caravan Park
properties.description:
Yurlu Caravan Park Newman is for those wanting to camp under the stars or visitors travelling across Australia’s North-West by motor home.

Well-equipped with a laundry, kitchen and air conditioning in the communal lounge, travellers will enjoy the on-site facilities available.

Whether you're enjoying the delights of Newman or using Yurlu Caravan Park, Newman as a basecamp while you're enjoying the incredible sights and natural beauty of the Shire of East Pilbara, we hope you enjoy your stay.

Amenities include:
- Toilets and showers
- Handicapped Shower with wheelchair access 
- Baby-change table
- Laundry room with coin operated washers and dryer and ironing station
- Kitchen with fridge x2, sinks x2, microwaves x2, hot water boiler, kettle x2, toaster and induction hotplate
- Recreation building with 75" TV, lounges, book exchange, tourist information and dining area
- Liquid waste disposal point (dump point)
- Free use BBQ Area

properties.name: Membinup  beach
properties.description: Nice designed campground just before the beach. Separated pitches. You can drive on the beach and camp there as well. No open fire November- March. 2WD accessible.

properties.name: Kangaroo Point
properties.description: Idyllic beach popular for shore fishing and boating. To the north-west you can see Cervantes at Thirsty Point. Out to sea, within the Jurien Bay Marine Park, are the Cervantes Islands.

properties.name: Yeagerup Sand Dunes
properties.description: The Yeagerup Sand Dunes are one of the finest examples of landlocked dunes in Australia. They make the beach and the mouth of the Warren River accessible only by four-wheel drive vehicle. The sand is encroaching on the forest and this area has many unusual and unique features. Well worth a visit. There are camp spots available at the Leaning Marri Campgrounds, and coastal fishing is popular at the beach. The southern ocean is not the most hospitable for swimming or surfing at this point however it is well worth the visit.

properties.name: Water Wheel
properties.description: Visit the antiquated Augusta Water Wheel to see how water was pumped to the nearby Cape Leeuwin Lighthouse and the lighthouse keeper's cottage back in the 1890s. Read the information plaque about the sites history, the water system and the fresh water spring it flows from.

properties.name: Warren River Loop Walk Pemberton
properties.description:
The Warren River Loop Walk is located in the Warren NP near Pemberton. This 10.5km moderately difficult walk follows the Warren River and passes through some of the regions most magnificent old growth karri forest. 
The trail takes you deep into the moss-clad Warren River valley where it meanders alongside the river, through groves of karri, sheoak and Warren River cedar.

properties.name: The Granites
properties.description:
The Granites are a series of granite rock formations located in the Murchison region of Western Australia, about 7 kilometres north of the town of Mount Magnet. The Granites are a popular tourist destination, known for their unique and spectacular scenery. 

The Granites are also a significant Aboriginal cultural site. 

The area is home to a number of Aboriginal rock art sites, some of which are thousands of years old. The rock art depicts a variety of subjects, including animals, plants, and people.

properties.name: Ross Graham Lookout
properties.description:
The Ross Graham Lookout offers breathtaking views over the gorges within the Kalbarri National Park. Take a short walk from the car park down to the river's edge for a swim and explore the glorious countryside on foot. If you can plan your visit for late July you will be welcomed by a profusion of colour as the wildflowers are in full bloom. 

The park is famous for its wildflowers and has several species that can only be seen here. Look out for the Kalbarri Spider Orchid and the Kalbarri Catspaw. You may also be lucky enough to see Grey Kangaroos and emus as well. Named after the first school teacher in Kalbarri, Ross Graham was a devoted conservationist who aided in the exploration of the Murchison River.

properties.name: Reynoldson's Flora Reserve Walk
properties.description: Reynoldson's Flora Reserve in Wongan Hills displays a stunning array of colour between October and December each year when the wildflowers are out in bloom. Allow at least one hour to stroll along the walk trail and examine the reserve's spectacular floral exhibition.

properties.name: Railway Reserves Heritage Trail
properties.description: Located within the picturesque Perth Hills in Western Australia, Railway Reserves Heritage Trail retraces 59 kilometres of the old Eastern Railway that formerly linked Fremantle to York in the late 1880s. This popular walking, cycling and horse riding rail trail begins its journey at Bellevue.

properties.name: Perth Observatory
properties.description:
The Perth Observatory is a public astronomical observatory located in Bickley, Western Australia, approximately 30 kilometres east of Perth. It was established in 1896 and is the oldest public observatory in Western Australia.

The observatory is home to a variety of telescopes, including a 61-centimeter (24-inch) reflector telescope, which was the largest telescope in the southern hemisphere when it was installed in 1965. The observatory also has a number of smaller telescopes, as well as a variety of other astronomical equipment.

The Perth Observatory is open to the public and offers a variety of educational programs and tours. Visitors can learn about astronomy, see the night sky through telescopes, and attend special events such as planetarium shows and meteor showers.

properties.name: Ophthalmia Dam
properties.description: Ophthalmia Dam is a reservoir located in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, about 21 kilometres northeast of the town of Newman. It is the largest dam in Western Australia and the fourth largest in Australia by storage capacity. The dam was constructed in 1981 to provide water for the mining industry in the Pilbara.

properties.name: Oak Grove Walk
properties.description: The premier Top Trail, Oak Grove Walk, is an easy 1.5 kilometre loop walk through the heritage listed Golden Valley Tree Park, the largest arboretum in Western Australia featuring tree species from around the world. The 60 hectare landscaped park is set in the picturesque hills of Balingup, three hours south of Perth.

properties.name: Mount Nameless
properties.description: Mount Nameless, known as Jarndunmunha to local Aboriginal people, is located in Tom Price. The peak of Mount Nameless/Jarndunmunha stands 1128 metres above sea level, and from the lookout there are sweeping views across the Hammersley Ranges, the town of Tom Price and the iron ore mining operations. It's the second highest accessible mountain by four wheel drive in Western Australia and offers all of the rewards of a spectacular mountain view without the hike! When driving to the summit, low range 4WD is required. You can also hike to the summit - a walking trail starts from the base of Mount Nameless at back of the Tom Price Speedway track. Allow 3 hours for the return hike.

properties.name: Mt. Matilda Walking Wildflower Walk
properties.description:
The Mt. Matilda Walking Trail, stretching over 7.9 kilometres, can be found within the picturesque Wongan Hills Nature Reserve, situated just 12 kilometres away from the town of Wongan Hills. 

This meticulously marked Grade 3 trail guides you through a breathtaking landscape, where the serene beauty of natural bushland unfolds, framed by expansive wheat fields, rugged rock formations, and a vibrant tapestry of wildflowers, which truly come to life during the spring months of July through October.

properties.name: Mount Dale Walk Trail
properties.description:
The Mount Dale Walk Trail is a 2.5-kilometre loop trail located in the Helena National Park, approximately 60 kilometres east of Perth, Western Australia. It is a popular trail for all ages and abilities, offering stunning views of the Darling Ranges and the surrounding countryside.

The trail begins at the Mount Dale picnic area and winds through jarrah forest, passing by wildflowers (in spring) and wildlife such as kangaroos and emus. The trail also offers views of Mount Cooke and the farmlands below.

properties.name: Mimbi Caves
properties.description: The ancient labyrinth of the Mimbi Caves holds many hidden secrets, not only of the Devonian Great Barrier Reef that was formed over 350 million years ago, but also of one of the oldest surviving cultures on Earth. Amongst the striking limestone formations, you'll see some of the best preserved fish fossils in the world, and an extensive collection of Aboriginal rock art.

properties.name: Marble Bar Pool 'A' Class Reserve
properties.description: The Marble Bar Pool 'A' Class Reserve is a popular swimming spot located about 5 kilometres west of the town of Marble Bar in the Pilbara region of Western Australia. The pool is formed by a natural rock bar that crosses the Coongan River.

properties.name: Logue Brook Dam
properties.description:
Logue Brook Dam is a large dam located in the Darling Scarp region of Western Australia, approximately 125 kilometres south of Perth. The dam was built in 1963 to supply water for irrigation, but is also a popular recreational destination.

The dam is surrounded by jarrah forest and offers a variety of activities for visitors, including swimming, boating, fishing, camping, and bushwalking. There is also a picnic area and a children's playground located near the dam wall.

Logue Brook Dam is a popular spot for water skiing and canoeing. The dam is also home to a variety of fish, including rainbow trout, brown trout, and perch. Fishing licenses are required to fish in the dam.

There are two campgrounds located near Logue Brook Dam, both of which offer a variety of amenities, including toilets, showers, and picnic areas. The campgrounds are open year-round and can be booked online in advance.

Logue Brook Dam is a great place to visit for a family day out, a weekend getaway, or a longer holiday. The dam offers something for everyone, from swimming and boating to camping and bushwalking.

Here are some additional tips for visiting Logue Brook Dam:

The dam is busiest during the summer months, so it is best to visit during the shoulder season or winter if possible.
Be aware that the dam is a popular spot for water skiing, so be careful when swimming and boating.
Wear sunscreen and insect repellent, especially if you are visiting during the summer months.
Take all your rubbish with you when you leave.
Be aware of your surroundings and watch out for snakes and other wildlife.

properties.name: Lobster Shack
properties.description: Based on the shores of the coral coast, just 17 kilometres from the famous Pinnacles National Park, the lobster processing factory offers the complete lobster experience from lobster pot to cooking pot! The Lobster Shack provides a close up encounter with the most valued single species fishery in Australia.

properties.name: Lake Hillier
properties.description:
Lake Hillier is a stunning pink lake located on Middle Island, Western Australia. It is one of only a handful of pink lakes in the world, and its vibrant color is a sight to behold.

The exact cause of Lake Hillier's pink color is still unknown, but scientists believe that it is due to a combination of factors, including the presence of Dunaliella salina algae, halobacteria, and other microorganisms. These microorganisms produce carotenoids, which are pigments that give the lake its pink hue.

Lake Hillier is about 600 meters long and 250 meters wide. It is surrounded by a rim of sand and a dense woodland of paperbark and eucalyptus trees. The lake is located in a remote area of Middle Island, and the only way to see it is by boat or plane.

properties.name: Koolanooka Springs
properties.description:
Koolanooka Springs is a beautiful natural spring located in the Mid West region of Western Australia, approximately 30 kilometres east of the town of Morawa. The spring is fed by underground aquifers and provides a constant flow of clear, fresh water. The spring is also home to a variety of native plants and animals, including kangaroos, emus, and wildflowers.

There is a campground located near Koolanooka Springs, which offers a variety of amenities, including toilets, showers, and picnic tables. The campground is open year-round and can be booked online in advance.

properties.name: Kokerbin Rock
properties.description: Kokerbin Rock, also known as Kokerbin Hill, is the third largest monolith in Australia. Spend a day out at the rock exploring all of the interesting rock formations, caves, plants and wildlife.

properties.name: King Cascades Waterfalls
properties.description:
The King Cascades waterfalls are a series of waterfalls located on the Prince Regent River in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. The falls are situated in a remote and rugged landscape, and are accessible by boat or plane. The King Cascades are a popular tourist destination, and offer visitors the opportunity to swim, fish, and hike in a stunning natural environment. The falls are also a popular spot for birdwatching, as the area is home to a variety of native bird species. 

The best time to visit the King Cascades is during the dry season (April-October), when the weather is mild and the water levels are lower. During the wet season (November-March), the falls can be swollen and dangerous to swim in.

properties.name: Karakamia Sanctuary
properties.description: Experience the magic of Karakamia Sanctuary on a two hour guided walk at dusk. Setting off along a bush track just before sunset, you will have the chance to see a variety of nocturnal animals including Woylies, Tammar Wallabies and Quenda (Southern Brown Bandicoots).

properties.name: Joonjoo Botanical Trail
properties.description: The Joonjoo Botanical Trail provides an excellent opportunity to view a wide diversity of flora and fauna. Stroll along the interactive walking trail, reading the informative plaques to learn about the various species of flora along the way. Discover how the habitat is used by the Nyikina Aboriginal people.

properties.name: Heritage Park and Trail Busselton
properties.description: The Heritage Park and Trail in Busselton is a self guided easy walk through the charming coastal town providing information about the towns rich and colourful heritage.

properties.name: Harding River Dam
properties.description: A perfect location for a relaxing afternoon. Explore parts of the dam on foot to see the native flora and fauna that inhabit the area and take advantage of the stunning scenic views. Facilities at the dam recreation area include barbecues, toilets (including disabled), shade and a lawn area. Water from the Dam supplies the towns of Dampier, Karratha, Roebourne, Wickham and Point Samson, and it has a capacity of 64 billion litres. From Roebourne, follow the sealed Harding River Dam access road, signposted from the town.

properties.name: Golden Quest Discovery Trail
properties.description: The Golden Quest Discovery Drive Trail runs 965 kilometres through Western Australia's Goldfields from Coolgardie through to Laverton. This moderate Top Trail is a true adventure drive which commences approximately seven hours drive east of Perth and travels to 25 interpreted sites highlighting the 1890s gold rush.

properties.name: Golden Quest Discovery Trail
properties.description:
The Golden Quest Discovery Trail traverses 965 kilometres capturing the essence of the historic, cultural and spiritual Goldfields region of Western Australia.
The Trail provides a rewarding exploration of the Goldfields region that has contributed significantly to the fortunes of Australia as a nation.

properties.name: Fortescue Falls
properties.description: Take a refreshing dip under Fortescue Falls, the only permanent waterfall in Karijini National Park. The ancient gorges, tunnels, and waterways of Karijini are renowned for their bushwalking trails, lush vegetation, and sheer-sided chasms, some of which reach depths of up to 100 meters. The year-round flow of the waterfall's creek invites you to take a dip and cool off from the heat and humidity of the area.

properties.name: Flat Rocks Surf Beach
properties.description:
Flat Rocks is a renowned first class surfing beach just south of Geraldton. 

Surfers will enjoy the consistently perfect surf conditions. For those who prefer to watch from the shore, the soft pristine beach offers the perfect vantage point.

properties.name: Ethel Daw Scenic Drive
properties.description: The Ethel Daw Scenic Drive is a 30 kilometre heritage trail. Allow yourself one to two hours. Drive up to Mount Desward Lookout at 340 metres high for a fabulous 360 degree view over bushland, old mines and on a good day, the Southern Ocean.

properties.name: Elachbutting Rock
properties.description: Elachbutting Rock is a massive granite outcrop, a very popular camping spot for 4x4 wheel clubs and for locals, also a popular site for weddings and other gatherings. Elachbutting Rock is a spectacular natural rock formation with similar features to Wave Rock. The rock has a number of large cavern areas and is surrounded by natural bushland.

properties.name: Cosy Corner
properties.description:
Cosy Corner, beautiful white sand and clear water make this place a great fishing and snorkelling bay. Boat launching is possible via the beach ramp. 

Fishing from the rocks and beach is productive. Cosy Corner has rock fishing from both sides of the point, which makes it an ideal rough-weather spot.

properties.name: Coppin Gap
properties.description:
Coppin's Gap is a tranquil and scenic gorge lined with red jasper. 
It provides visitors with a safe and picturesque swimming location shaded by tall native trees and framed by a spectacular rock face. Enjoy a relaxing swim in the peaceful waters and soak up the natural scenic beauty. 65 kilometres from Marble Bar, a 1 hour drive.

properties.name: Carnarvon Heritage Precinct
properties.description:
The Carnarvon Heritage Precinct is home to the One Mile Jetty, the Kimberley Steam Train, Lighthouse Keepers Cottage, 1 Mile Station Restaurant, walktrails and many other attractions.

If you're not up to walking the Jetty or need to bring the big catch back why not catch a ride on the Coffee Pot train.

properties.name: Broad Arrow Ghost Town
properties.description:
Broad Arrow stands as a haunting relic of the past, a solitary ghost town nestled amidst the remnants of a once-booming gold mining community. Situated on the northern fringe of Kalgoorlie's arid desert landscape, it exudes a captivating, outback charm that draws visitors seeking a glimpse of history. 

Unsurprisingly, it finds its place on the itineraries of all the 'Ghost Towns' tours originating from Kalgoorlie.

properties.name: Boab Prison Tree
properties.description:
The Boab Prison Tree is a large boab tree located in Derby, Western Australia. It is estimated to be over 1,500 years old, and it is one of the largest and oldest boab trees in the world.

The Boab Prison Tree is significant for its cultural and historical importance. It was used as a prison by the Aboriginal people of the area for many years, and it is also a sacred site to them. The tree was also used as a prison by the European settlers, and it is said that many prisoners were carved into the trunk of the tree.

properties.name: Big Lagoon
properties.description:
Big Lagoon is a series of magnificent tranquil lagoons located just outside of Denham. 

Sit on the shore and watch the abundant marine life including dolphins, sting rays and sharks as they frolic in the shallow waters.

properties.name: Bells Rapids
properties.description:
Bells Rapids is a series of rapids and waterfalls located on the Avon River in Brigadoon, Western Australia, about 45 kilometres northeast of Perth. It is a popular spot for swimming, picnicking, and bushwalking.

The rapids are formed by a series of large boulders that have fallen into the river from the surrounding hills.

Bells Rapids is also a popular spot for fishing. The river is home to a variety of fish species, including trout, bass, and marron.

properties.name: Beagle Bay
properties.description:
Beagle Bay roebuck is a small town in the Kimberley region of Western Australia. It is located on the Dampier Peninsula, approximately 210 kilometres northeast of Broome. The town is named after Beagle Bay, a nearby inlet that was discovered by HMS Beagle in 1837.

Beagle Bay is a popular tourist destination, known for its stunning beaches, rugged coastline, and abundant marine life. The town is also home to a number of Aboriginal communities, who have lived in the area for thousands of years.

One of the most popular attractions in Beagle Bay is the Beagle Bay Cemetery, which is the final resting place of over 1,000 Japanese pearl divers who died in the region between 1912 and 1942. The cemetery is a moving reminder of the sacrifices made by these men, and it is a popular spot for visitors to pay their respects.

Another popular attraction in Beagle Bay is the Beagle Bay Rock Art. This ancient rock art is located on a cliff face overlooking the ocean, and it is believed to be over 10,000 years old. The rock art depicts a variety of animals and people, and it provides a fascinating glimpse into the lives of the Aboriginal people who lived in the area thousands of years ago.

properties.name: Barrabup Pool
properties.description: Barrabup Pool is a naturally formed watering hole just outside of Nannup. The peaceful location is a popular swimming and canoeing spot. The surrounding tall native trees provide plenty of shade and the tranquil waters make it a relaxing setting to unwind.

properties.name: Bald Head Walking Track
properties.description:
The Bald Head Walking Track provides a spectacular way to check out the stunning coastal scenery of the Flinders Peninsula in the Torndirrup National Park near Albany. The challenging walk provides hiking enthusiasts with a rewarding and breathtaking view of the coastline at the end of the track.

Walk through the thriving bushland to discover an array of native plants. If you have the chance to visit in spring you will enjoy the spectacular display of wildflowers during the season. Be mesmerized by the magnificent southwest coastline and keep your eye out for whales gliding through the ocean.

The walking track is an arduous 12.5 kilometres and requires a good level of fitness. It will take between 6 and 8 hours to complete the walk to Bald Head and back. Appropriate enclosed footwear and long shirts and trousers are recommended.

properties.name: Badgingarra Nature Trail
properties.description: The spectacular and diverse wildflower display along the Badgingarra Nature Trail is a sight not to be missed. Ensure you bring your binoculars and camera to capture the kangaroos, Wedge-tailed eagles and emus at home in the vast bushland.

properties.name: Hamelin Pool Caravan Park
properties.description: Caravan Park with both powered and unpowered sites. It has a pool, cafe and little store inside with jewelry and clothing. Good accessibility from the main road. There is no cell reception. Flushing toilets and hot showers are available; limited drinking water can be bought from the shop. The caravan park also offers regular and backpacker accommodation.

properties.name: Hangover Bay Beach
properties.description:
Hangover Bay is the perfect cooling tonic after a day of exploring the tracks and trails of the Pinnacles Desert in Nambung National Park. Step off the white sands into the bright blue waters of the Indian Ocean for a swim or snorkel, launch your boat or fish from the beach to catch dinner as the sun sets.

The secluded bay is 18 minutes drive west from the Pinnacles Desert or south from the rock lobster capital of Cervantes. From Perth, you can get there in just 2 hours by joining the scenic Indian Ocean Drive at Yanchep.

When the swell and sea breeze are up, you’ll find top-notch conditions for windsurfing and surfing in Hangover Bay too. After good winter rains, the coast is coloured with clusters of pink and white banjine, yellow wattle and many other wildflower species.

Nature lovers may also spot Bottlenose dolphins, Sea lions, Emus, Kangaroos, Bobtail lizards, Gould’s monitors and Carpet pythons (which are completely harmless).

Picnic tables and gas barbecues make Hangover Bay the ideal spot for lunch or dinner by the ocean, or head into Cervantes to feast like a king on Western Australia’s most valuable delicacy - the rock lobster.

properties.name: The Pinnacles Desert
properties.description:
The Pinnacles Desert in Nambung National Park, Western Australia, is a unique and otherworldly landscape. It is home to thousands of weathered limestone pillars, known as pinnacles, which rise up to 3.5 meters from the yellow sand base. The Pinnacles were formed over 25,000 to 30,000 years ago, when the sea receded and left behind deposits of sea shells. Over time, these deposits hardened and were eroded by the wind and rain, forming the pinnacles that we see today.

The Pinnacles Desert is a popular tourist destination, and visitors can explore the area on foot, by bike, or by car. There are a number of walking trails that wind through the pinnacles, and visitors can also climb to the top of some of the tallest pinnacles for stunning views of the surrounding area.

properties.name: Spring Creek Free Camping Area and Rest Stop
properties.description: Rest area is located just next to the turn of to Purnululu NP. There are three sheltered picnic areas, a public toilet, a few garbage bins and a dump station provided. The rest area fits quite a few vehicles. You camp on a sealed road and the rest area is surrounded by bush and some trees.

properties.name: Janes Bay Campground
properties.description:
Janes Bay is situated adjacent to Cloates Sanctuary Zone of Ningaloo Marine Park with access for launching small boats and kayaks from the beach (4WD only). 

The shoreline is a special purpose zone where shore-based fishing is permitted.

properties.name: Margaret River Visitor Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Milligan Island Eco Camping - Coastal Nodes
properties.description:
From 15 December we will only be allowing campers with an Online Booking.

Nestled amongst the natural bushland is the new Milligan Island Eco Tourist Camp. Located on the Turquoise Coast, between the two small towns of Leeman and Green Head, the camping node hosts 36 camp sites, shade shelters, picnic settings and long drop toilets all within a short walk from the beach.  Milligan Island Camping Node is perfect for a relaxing break. 

A site fee of $15 per vehicle (collection by Ranger or camp host ) applies with a 3 day maximum stay length. All sights to be vacated by 11am.

As there are minimal facilities avaiable at these sites, please observe and ensure the following:

Pets must remain on leads at all times. Please ensure all excrement is picked up and disposed of correctly.
No camping outside designated areas
No off-road vehicle usage
Designated track to be used only
Open fires are not permitted
No rubbish to be left behind. Please dispose of rubbish correctly in the skip bins provided at the entry/exit to the area
Chemical toilets are not to be emptied at the site. There are free RV Dump Points located in Green Head at the rear of the Volunteer Fire Brigade Shed and in Leeman at the Recreation Centre on Rudduck Street. 
There is no running water or power on site. PLEASE NOTE: Fresh water is not available at this site but can be purchased in Green Head & Leeman

properties.name: Carnarvon Rocky Pool
properties.description:
Rocky Pool is a pristine freshwater pool located in close proximity to Carnarvon. Its stunning natural beauty renders it an ideal destination for a delightful day excursion. Regardless of the season, visitors can enjoy a refreshing swim in its inviting waters, thanks to the consistently warm climate throughout the year. 

Stroll through the Rocky Pool area, taking in the breathtaking sights of the majestic ghost gum trees. Alternatively, float serenely in the calm waters and embark on an exploration of the shallow pools, where you may discover fossils that have been carried down from the Kennedy Ranges. Whether you opt for a picnic or decide to prepare a meal on the provided barbecue facilities, Rocky Pool promises an opportunity to unwind and savor the tranquil surroundings.

properties.name: Bunbury Lighthouse
properties.description:
Bunbury Lighthouse is a historic lighthouse located at the end of the Bunbury Breakwater in Bunbury, Western Australia. It was built in 1870 and is the oldest surviving lighthouse in Western Australia.

The lighthouse is a white octagonal tower that stands 19 metres tall. It is made of limestone and has a cast iron lantern room. The lighthouse is still in operation today and helps to guide ships into Bunbury Port.

properties.name: Meelup Beach
properties.description: This is a public beach with good surf, rocks, scenery and wildlife. There is a public toilet, rubbish bins, and picnic area.

properties.name: Ivanhoe Village Caravan Resort
properties.description:
Ivanhoe Village Caravan Resort provides accommodation from camping to standard cabins and 2bedroom Villas. Our customers are our greatest advertisement. Once you’ve experienced the Ivanhoe Village Caravan Resort lifestyle we’re sure you’ll be back to see us again, just like our other regulars.

Our aim is to ensure your stay here is so comfortable that you’ll never want to leave, and so memorable you can’t wait to return.

Kununurra is a picturesque landscape of stark contrast – tropical vegetation meeting red rock gorges and deep blue waterways against the rusty pindan soil.

We look forward to welcoming you soon.

properties.name: Kununurra Agricultural Society Show Grounds
properties.description: Overflow Caravan Park

properties.name: Mount Trio
properties.description: Mount Trio has three separate summits linked by a plateau. The trail starts and finishes at a picnic area set amongst shady trees, a pleasant place to rest after your walk. A steep climb that leads to a broad saddle between the north and east peaks. From the saddle it's an easy stroll to the north peak where you can enjoy sweeping views of Mount Toolbrunup and mountains to the south-west. Montane thicket on the upper levels of the peaks puts on a colourful display of wildflowers in spring and early summer.

properties.name: The Cut Campground
properties.description:
Within the Leschenault Peninsula Conservation Park, you will find The Cut – a campsite and day-use area with an island-like atmosphere.
You must either walk-in or boat in to reach The Cut. However, you will be rewarded with a beautiful spot that’s away from it all but only kilometres from the city.

The Cut is a small camping area at the end of the peninsula where the Leschenault Estuary meets the Indian Ocean, 8.5 km south of the Belvidere Campground and Day Use Site.

Fishing spots along the groyne can easily be reached via footpaths leading from the picnic site. Alternatively, the beach is less than a 500m walk away.

Bring your own firewood and drinking water. Toilets, picnic, and barbecue facilities are provided. The lighting of campfires in other than designated areas and periods is prohibited. It is recommended that you take a portable gas stove for cooking.

There are 11 campsites available, including two for large groups. Each site features a secluded area for a tent, a wood fireplace, and a picnic table. There are shelters and a fish cleaning table.

properties.name: Cocklebiddy Cave
properties.description:
Cocklebiddy Cave is a remarkable limestone cave system located in the Nullarbor Plain region of Western Australia. It is one of the longest cave systems in Australia and has gained international recognition for its extensive underground passages. 

Exploring Cocklebiddy Cave requires proper equipment and permits, and it's often undertaken by experienced cavers and cave divers. 

Public visitors walk down the doline and can go as far as the barriers at the cave mouth and see the wonder of it, along with seeing the information boards about the cave, to learn about the unique geological formations and the cave's ecological significance. 

Cocklebiddy Cave offers a rare opportunity to study the Earth's subterranean beauty.

properties.name: Boat Harbour Camping (4WD only)
properties.description: Beautiful free camping spot with beach access. Toilets and barbecue area with wooden deck overlooking the beach.

properties.name: Conto Campground
properties.description:
Conto is a large campground four kilometres from Conto Beach, close to Boranup Forest and on the Cape to Cape Track.

Bookings are essential and can be made up to 180 days before arrival, for one campsite only.

Conto has eight camping areas.
