Chuditch (19 campsites) and Quenda (18) areas are reverse-in with a compacted crushed limestone surface.

Davies (12), Hamelin (22), Isaacs (13), Whalers (11) and Whistlers (14) areas are compacted earth and grass sites nestled amongst the peppermint trees, often with low overhead clearance - suitable for tents and swags only.

Wanil is a fenced grass area for tents and swags only.

All campsites are unpowered.

Drinking water is not provided.

No-flush pit toilets in all areas.

Chuditch and Quenda areas have food preparation shelters with gas barbecues, sinks with rainwater (not guaranteed), food preparation surfaces, picnic tables and benches. Hamelin, Quenda and Wanil areas have gas barbecue shelters. Campers in any area may use any of the shelters.

Wanil area has communal picnic tables and fire rings.

Campsites in Davies, Hamelin, Whalers and Whistlers areas have a picnic table, benches and a fire ring.

Campsites in Isaacs area have a picnic table.

Campsites in Chuditch and Quenda areas have a fire ring.

properties.name: McGowans Sunset Beach Camping
properties.description:
This charming nature and fishing campsite is located just 16 km north of Kalumburu in the Kimberley, WA, and is open from April to October.

Accessible by 4WD, the unpowered sites are suitable for tents, camper trailers, and semi/off-road caravans. Facilities include toilets, cold showers, clean drinking water, and a washing machine. Wi-Fi and landline phone access are available for an additional fee.

Pets are welcome, provided dogs are well-behaved, not overly noisy, and are not of aggressive breeds.

properties.name: Granite Skywalk
properties.description:
The Granite Skywalk in Castle Rock is a breathtaking natural attraction, offering visitors a unique opportunity to experience Western Australia's stunning landscapes from elevated heights.

**Highlights:**
- Suspended Skywalk: Walk on a cantilevered platform, hovering above the rugged terrain.
- Panoramic Views: Enjoy sweeping vistas of ancient granite outcrops and lush forests.
- Aboriginal Heritage: Learn about the indigenous culture and history of the area.
- Birdwatching: Spot diverse bird species in this pristine wilderness.
- Sunset Spectacle: Witness the sky ablaze with colors during evening visits.

properties.name: Monkey Rock
properties.description:
Perched majestically above the tree-clad terrain along the breathtaking Denmark coastline, this venerable and awe-inspiring rock formation, known as Monkey Rock, offers a thrilling ascent and a remarkable walking experience. 

The effort to get there is rewarded, particularly on a clear day, as you can marvel at the panoramic views stretching from Nullaki to the East and William Bay National Park to the West. 

Ensure you come prepared for a walk, and always keep a watchful eye on children.

properties.name: Donnybrook Transit Park
properties.description:
Situated off Reserve Street in a prime position next to the Apple Fun Park playground and Egan Park, local shops and services, and next to the scenic Noneycup Creek, the Donnybrook Transit Park is the perfect choice when visiting Donnybrook and surrounds. 

At this location, each site has capacity for vehicle or tent camping. There are fourteen (14) powered sites with concrete slabs, and seven (7) unpowered sites. There are also modern accessible ablutions, a BBQ, scheme water, and a caravan liquid waste dump-point. 

All guests at the Donnybrook Transit Park must adhere to the Shire's Local Laws, the Caravans & Camping Grounds Regulations 1997, and the Dog Act 1976.

Max 3 night stay.

properties.name: Ravensthorpe Silo Art Trail
properties.description:
The Ravensthorpe Silo Art Trail is a captivating outdoor art experience in Western Australia. 

It features stunning murals painted on towering grain silos, showcasing the region's rich natural beauty and cultural heritage. 

As you follow the trail, you'll encounter vibrant depictions of native flora, fauna, and local stories, all masterfully rendered by talented artists. The trail offers a unique opportunity to immerse yourself in the area's history and connect with its picturesque landscapes.

properties.name: Giant Tingle Tree
properties.description:
The Giant Tingle Tree is a massive red tingle tree (Eucalyptus jacksonii) located in Walpole-Nornalup National Park in Western Australia. It is estimated to be over 400 years old and has a circumference of 24 metres. The tree was hollowed out by fire many years ago, creating a large cavity that can be accessed by visitors. 

The Giant Tingle Tree is a popular tourist destination and is a reminder of the ancient forests of Western Australia. It is a short walk from the car park to the tree, and there is a boardwalk that surrounds the cavity so visitors can safely view it.

properties.name: Molly Springs Kununurra
properties.description:
Molly Springs is a gorgeous little spring fed pool and waterfall about 30 kilometres from Kununurra (towards Wyndham). 

Emphasis should be placed on little here; the pool is only a few metres across so a little cosy sometimes! 

It is however a lovely shady place to sit in the water and watch the fish, goannas and birds. 

This little Kununurra waterfall is very popular with the locals and its available to access all year round.

properties.name: Two Camels Creek Rest Area
properties.description: 24hr rest area, all new. Fire is allowed. Big overnight stay with lots of space to fit alot of cars/vans/campers etc.

properties.name: Carnavon Caravan Park
properties.description: Large caravan park with all usual facilities, but a bit getting old. Free WiFi. Grass areas with concreted area. Dogs allowed. Cheapest place in Carnavon

properties.name: Paynes Find Roadhouse & Tavern
properties.description:
Family owned and operated Paynes Find Roadhouse & Tavern is located in a remote area on the Great Northern Highway, 420 km north of Perth.

We have accommodation for everyone and every need available. We offer single rooms, double rooms, family units, a camping area and a caravan park with powered and unpowered sites.

As we are one of the few independent roadhouses left, we take great pride in our hospitality and customer service.

We cook and serve homestyle food & beverages 24 hours a day, every day. You can enjoy your meal in our comfortable, restaurant-style dining room or outside in our beer garden. During the opening hours of our on-site pub, your meal is best enjoyed with a cold beverage.

Food and fuel as well as shop items are available all day and night, except for the Christmas and New Year’s holidays.

properties.name: Black Diamond Lake
properties.description: Black Diamond Lake is a stunning artificial lake located in Collie, Western Australia. It is a popular spot for swimming, kayaking, stand-up paddleboarding, and picnicking.

properties.name: Mandurah Coastal Holiday Park
properties.description:
Welcome to the Mandurah Coastal Holiday Park (formerly Belvedere Caravan Park) , located 500m from the beach, in the heart of Mandurah. Our central location means everything is just minutes away, including Mandurah Foreshore and Dolphin Quay Marina hospitality and tourism precincts, the Peel inlet with abundant marine life, excellent fishing, crabbing, cruising, dolphin watching, eateries, shopping and more.  

We are a Quality Tourism Accredited business offering clean and affordable accommodation and powered caravan and camping site facilities.

properties.name: Youndegin
properties.description: Visit the ruins of the early settlement of Youndegin, 19 kilometres south of Cunderdin, and see all that remains of a once thriving settlement. You can walk through the old police outpost, which was built in 1865, and was the first building constructed, in what is said to be the earliest settlement in the area.

properties.name: Wreck of SS Mildura
properties.description:
The intriguing sight of the shipwreck of SS Mildura can be seen from the tip of North West Cape. The SS Mildura was a cattle steamer, wrecked in 1907 during a cyclone. Most of the remains were salvaged and used for renovations and the hull was used for bombing practice in World War II. 

The remains of the SS Mildura now rest only 80 metres from shore and are best viewed on a low tide.

properties.name: Woylie Walk Dryandra Woodland
properties.description: The Woylie Walk in Dryandra Woodland. This scenic trail takes you through the heart of Western Australia's pristine wilderness. Discover unique flora and fauna while enjoying a tranquil stroll. Woylie Walk is a 5.5km, grade 2 hike located in the Dryandra Woodland, Western Australia. The hike should take around 1.5 hrs to complete.

properties.name: West End
properties.description: West End is located on the western most Point of Rottnest Island. It is a rugged piece of coastline, which unlike the rest of the island is not so calm and peaceful. Here you can gaze across the Indian Ocean and view the magnificent waves forming, a paradise for surfers. Away from the beaches and lively buzz of the main settlement, around the sandy coast and rolling swell, you'll find Wadjemup / Rottnest Island's West End.

properties.name: Wellington Discovery Forest
properties.description: The Wellington Discovery Forest provides an informative insight into the diverse ecosystem of the Jarrah Forest. Take the self-guided walk through the magnificent forest or pack a picnic to sit and enjoy soaking up the atmosphere. Find out about the animals that inhabit the mighty giant tress.

properties.name: Wanneroo Markets
properties.description:
Since 1980, the original Wanneroo Markets have consistently offered award winning, exceptionally great quality, locally grown produce. As a true weekend marketplace, the original Wanneroo Markets are a retail icon of Perth's northern suburbs and continue to keep pace with the spectacular growth of the region. 

Offering a wide selection of fascinating variety stalls, a huge food court and modern bar area, the Wanneroo Markets offer Something for everyone

properties.name: Wanna Munna Aboriginal Rock Carvings
properties.description: The Wanna Munna Aboriginal rock carvings are a series of ancient petroglyphs located in the Pilbara region of Western Australia. The carvings are thought to be over 40,000 years old and depict a wide variety of subjects, including animals, people, and spiritual symbols.

properties.name: Walga Rock
properties.description:
Walga Rock is a large inselberg (monolith) located in the Shire of East Pilbara, Western Australia, about 250 kilometres northeast of Newman. It is the largest inselberg in Australia, and one of the largest in the world.

Walga Rock is about 2.6 kilometres long, 1.3 kilometres wide, and rises 275 metres above the surrounding plain. It is made of hard dolerite rock, which is resistant to erosion.

Walga Rock is a sacred site to the Aboriginal people of the area. It is also a popular tourist destination, known for its stunning scenery and unique geological features.

properties.name: Useless Loop
properties.description:
Useless Loop is a closed company town in Shark Bay, Western Australia, that is home to the world's largest solar salt mine. The salt mine produces the purest grade of salt in the world, which is used in a variety of applications, including food production, water treatment, and pharmaceuticals.

While Useless Loop is not open to the public, visitors to Denham can still get a glimpse of the salt mine from a distance. The salt mine can be seen from the beach at Denham, where it appears as a white mountain in the distance. For those with a four-wheel drive vehicle, there is a track that leads to a viewpoint where the salt mine can be seen up close.

The Useless Loop salt mine is a reminder of the unique natural resources that Australia has to offer. It is also a testament to the ingenuity of the people who have developed ways to extract and use these resources in a sustainable way.

properties.name: Two-Up School
properties.description: Experience the aura of excitement surrounding the much cherished game of Two-Up by visiting the only legalised Two-Up School in Australia. Take a 10 minute drive out of Kalgoorlie, along a dirt road to the original corrugated iron shed and bush ring that was once the Two-Up School.

properties.name: Thirsty Point Lookout
properties.description:
Thirsty Point Lookout is a popular tourist destination located in Cervantes, Western Australia. It offers stunning panoramic views of the Indian Ocean, Cervantes Bay, and the town of Cervantes.

To reach the lookout, visitors must take a short walk along a wooden boardwalk through the sand dunes. The lookout itself is a raised platform with seating, providing visitors with a comfortable place to enjoy the views.Take the wooden boardwalk through the sand dunes and climb up to the top of the lookout.

properties.name: The Great Forest Trees Drive
properties.description:
The Great Forest Trees Drive is a 48-kilometre scenic drive located in the Shannon National Park in Western Australia. The drive winds its way through a karri forest, which is home to some of the tallest trees in the world.

The drive is a popular spot for photography and hiking. There are a number of stops along the way where you can get out and stretch your legs, take in the views, and learn about the forest.

properties.name: The Esplanade
properties.description:
The Esplanade located at the southern end of the Foreshore is a popular destination for tourists and Geraldton residents.

The Esplanade offers views of the City, Port, Champion Bay and Moresby Ranges from a 360 degree viewing platform at its far end. The area also boasts barbecue facilities and landscaped walkways.

properties.name: Stockyard Gully Caves
properties.description:
Stockyard Gully Caves, located near Paynes Find in Western Australia, are a geological wonder and a popular tourist attraction. These caves are not true limestone caves but rather large, naturally eroded rock formations that have created intriguing tunnel-like passages and chambers. 

The caves are known for their unique rock formations and the eerie, almost otherworldly ambiance inside. Visitors can explore the maze-like tunnels and chambers, marvel at the rock textures and colors, and take in the fascinating geological features. 

Stockyard Gully Caves are also famous for their historical significance, as they were once used as shelter by early settlers and gold prospectors in the area. Exploring the caves provides a glimpse into the region's pioneering past. 

It's important to note that while the caves are open to the public, visitors should exercise caution and be well-prepared with suitable footwear and lighting when exploring them.

properties.name: Steep Point Campground
properties.description:
Eight rock-surface campsites. All campsites are unpowered.

No dogs (or other pets) allowed at this campground. No-flush pit toilets.

properties.name: Separation Point Lookout
properties.description:
Separation Point Lookout is a popular tourist destination in Beachlands, Western Australia. It offers stunning panoramic views of the Indian Ocean, the Abrolhos Islands, and the Geraldton coastline. The lookout is also a popular spot for windsurfing, surfing, and fishing. 

If you are planning a trip to Separation Point Lookout, be sure to check the weather forecast in advance. The lookout can be windy.

properties.name: Rotary Lookout Esperance
properties.description:
The Rotary Lookout in Esperance sits atop a granite outcrop, granting a commanding perspective of the coastal town and its stunning beaches. Behold the impressive outlook over the distant islands of the Recherche Archipelago and the vast town of Esperance.

Perched on Wireless Hill, this vantage point offers a complete 360-degree view, spanning from 'Pink Lake' inland to the expanses of farmland on the town's periphery.

properties.name: Point Walter
properties.description: Point Walter, south of Perth, is where the locals go on weekends for riverside picnics, swimming and fishing. This scenic reserve boasts sweeping views of the Swan River and is the perfect place for a barbecue with friends and family.

properties.name: Point D'Entrecasteaux
properties.description: Point D'Entrecasteaux was named after the French navigator Antoine de Bruni D'Entrecasteaux who sighted the point on his way to Cape Leeuwin in 1792. D'Entrecasteaux Drive is a sealed, scenic drive which shows off the impressive coastline and surrounding karri forest. The spectacular views of the rugged southern coastline is a rewarding surprise. Stand on a viewing platform high up on the cliffs for a magnificent view, then take one of the walk trails to further explore this rugged coastline. A whale watching platform is set high on the limestone cliff at Tookulup providing unbeatable views of the southern coastline and limestone cliffs. The best time for whale watching is September to June.

properties.name: Peace Gorge
properties.description:
Peace Gorge is a stunning spot to relax and take in the beauty of the surroundings whilst enjoying a picnic lunch. 

Explore the fascinating rock formation of the gorge and take a walk around the reserve to examine the wildflowers, native shrubs and vegetation.

properties.name: Parry Lagoons Nature Reserve
properties.description: For one of the best bird watching sites in Western Australia head to Parry Lagoons Nature Reserve near the Kimberley town of Wyndham. This is where waders from as far afield as Siberia come to rest and feed. The lagoons and billabongs of this nature reserve teem with wildlife, especially during the wet season.

properties.name: Big Satellite Dish
properties.description: The 'Big Dish' is a Carnarvon landmark. Take a drive out to the site of this massive satellite dish and marvel at the 29.5 metre diameter of the reflector. You can visit the site and enjoy the panoramic views of Carnarvon and the surrounding plantations.

properties.name: Observatory Point Beach and Lookout
properties.description:
Observatory Point and Lookout provide stunning panoramic views of the coastline in Cape Le Grand National Park. Don’t miss the memorial at the lookout honoring the explorers who sought refuge from a storm in 1792. From June to October, keep your eyes peeled for the majestic whales swimming in the surrounding waters.

The park is full of attractions. Wander along various walking trails during wildflower season to witness a breathtaking display of vibrant flora. Try your luck at fishing for fresh salmon to enjoy a delicious evening meal. You might even spot kangaroos lounging on the pristine beaches! Be sure to visit the nearby bird sanctuary, home to a variety of native bird species.

Recognized as one of the most breathtaking national parks in Western Australia, Cape Le Grand is just a 30-minute drive from Esperance and about nine hours by car or one-and-a-half hours by plane from Perth.

Don't miss the awe-inspiring display of the whale migration, frequently spotted swimming in the ocean from June to October.

properties.name: New Norcia Heritage Trail
properties.description:
Experience the New Norcia River Walk, a captivating self-guided excursion that delves into the historical, spiritual, and Indigenous legacy of New Norcia. 

In New Norcia, a culture of perpetual learning thrives, and the self-guided River Walk invites you to embark on a captivating voyage through the intricate tapestry of this exceptional community's history. 

Enriching your journey are the distinctive interpretive trail signs that accompany your steps, skillfully leading you through New Norcia's heritage. These markers illuminate significant landmarks and offer profound insights into life within this vibrant community, spanning over the past 170 years.

properties.name: Mundella Foods
properties.description: Mundella is an award-winning WA dairy located in the beautiful Serpentine Jarrahdale region. We have been making premium yoghurts for over 40 years and every product is made using only the finest ingredients, sourced locally. Our milk is sourced mostly from local farms within 20km of our factory, ensuring the freshness of our range and we only use natural and wholesome ingredients free from any additives, gelatins, thickeners, colours, preservatives or artificial sweeteners. And then we get our yoghurt straight into the stores – no delays and perfectly chilled the entire trip.

properties.name: Mulka's Cave
properties.description: Mulka's Cave is located within the vicinity of Wave Rock in Hyden Western Australia. The name Mulka comes from an Aboriginal legend associated with the cave. Mulka was the illegal son of woman who fell in love with a man with whom marriage was forbidden according to their law.

properties.name: Mount Brown Lookout
properties.description: Mount Brown Lookout is a scenic viewpoint located in the town of York. It offers stunning panoramic views of the town, the surrounding countryside, and the Darling Range. The lookout is accessible via a short drive from the town center. From the lookout, visitors can enjoy views of York's historic buildings, the Avon River winding its way through the town, and the Darling Range in the distance. On a clear day, it is possible to see all the way to the Perth Hills to the west.

properties.name: Millers Ice Cream
properties.description: Millers ice cream is handmade, on farm, from creamy farm fresh milk. The Millers are third generation dairy farmers who run a farm, hand make ice cream, bottle creamy milk and run the popular Millers Farm Cafe.

properties.name: Merredin Peak Trail
properties.description: The Merredin Peak Trail provides an uninterrupted view across the town of Merredin and the surrounding rural area. As the highest peak in the area it offers spectacular panoramic views as far as the eye can see.

properties.name: Manning Gorge
properties.description:
Manning Gorge is one of the most beautiful and best swimming spots in the Kimberley.

Located on Manning Creek in the grounds of the 283,280ha Mt Barnett Station, water remains at the base of the waterfalls and in several pools along the creek year round, ideal for a refreshing dip. 
The waterfalls are seasonal and fed by the rains during wet season, so they may be dry the mid to late dry season. 

When exploring, you may also come across some examples of Bradshaw and Wandjina rock art.

Visiting the gorge involves an adventurous walk of approximately 3 kilometres to the top of the gorge, following the informal trail markers made up of rock cairns, red discs and arrows. The trail begins at the campground, where visitors must first cross Manning Creek to re-join the trail path on the other side. Visitors may swim the 100 metres across, or use the rope guide with floats to ferry belongings. 

The trail follows a route overland rather than along the creek with views over the ranges and savannah woodlands along the way. The terrain is uneven, with some rock scrambling and an incline towards the end. The trail is mostly unshaded, so it is important to bring drinking water and to wear a hat.

properties.name: Mandalay Beach
properties.description: Mandalay Beach is a great stop between Manjimup and Walpole. Worth a visit purely for the stunning beach scenery, you may be fortunate enough to glimpse the wreck of the Mandalay, which can still be seen poking out of the rough waters of the Southern Ocean when the tides are low.

properties.name: Maidens Tuart Forest
properties.description: Maidens Tuart Forest in Bunbury is one of the last remaining Tuart forests in Australia. It is best to explore the superb bush land on foot, with a network of walk trails to choose from. Take the path to the lookout and enjoy the exquisite panoramic views of the coast, the City of Bunbury and the surrounding bush land.

properties.name: Lotterywest Federation Walkway
properties.description:
The Lotterywest Federation Walkway is a 620-metre elevated walkway through the Western Australian Botanic Garden in Kings Park. It features a spectacular 52-metre glass and steel arched bridge suspended among a canopy of tall eucalypts, offering breathtaking views of the city skyline, Swan and Canning Rivers, and surrounding bushland. 

Visitors can enjoy a 40-minute return journey along the walkway, passing by beautiful wildflower gardens, across the Tuart Lawn, alongside the tranquil Water Garden valley, and through the cathedral of the Marri woodland forest. Interpretive signage provides insights into the flora, fauna, Aboriginal culture, and fascinating history of the area.

properties.name: London Bridge
properties.description: The Sandstone area has countless natural rock formations or 'breakaways' which contrast dramatically with the rust stained landscapes. Believed to be 350-million years old, one of the most spectacular breakaways known as 'London Bridge' was once wide enough to allow and horse and sulky to cross.

properties.name: Lake Clifton Thrombolites
properties.description:
Thrombolites are mound-shaped structures that are formed by the activity of bacteria. The bacteria use sunlight and carbon dioxide to produce food, and they secrete a calcium carbonate matrix that forms the structure of the thrombolite.

The Lake Clifton Thrombolites are the largest and most extensive thrombolite reef in the southern hemisphere. They are estimated to be about 2,000 years old, but scientists believe that thrombolites may have existed as far back as 570 million years ago.

properties.name: Lake Argyle
properties.description: Lake Argyle, Australia's largest freshwater lake, is a sparkling oasis in the arid Kimberley region. With its turquoise waters, pristine beaches, and lush islands, it's a paradise for swimming, fishing, boating, and camping. Native wildlife, including freshwater crocodiles, fish, birds, and wallabies, abound in this unique ecosystem.

properties.name: Kojonup Rose Maze
properties.description: Stroll around the stunning display of Australian bred roses at the Kojonup Rose Maze and enjoy the most comprehensive public collection in the country. Take in the beauty of the gardens whilst sitting under one of many rustic pergolas scattered throughout the park. Engross yourself in the 500 metre long maze of roses.

properties.name: Hunts Well
properties.description: Hunts Well is a historical site located a few kilometres south of Tammin. It was once used as a watering point for prospectors and others en route to the Goldfields. It is worth stopping to see this important part of the state's history whilst out viewing the region's wildflowers.

properties.name: Greens Pool
properties.description:
Greens Pool, located at the edge of William Bay National Park, is renowned for its striking granite boulders, crystal-clear turquoise waters, and pristine white sandy beach. These boulders create a natural barrier, shielding the pool from the powerful Southern Ocean.

Stunning year-round, Greens Pool is especially popular in summer, offering calm waters perfect for family-friendly activities. Visitors can swim, snorkel, or simply relax on the beach or atop the surrounding rocks with breathtaking views of the water.

Snorkelers can explore the vibrant underwater landscape, home to an array of marine life. You might spot zebra fish, silver drummer, six-spined leatherjackets, and mosaic sea stars among the many fascinating creatures.

Due to its popularity during peak seasons like school and public holidays, parking at William Bay National Park can be limited, so it's best to visit outside these times if possible. Note that camping is not allowed within the park.

A short walk from Greens Pool takes you to Elephant Rocks, another must-see location ideal for swimming.

properties.name: Greenbushes Loop
properties.description:
The Greenbushes Loop is a delightful 15 km return walk trail that connects Greenbushes to the renowned Bibbulmun Track. Commencing at the Eco-Cultural Discovery Centre, the trail meanders through a captivating blend of jarrah and marri forest, adorned with a wildflower spectacle in spring. Enchanting sights include a natural swimming pool, granite rock waterfalls, and the serene Mount Jones Dam.

Upon crossing the dam walk, ascend the steps to join the Bibbulmun Track for an approximately 5 km stretch. The choice is yours - continue the loop back to Greenbushes or follow the Bibbulmun Track for a picturesque 6.7 km to the charming destination of Balingup.

properties.name: Ghost House Walk Trail
properties.description: The 12.4km loop Ghost House Walk Trail will take most of the day to complete, so make sure you have plenty of water your lunch and snacks. It takes you on a journey to discover the natural and cultural history of the wilderness areas in Yanchep National Park, an hour north of Perth. Along the way you will encounter the sights and sounds of the pristine wetlands and discover the historic remains of the �Ghost House'.

properties.name: Gantheaume Point
properties.description:
Gantheaume Point Viewpoint is a stunning coastal vantage point located near Broome in Western Australia. This viewpoint offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Indian Ocean and the rugged coastline. It's renowned for its distinctive red sandstone cliffs that contrast beautifully with the turquoise waters of the ocean. 

Aside from its natural beauty, Gantheaume Point is also known for its historical significance. The area is home to ancient dinosaur footprints embedded in the rocky shoreline, offering a glimpse into the prehistoric past of the region. 

Visitors can explore the viewpoint, take in the mesmerising vistas, and even learn about the dinosaur tracks through informative signs and displays.

properties.name: Fitzgerald Biosphere Reserve
properties.description: The Fitzgerald Biosphere is a UNESCO-designated biosphere reserve located on the south coast of Western Australia. It is one of the most biodiverse regions in Australia, with over 2,000 species of plants and 300 species of animals, many of which are found nowhere else on Earth.

properties.name: Fisherman's Lookout
properties.description: Fisherman's Lookout offers a panoramic view of Port Denison and the harbour. Watch the magnificent ocean waves crashing on the reef below. Visit the obelisk built in the late 1800s to commemorate the sailors' lives lost at sea.

properties.name: Emma Gorge at El Questro
properties.description:
Emma Gorge is one of the Kimberley's most spectacular and accessible gorges, set in the one-million-acre wilderness of El Questro. 

Enjoy the cool shade and dramatic beauty of its sheer 65-metre cliffs and crystal clear swimming waters.

properties.name: Dimond Gorge
properties.description:
Rugged and remote Dimond Gorge sits amidst the Kimberley outback near Mornington Wilderness Camp. 
Here, you can go bushwalking, swimming, canoeing and bird watching. 
You'll be amazed by the rich colours of the 30 metre-high cliff walls and abundant wildlife

properties.name: Denmark Dinosaur World
properties.description: Dinosaur World - Where the past meets the present. Interact with living dinosaurs, the birds and reptiles of today's world, including some friendly, furry locals.

properties.name: Culham Inlet
properties.description:
Culham Inlet is a 4,200-hectare coastal salt lake located on the south coast of Western Australia, about 10 kilometres west of the town of Hopetoun. It is separated from the Southern Ocean by a narrow sandbar.Culham Inlet is an important wetland area, and it is home to a variety of birds, fish, and other wildlife. The inlet is also a popular spot for fishing, swimming, and birdwatching. 

The best time to visit Culham Inlet is during the spring and autumn months, when the weather is mild and there are fewer crowds.

properties.name: Christmas Rock Walk
properties.description: The Christmas Rock Walk Trail is a scenic nature trail through the bushland and beautiful wildflowers just outside of Wongan Hills. Take the leisurely 40 minute walk to the rock wall that is used to divert water down to the town dam. Look out for the kangaroos and other marsupials that live in the surrounding bush.

properties.name: Chinaman's Pool and Picnic Area
properties.description: Chinaman's Pool and Picnic Area is a popular spot located in Marble Bar, Western Australia, known for its crystal-clear waters and picturesque setting. The pool is surrounded by towering cliffs and lush greenery, making it a great place to cool off on a hot day or relax and enjoy a picnic.

properties.name: Cape Le Grand Beach
properties.description:
There aren’t too many places in Australia where kangaroos sunbake on the beach, but at Cape Le Grand National Park this is just one of the many natural highs on offer.

This pristine park near Esperance is known for its stunning scenery like this idyllic beach.

properties.name: Cape Keraudren Nature Reserve
properties.description: Cape Keraudren Nature Reserve is a beautiful coastal reserve located in the Pilbara region of Western Australia, about 150 kilometres north of Port Hedland. The reserve is known for its pristine white sand beaches, crystal-clear waters, and diverse wildlife.

properties.name: KCGM Super Pit Lookout
properties.description: The Super Pit one of Australia's largest open pit gold mines. Kalgoorlie Consolidated Gold Mines (KCGM) Operation is a world class asset located adjacent to the City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder approximately 600 kilometres east of Perth, Western Australia.

properties.name: Stubbs Park
properties.description: 72 hrs overnight area for self contained campers. There are also toilets and a dump station.

properties.name: Mt Bruce Walking Trail
properties.description:
The Mount Bruce Walking Trail is a 9-kilometre (5.6-mile) out-and-back trail that takes hikers to the summit of Mount Bruce, the highest point in the Hamersley Range. The trail is moderately steep and challenging, with some rock scrambling required. 

The trail offers stunning views of the Hamersley Range and the surrounding countryside. Hikers may also spot kangaroos, wallabies, and other wildlife along the way.

properties.name: Circular Pool
properties.description:
Circular Pool is a popular picnic spot on the Frankland River with rapids in the winter and a large, tranquil pool in summer.

Paths lead to two viewing platforms that allow you to look over the Frankland River and down to Circular Pool or into the forest. There is a boardwalk around the pool below and a picnic table so that you can enjoy a peaceful picnic or meditate by the waters edge.

properties.name: Walpole YHA
properties.description: A warm homely atmosphere awaits you at Tingle All Over YHA. This Walpole hostel has a spacious kitchen and wood fire in the lounge during winter, as well as heaters in most rooms.

properties.name: Thomas River Shire Reserve Campground
properties.description: Thomas River Shire Reserve Camp is located at the mouth of the Thomas River in Cape Arid National Park. Visitors can enjoy canoeing and kayaking along the river, as well as fishing. Nestled in the midst of banksia woodland, the campground includes a shaded shelter and toilets as basic facilities

properties.name: Belvidere Camp
properties.description:
Nestled amongst tuart forest in the Leschenault Peninsula Conservation Park, Belivedere Camp is the perfect spot for enjoying snorkelling, swimming and fishing. 
The area is also popular for birdwatching and seeing dolphins playing on the southern and western sides of the peninsula.

properties.name: Banksia Campground
properties.description: Located in the D'Entrecasteaux National Park, Banksia Camp is a shared camping shelter with four bedrooms and a common area designed to accommodate 12 people comfortably. It's accessible only by 4WD and is an ideal spot for enjoying bushwalking, four-wheel driving, photography, fishing and bird watching.

properties.name: Young River Rest Area
properties.description: Decent size drive-through bay located directly by the highway behind some trees. No facilities and limited shade.

properties.name: Willow Springs Camping Area
properties.description: This scenic campsite is a remainder of a sawmill that once occupied this area. It has no amenities, however, it offers flat and shaded campsites with views over the ruins and a few pleasant trek opportunities. Not suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Port Hedland Turf Club
properties.description: This nice camping area with rubbish bins and a dump point is located in the Town of Port Hedland, close to the beach and approx. 500m from the local shops.

properties.name: New Beach
properties.description: Beach front campground with no facilities located an easy drive away from the main road. There are greywater tanks provided to dispose of waste and the site is being serviced weekly by the rangers. Great location for swimming and fishing. Please do not collect wood for fires and leave no trace!

properties.name: Meckering Memorial Park
properties.description: A big and slightly sloping roadside rest area located in town, just in front of a store and Shell station. There are toilets and drinking water available and the rose gardens are very pleasant to look at. The surface is a mix of sealed and gravel, with some grass available at the very back. There is also plenty of shade.

properties.name: Marrinup Town Site Campground
properties.description: This peaceful camping area with good amenities is located in a forest, which provides good shade. There are a few walking tracks and it's also good for cycling. Suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Lake Johnston
properties.description: This scenic and open campground is located on a very long drive with two circular areas, just off the highway. It is situated along the shore of a salt lake which is often dry. It has basic amenities and is easily accessible by all vehicles, however only SC vehicles can stay here overnight.

properties.name: Koolanooka Springs
properties.description: Really large gravel roadside rest area with basic facilities. The further away from the highway you drive, the lower the noise levels become and there is plenty of space to get away from the traffic noise.

properties.name: Grotto Creek Camping Area
properties.description: This remote campsite boasts scenic views over the grotto and is located 1.3km off the main road. There are no amenities here and the site is rather small, so it is not suitable for bigger vehicles. The waterfall provides good swimming opportunities.

properties.name: Credo Homestead
properties.description:
Credo Homestead is a former pastoral station situated within the Rowles Lagoon catchment.

There are six rooms available in the old shearers' quarters and a number of bush camping sites. Facilities include picnic tables, barbecue fire rings and toilets with accommodation at the old shearers' quarters including four flushing toilets and four showers.

Camping fees apply and bookings can be made through the Parks and Wildlife Kalgoorlie office or to the caretakers on-site.

No dogs (or other pets) allowed at this campground

properties.name: Harvey Dickson's Country Music Centre Campground
properties.description:
Harvey Dickson's Country Music Centre offers bush camping at three different sites. 

Camping amenities are limited to toilets, dam water taps, and rain water tanks for drinking water. 

The music centre is open 7 days a week with rodeo shows, music shows, tours and food. Bookings can be made in advance, but aren’t necessary.

properties.name: Pingelly Caravan Park
properties.description:
The Pingelly caravan park is managed by the Community Craft Centre. All bookings can be made through the Craft Centre on (08) 9887 1351. The caravan park is located at 26 Sharow Street.

Pingelly very much welcomes touring caravan and RV clubs. Where large groups come to town arrangements are made to park the vans as a group at our Recreation Ground. Powered sites are available there and clubs can arrange to hire the Community Centre for events. There is an RV dump site at the Recreation Ground.

properties.name: Cape Riche Campground
properties.description: Cape Riche Campground features family- friendly campgrounds overlooking the ocean, down unsealed road. Facilities include toilets, showers, free BBQs, fire pits, and a boat ramp. Caretakers are on residence. Call for enquiries.

properties.name: Gnoorea Point (40-Mile)
properties.description: Gnoorea Point (40-Mile) is a natural camping area, with no facilities. Fees apply from May- September and must be paid to the Shire of Roebourne caretaker on site. Maximum stay during peak season is 28 days. During off-peak season (October- April), no fees apply, but maximum length of stay is 3 days.

properties.name: Munglinup Beach
properties.description: Munglinup Beach is easily accessible by 2WD, with basic bush facilities including toilets and non-drinkable water.

properties.name: Alexandra Bridge Camping Area
properties.description: Alexandra Bridge Camping Area is situated along the peaceful banks of the Blackwood River, with opportunity to fish, boat, swim and canoe. Basic facilities are available, including toilets, cold showers, picnic tables, gas barbecues, water and rubbish bins. Sites are on a first-come-first-serve basis. Caretaker will collect fees.

properties.name: Wuggubun Aboriginal Community Campground
properties.description:
Wuggubun Aboriginal Community Campground offers camping between April and October in a natural environment. 

Ten campsites are available with facilities including a community hall, ablutions block and visitors shelter. 

Call for bookings and more information.

properties.name: Stockton Lake Recreation Area
properties.description: Stockton Lake Recreation Area offers lake side camping amongst trees with accessible toilets. Camp fires are permitted, except in case of fire ban. Call for more information. Sites are available on a first-come-first-serve basis.

properties.name: Congelin Campground
properties.description:
The Congelin campground has eight caravan bays and a group camping area with room for approximately 30 campers.

Fires are not permitted between the dates stated at the campsite.

A small water tank is available for use but water supply and quality are not guaranteed. Visitors should bring their own water.

The campground is a great place to see marsupials and birds but please do not feed them.

No Dogs .

properties.name: Wyalkatchem Travellers Park
properties.description: Wyalkatchem Travellers Park offers powered and unpowered sites. Facilities include showers, camp kitchen, laundry area, BBQ and dump station. Pets are allowed.
properties.fees: $35 for en-suite site with power and water. $25 unpowered shared ammenities

properties.name: Coronation Beach
properties.description: Coronation Beach camping area is suitable for caravans and motorhomes. Facilities include toilets, dump point, wood fireplace and picnic tables. Pets are allowed. Generators are permitted with conidtions. There is a caretaker on site. Peak season can become very busy. No bookings are required.

properties.name: King Edward River Campground No 2
properties.description:
This is one of the two large camping areas at King Edward River, managed by Traditional Owners. Campfires are permitted (bring your own firewood). These sites are popular with campers due to the rare opportunity to swim and the ample shade available. Nearby, you can find impressive Aboriginal rock art—ask the caretakers for directions.

The site offers easy day access to Punamii-Uunpuu (Mitchell Falls), river swimming, waterfalls, and Wanjina & Gwion rock art. Guided tours with Traditional Owners are available.

The campground is open from May 1 to September 30, and no bookings are required.

Please note: Pets are not allowed. 

To camp at Munurru, you must hold a Uunguu Visitor Pass (UVP). The facilities are basic.

properties.name: Wandering Caravan Park
properties.description: Wandering Caravan Park and camping area offers 4 powered sites. Facilities include ablution block, bins, and BBQs (on Main St.). There is a camp kitchen available for use with a $50 cash deposit. Pets are not allowed. Bookings can be made at the Shire of Wandering Office on Watts Street.

properties.name: Mullewa Caravan Park
properties.description: Mullewa Caravan Park provides powered and unpowered sites, suitable for tents, caravans and large rigs. Facilities include laundry, toilets, showers, BBQ and dump point. Cash payments can be made at the Ampol Deli in town.
properties.fees: AUD $20 per unpowered site. AUD $30 per powered site

properties.name: Quairading Travellers Rest Area
properties.description:
Although this is officially a Rest Area, the Department of Main Roads has allowed overnight stays at this location. Time limits do apply, which are detailed in our features below, and should also be clearly posted on site.

Rest areas in Western Australia, provided by Main Roads, are intended for short breaks to help reduce driver fatigue.

Please note that rest areas are not meant to serve as campgrounds or caravan parks. Using them for multiple overnight stays as part of your itinerary is not consistent with their intended purpose.

For longer stays, it's recommended to find designated camping areas or caravan parks in nearby towns.

Permits can be obtained from the Shire Office or the caretaker.

properties.name: Old Halls Creek Lodge
properties.description: Old Halls Creek Lodge provides powered and unpoweredsites for tents and caravans. Facilities include toilets, showers, wood fireplace and BBQ. Pets are allowed.
properties.fees: AUD $17 per 2 people tent site. AUD $20 per caravan site

properties.name: Harrismith Caravan Park
properties.description:
Harrismith Caravan Park offers powered and unpowered sites for tents, caravans and long rigs. 

Facilities include toilets, showers, and BBQ area. There is food and fuel available. 

Bookings and information is available through the Oasis Hotel.

properties.name: Cranbrook RV Stop
properties.description: Cranbrook RV Stop is suitable for self contained vehicles only. Facilities include dump point and potable water. Permits are available from the Shire Office. There is a maximum stay of 48 hours.

properties.name: Chuditch Campground
properties.description:
Chuditch is a medium-size campground in jarrah forest, close to the Murray Valley Mountain Bike Trails and a short distance from the Chuditch picnic area with access to launch kayaks on the Murray River.

Booking:
Bookings are essential and can be made up to 180 days (approximately six months) before arrival and for one campsite only.

If you are an outdoor education provider, licensed commercial tour operator or are organising an event (friends, family and other social groups camping together does not constitute an event), contact Parks and Wildlife Service Dwellingup Work Centre to discuss your requirements.

Campsites:
Twenty-four campsites that vary significantly due to the forest setting. Most campsites are suitable for tents and swags only.

All campsites are unpowered.

Check campsite details and the campground map carefully when booking

Facilities:
Drinking water not provided. Rainwater may be seasonally available but supply is not guaranteed and treatment is required to make safe for consumption.

No-flush pit toilets.

Dining shelter with gas barbecues, dishwashing sinks with unheated rainwater (not guaranteed year-round), food preparation surfaces, picnic tables and benches and solar-powered lighting.

Toilets and dining shelter are accessible to people in a wheelchair.

All campsites have a picnic table and benches.

Campground Rules:
- No campfires at any time.
- Dogs are permitted. They must be controlled on a leash at all times.
- Generator use is permitted at all campsites between 8am-9pm only.
- Do not empty your portable toilet waste into campground toilets. Carry waste out of the park for disposal in an authorised dump point.
- Dispose of non-toilet waste in the bins provided at the campground or carry out of the park

Fees:
A per person camping fee and a per vehicle park entry fee apply.

Camping fee must be paid by Mastercard or VISA when booking.

Vehicle entry fee may be paid when booking, on arrival at Lane Poole Reserve or by purchasing a park pass and is required for motor vehicles only. Payment is not required for trailers, including camper trailers and caravans.

properties.name: Westonia Caravan Park
properties.description: Westonia Caravan Park provides powered and unpowered sites suitable for vehicle based camping, camper trailers and caravans. Facilities include toilets, showers, camp kitchen, coin operated laundry area, BBQ and picnic tables. Dogs are permitted. Bookings can be made by phone.

properties.name: Bencubbin Caravan Park
properties.description:
Bencubbin Caravan Park provides powered and unpowered sites suitable for camping and caravans. 

The Caravan Park has a shared kitchen, with tables, three ovens, two fridges and freezers, microwaves, toasters, kettles, toastie makers, and cooking utensils. It also has an ablution block with washing machines, dryers, toilets and showers.

There are also cabins available for hire. 

Camp fees can be paid at the council office.

properties.name: Canna Hall
properties.description: Canna Hall camping area offers powered sites for all camping vehicles. Facilities include drinking water, hot showers, toilets, BBQ and shelter. Generators are allowed.

properties.name: Breakaway Campground
properties.description:
Breakaway Campground located in Coalseam Conservation Park, provides sites for caravans and tents. 

There are no facilities at this site. 

1km to the east of the River Bend, you can find toilets, BBQs, and picnic tables. Generators are allowed between 8am and 8pm. 

There is a maximum stay of 3 nights during the peak season.  

You will need to bring your own water. 

Camping fees apply from around mid July to October. 

Advanced bookings are not taken.

properties.name: Charlies Flat Campground
properties.description:
Lane Poole Reserve covers some 55,000 hectares of Jarrah forest just 100 kilometres from Perth near Dwellingup. The Murray River flows through the reserve and offers numerous recreational activities from swimming and canoeing to white-water rafting.

Charlie's Flat is one of a number of small campgrounds situated along the Murray River within Lane Poole Reserve. Charlie's Flat has 16 campsites that are ideal for families; it is not intended for group usage. The campground has barbecue pits, picnic tables, toilets and rubbish bins.

Provision has been made at four sites to allow for smaller caravans or camper trailers, larger vehicles will need to find a site at either Nanga Mill or Baden Powell.

properties.name: Nungarin Recreation Ground
properties.description:
The Shire of Nungarin's Recreation Ground, Caravan and Camping Facilities is a small but vibrant caravan park that has a range of power and unpowered sites.

The park has an outdoor shaded barbeque and entertaining area, a children's playground, and bathroom facilities currently located inside the recreation centre, including a disabled shower and toilet.

The Recreation Ground, Caravan and Camping Facilities is close to the local aquatic center, open during the summer months.

Brochures, maps and visitors guides of the area are available at the Shire and the Nungarin Visitors Centre (Post Office Building) on Railway Avenue. Facilities include BBQ, campers kitchen, playground, hot showers and kiosk. 

Dogs are allowed, please enquire first.

properties.name: Northbrook Farmstay
properties.description: Northbrook Farmstay provides a range of accomodation, including powered sites, camp sites, and cottages.  Campground facilities include showers, toilets, BBQ and cooking area, and fire pit. Local attractions include Chiverton House Museum, Kalbarri National Park and Horrocks beach. Bookings can be made online.
properties.fees: AUD $25 2ppl/powered site AUD $20 2ppl/non-powered site. $5 additional person

properties.name: Mogumber Oval and Reserve
properties.description:
The facilities are managed by dedicated local community volunteers, with support from the Shire of Victoria Plains. You can camp here for up to 48 hours, with a nightly fee of $10.50. A donation box is located inside the BBQ shelter, and all contributions go towards improving community amenities.

The site offers toilets, picnic tables, and a barbecue area, with plenty of shady spots around the oval. It's dog-friendly, and larger groups can book the hall, which includes a kitchen and showers. Enjoy a walk to the historic wooden Mogumber Bridge or explore the 55 hectares of nearby reserve, ideal for nature strolls.

On weekends, small rodeo events often take place in the arena next to the oval, and the area is well-known for the Mogumber Outback Club New Year’s Eve Rodeo, a community-run event. The Mogumber Tavern, open every evening, is just a short walk away.

properties.name: Nanga Mill Lane Pool Reserve
properties.description: Nanga Mill camping area is located in Lane Pool Reserve. It offers campsites for vehilce based camping, caravans and camper trailers. Facilities include toilets, picnic tables, dirnking water and wood fireplaces. Activities include swimming, fishing, biking and walking trails. Pets are allowed. Bookings cannot be made.
properties.fees: $7.50 per adult per night + $12.50 park fee

properties.name: McCorry's Old Hotel Caravan Facility
properties.description:
McCorrys Old Hotel Caravan Facility offers powered and unpowered camp sites. 

Facilities include toilets, showers, laundry, water and BBQ. Pets are allowed.
properties.fees: AUD $20 per night/2 ppl powered, additional guest $5. $15 per night/2 ppl unpowered.

properties.name: New Norcia Caravan Park
properties.description:
New Norcia Caravan Park offers 5 powered overnight stops and an area for self-contained caravans. Facilities include toilets and showers. 

We have nine overnight stops with power and basic shower and toilet facilities at the New Norcia Roadhouse. We also have a designated area available for self-contained caravans. Please visit the Roadhouse during business hours for more information (please note, sites cannot be booked ahead).

There is a coin operated laundry service available. Bookings can be made at the Roadhouse during business hours or after hours at the Hotel.

properties.name: The Stringers Campground
properties.description:
Stringers is a small campground in jarrah forest on the Murray River with access for swimming and kayaking.

Booking:
Bookings are essential and can be made up to 180 days (approximately six months) before arrival and for one campsite only.

If you are an outdoor education provider, licensed commercial tour operator or are organising an event (friends, family and other social groups camping together does not constitute an event), contact Parks and Wildlife Service Dwellingup Work Centre to discuss your requirements.

Campsites:
Six campsites that vary due to the forest setting and are suitable for tents and swags only.

All campsites are unpowered.

Check campsite details and the campground map carefully when booking.

Facilities:
No-flush pit toilets.

All campsites have a picnic table and benches and a fire ring.

Campground Rules:
- Campfires when conditions permit and in the fire rings provided only. Usual permitted season: April - November.
- Bring your own firewood. Collecting firewood and kindling is not permitted in national parks and other conservation reserves.
- Dogs are permitted. They must be controlled on a leash at all times.
- Generator use is permitted at all campsites between 8am-9pm only.
- Do not empty portable toilet waste into campground toilets. Carry waste out of the park for disposal in an authorised dump point.
- Dispose of non-toilet waste in the bins provided at the campground or carry out of the park.

Fees:
A per person camping fee and a per vehicle park entry fee apply.

Camping fee must be paid by Mastercard or VISA when booking.

Vehicle entry fee may be paid when booking, on arrival at Lane Poole Reserve or by purchasing a park pass and is required for motor vehicles only. Payment is not required for trailers, including camper trailers and caravans.
properties.fees: AUD $7.50 per adult $2.20 child. Under 5's are free

properties.name: Starvation Bay Campground
properties.description: Starvation Boat Harbour is suitable for tents, vehicle based camping, camper trailers and caravans. Facilities include toilets, boat ramp and BBQ.  Local activities include fishing, boating, swimming and walking trails. You will need to bring your own water. Fires are permitted druing the fire danger season. There is a ranger on site.

properties.name: Quairading Caravan Park
properties.description: Quairading Caravan Park offers powered and non-powered sites suitable for tents and caravans and new cabins. Facilities include swimming pool next door, fire pit, toilets, showers, laundromat, BBQ and picnic tables. Dogs are allowed.

properties.name: Workmans Pool
properties.description:
Located in St Johns Brook Conservation Park, Workmans Pool Camp is situated close to picturesque river pools, making it a favourite for swimming and picnicking.

The Park also has a fascinating saw-milling history from the early last century that is still evident today around Barrabup Pool and along the Old Timberline Trail - a track that can be enjoyed on foot or bike.

Workmans Pool is a small campground in Jarrah-marri forest about 1km from Barrabup Pool.

Bookings are essential and can be made up to 180 days (approximately six months) before arrival and for one campsite only.

There are six campsites which are suitable for tents and swags only and have steps between the tent and parking spaces. Please note some campsites are subject to standing water after heavy rain.

All campsites have a picnic table and benches and a fire ring and there are no-flush pit toilets.

properties.name: Woodanilling Recreation Reserve
properties.description:
There is a designated area for RV camping, along with an RV dump point at the Woodanilling Recreation Reserve and adjoining the Woodanilling Golf Course. Potable water is available. 

Overnight fees apply.

properties.name: Pannawonica Transit Site
properties.description: Pannawonica Transit Site offers powered and unpowered sites for caravans, motorhomes and campers. Facilities include toilets, showers and water. Pets are allowed. Bookings can be made over the phone.

properties.name: Gabyon Station
properties.description: Gabyon Station Stay operates as a working sheep station. Accomodation includes homestead rooms, shearers' quarters, caravn and camping sites. Facilities include camp kitchen, hot showers, BBQ, fire pit and swimming pool.

properties.name: Dowerin Roadhouse & Caratel Park
properties.description:
This is owned and operated by the Dowerin Roadhouse, which can be found on the Dowerin - Goomalling Road.

It has caravan bays and cabins.

properties.name: Kojonup Rest Area
properties.description: Located on the eastern side of the Albany Hwy, Kojonup Rest Area is suitable for all sized caravans. There are covered picnic tables on site. No other facilities are available.

properties.name: Munurru (King Edward River) Campground
properties.description:
Munurru Campground is the first campground when you cross over the King Edward River into Ngauwudu (Mitchell Plateau) and is managed by the Traditional Owners, the Wunambal Gaambera people and their Uunguu Rangers. The campground is open annually from 1 May to 15 October.

The highlight of visiting Ngauwudu is Punamii-Uunpuu (Mitchell Falls) and Munurru Campground - it is an ideal place to make your base camp to explore the area with easy day access to these iconic falls.

The campsites are spacious and serene, set in true Kimberley bush. There is wonderful river swimming, nearby waterfalls, Wanjina Gwion rock art and tours, campfires (BYO firewood), bird-watching, wildlife, bushwalking, and toilets.

To camp at Munurru you must be the holder of a Uunguu Visitor Pass (UVP), which provides Traditional Owner permission to visit approved visitor locations in Wunambal Gaambera Country. Purchase online on their website or from the Kimberley Visitor Centre.

This is one of 2 camping areas along the King Edward River. The campsite is suitable for tents, caravans and camper trailers. 

There are limited powered sites. Facilities include toilets, picnic tables and phone access.

properties.name: Warakurna Roadhouse
properties.description: Warakurna Roadhouse is located in Western Australia. The campsites are suitable for tents, caravans, camper trailers and motorhomes. There are both powered and non- powered sites available. Great facilities including a well stocked store offering personal items, fruit, veggies and ice creams.

properties.name: Leinster Caravan Park
properties.description: Leinster Caravan Park's campsites are suitable for tents, caravans and camper trailers. Facilities include picnic tables, toilets, showers and drinking water. Powered sites and a laundromat are available onsite

properties.name: Grass Patch Park & Stay
properties.description: Grass Patch Park and Stay is located in WA. This is a community based overnight camping area. Fees are payable at the tavern. There is limited powered sites available. Facilities include toilets, showers, water, BBQ facilities and access to a Laundromat.

properties.name: Miliyana Campground
properties.description:
Set in the bush, close to Millstream Creek, Miliyanha campground offers modern facilities including toilets, a camp kitchen, gas BBQ and hot water. 

In the area, you can enjoy bushwalking. Dogs and fuel fires are not permitted. Generators are allowed. 

Miliyanha is suitable for all camping equipment. The campground has non-flush toilets, sheltered gas barbecues including dishwashing facilities and picnic tables.

Online booking essential

You can get to this site by: Two-wheel drive - variable road condition.

properties.name: Conto Field Campground
properties.description: Conto Field campground has 116 camp sites among the coastal peppermint woodland. Sites are suitable for tents, campervans and camping trailers. Facilities include toilets, BBQ, firepit, and picnic tables. Generators are not permitted. Bookings cannot be made.

properties.name: Kurrajong Campground
properties.description: Kurrajong campground in Purnululu National park can accomodate tents, large 4WD campervans, caravans and camper trailers. There are a variety of walking trails in the park. This non powered campground is closed during the Kimberley wet season and bookings are online only. Bore water is avilable, but must be treated. Non-flush toilets are avialable. Generators, campfires or solid fuel appliances are not allowed.

properties.name: Bald Hill Campground
properties.description: Bad Hill campground is located on top of Bald hill with views of the Avon Valley Park. This site is suitable for small carvans or camper trailers only. It features tent sites, fire rings, picnic tables, untreated water and toilets. Liquid or gas BBQs are allowed,unless a fire ban has been declared. Registration is available on Quarry Road.

properties.name: Crystal Springs Campground
properties.description: Crystal Springs is an open campground that can accommodate tents, small campervans and camper trailers. Caravans and larger campervans are not permitted. There are toilets, picnic tables and wood barbecues. Campers own liquid or gas fuel barbeques, stoves and heaters can be used

properties.name: Valley Campground
properties.description: Valley Campground features sites suitable for tents, small caravans or camper trailers picnic tables, fire rings toilets and untreated water. All roads within the park are unsealed. Campfires are only permitted in the fire rings, however fire restrictions may be imposed at any time. Campers own liquid or gas fuel BBQ's, stoves and heaters can be used. The site facilities include picnic tables and a public toilet.
properties.fees: AUD$7.50 per Adult AUD$2.20 per Child

properties.name: Moingup Springs Campground
properties.description: Low Cost Campground with toilet facilities and gas barbeques. No Campfires allowed at anytime. Campers own liquid or gas fuel barbeques, stoves and heaters can be used at any time unless a total fire ban has been declared. A great Campground for Bushwalking. There are 2 resident rangers in the area.
properties.fees: AUD$11 per Adult/ AUD$2.20 per Child

properties.name: Ellendale Rest Area
properties.description: This large, flat rest area is located just off the highway. There is a toilet and a limited shade. Suitable for big rigs with 24hrs maximum stay.

properties.name: Dangin Rest Area
properties.description: This roadside parking is located close to the railway station and is suitable for all vehicles. There are no facilities (other than bins) and limited shade.

properties.name: Cliff Head North Rest Area
properties.description:
Located a stone's throw from Cliff Head North Rest Area, this spacious parking area is located on the beach and has clean drop toilets  and picnic tables. 

Some parts are accessible by 2WD, the rest by 4WD across sand.

It boasts spectacular ocean views, but not much shade.

properties.name: Caroline Pool Camping Area
properties.description: This camp site - featuring a natural swimming pool, but no amenities - is available for overnight stays with 24hrs limit. When exiting the main road, follow the track and turn left after 500m. Continue straight for another 1.5km, until you reach this site.

properties.name: Connolys Flat
properties.description: Spacious drive-through rest area with no facilities. It is separated from the highway by a lush string of trees which limits the traffic noise. There are many trees around and the surface is level with an occasional chuckhole.

properties.name: Balladonia Parking Bay
properties.description: Decent size gravel bay located directly by the highway. No facilities and limited shade.

properties.name: Gasocoyne River Rest Area Middle Branch
properties.description: This is a rest area 192 km NW of Meekatharra and 230 km S of Newman. There is access on each side of the bridge and a small concrete causeway connecting both - if the river is in flood this is impassable and the site may also be muddy or wet. The track to the camping areas is dirt and in good condition. There are some fire rings here, a rubbish bin and picnic table, but no other facilities. It is shady and there is some seclusion in the bush, but it is still close to the highway. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Kirkalocka Station 24 Hour Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Main Roads Western Australia 24 hour stopping area at Kirkalocka Station. There is a large bitumen pullover suitable for trucks and larger vehicles. Adjacent is a dirt parking area with a toilet, dump station, picnic area, and rubbish bins. There is some shade. It is right on the road so it is not secluded and it is noisy. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Paynes Find Camp Spot
properties.description: This is a camping spot 12 km N of Payne's Find or 132 km S of Mount Magnet. There is a secluded and hidden dirt track on the Western side of the road that leads to this area and it is easy to miss. Follow the track 1.2 km the bush will open up to a freedom camping area. There are also plenty of secluded bush sites throughout this area. There are no facilities, but some man-made fire rings. All types of vehicles can access this area, but large vehicles may have trouble with narrow tracks and turnarounds. There is shade and seclusion, but some noise from the highway is heard.

properties.name: Jibberding Nature Reserve Rest Area
properties.description: This is a camping spot 22 km NE of Wubin or 131 km SW of Payne's Find. It is a large dirt area with a good dirt road access from the highway. There are no facilities. There is very little shade. It is quiet and secluded but some road noise is heard as the highway is a road train route. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Koojan Salmon Gum Reserve
properties.description: This is a nature reserve just North of Koojan. It is a large forested area with different types of gumtrees. There is a large dirt parking area that is suitable for all types of vehicles but can be bumpy in parts. There is a picnic table and rubbish bins but no other facilities. There is a short nature walk through the gums as well. It is a shady area and at night it is quiet, but there is the occasional road noise. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Boorabbin Memorial Rest Area
properties.description: This is a large bitumen pullover with toilets and rubbish on the Eastern side of Boorabbin National Park. It is a memorial to those who lost there lives in the Boorabbin bush fire. There is a short walk to a memorial stone and informational gazebo.There is an extensive network of dirt tracks leading to bush camp sites. Some shade is available. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Frenchman Bay Lookout
properties.description: Frenchman Bay Lookout is a popular tourist destination in Albany. It offers stunning views of Frenchman Bay, the King George Sound, and the surrounding coastline. The lookout is located on a hilltop overlooking Frenchman Bay. It is accessible by a short walk from the Frenchman Bay car park. Once at the lookout, there is a platform with seating where you can relax and enjoy the views.

properties.name: Surfer's Point Margaret River
properties.description: A world-renowned surf spot with powerful waves and stunning views of the Indian Ocean.

properties.name: Freshwater Point Rest Area
properties.description: This is a camping area 48 km S of Dongara off Indian Ocean Dr. It is a small dirt area with beachside camping. There is a long drop toilet and rubbish bins but no other facilities. It is a small area that can accommodate 8-12 vehicles comfortably. There is some, but little, shade. It is quiet and peaceful but some road noise is heard from the highway. Maximum stay: 72 Hours. This site is no longer free. Now $20 per vehicle per night

properties.name: Merredin Reserve Parking
properties.description: This is a designated parking area for self-contained recreation vehicles in Merredin. It is adjacent to a parkland reserve and picnic area. The camping area has no facilities, but there are picnic tables and rubbish bins in the picnic area. It is a shady dirt-surfaced bush camp site that is accessible but all types of vehicles. There are some low hanging tree branches. Maximum stay: 24 Hours

properties.name: Herbert Parker (Yule River)
properties.description: This campground is not signposted, so you have to watch the gps location. There is a turnoff which leads you to the campground, and you need to go through a gate as well. The campground itself has several bins provided and lots of trees around it, so you can definitely get some shade. It's Aalto quite a big area so it will fit a lot of vehicles. You camp next to the river on a sandy road.

properties.name: Gorge Rock Pool Picnic Area
properties.description: This beautiful picnic area with no amenities, except for a picnic table and non-potable water, is located well off the road. It offers scenic views from the rock and good diversity of wildflowers around. There is enough room for a few caravans. It is accessible via a dirt track.

properties.name: Doolena Gorge
properties.description: This camp ground is located by the Coongan River, just 1.5km off the highway via a long dirt track. There are no amenities, however this site is famous for fishing and beautiful sunset views. 4WD access is recommended.

properties.name: Yuna Hall Rest Area
properties.description: This quiet campground is located behind Yuna town hall. It provides large unsealed parking area with toilets and some shade available. 24hrs limit applies.

properties.name: Lyndon River East Rest Area
properties.description: Long drive-through rest area with good facilities. It is separated from the highway by some scrub, which limits the traffic noise slightly and is adjacent to the Lyndon River. There is not much shade or privacy and the site is frequented by trucks. There are warning signs for flash flooding, so please use only in dry weather.

properties.name: Meckering Memorial Park
properties.description: This is a overnight parking area for RVs in the small town of Meckering. The area is a large sealed carpark without shade. Next to this area is a park with a barbecue, playground, picnic table, toilet, and rubbish bins. There is a dump station here as well. It is next to the road, so it can be loud at times. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Bilyuin Pool Camping Area
properties.description: Large riverside camp ground providing plenty of camping spots and shade, but no facilities. Water levels vary depending on the season. Access by dirt road.

properties.name: Camp Paradise
properties.description: A hillside campground located off the main road. It's a large and pleasant clearing with no amenities. 4WD recommended access.

properties.name: Palm Springs
properties.description: Very relaxing, nice camping area. You camp next to the springs and the road, but there won't be many noises as it is a really quite road. There are bins provided and there are some trees around for shade. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Quondong
properties.description: Take the turn of to Quondong point which will lead you to the campground. It's a beautiful spot with lookouts over the sea. This campground is separated into little camp areas along a dirt, sandy road. The camp areas are surrounded by bush and you camp on dirt or sand.

properties.name: Dundas Rocks Camping
properties.description: This is a historic settlement and camping area 25 km S of Norseman or 46 km N of Kumarl. 2 km E of Hwy. There is a 2 km dirt road in good condition. The site is on high ground but some of the road is lower and could be muddy in wet weather. There is a picnic table, fire pit, rubbish bins, and historical interpretive panels as well as a retaining wall from the old settlement. This is a quiet, secluded and peaceful shady site. All types of vehicles can access this area but there are some tight corners and turns that large vehicles may have trouble navigating.

properties.name: The Breakaways
properties.description: Shady dirt camp area on Hyden-Norsemen Rd. Toilets, picnic table and BBQ facilities available. Located 135km E of Hyden. Dirt road.

properties.name: Robe River Rest Area
properties.description: This camping area is located by a usually dry river, just off the highway. It has good amenities and is large and mainly level, with an occasional chuckhole. There are trees scattered here and there for shade, as well as sheltered picnic tables and a dump point.

properties.name: The Boab Rest Area
properties.description: Rest area is located next to the highway so it can be noisy. There are four shaded picnic tables and a few bins provided. Two of the picnic tables have shade because of the big boab tree in the middle of the rest area. You can not park right next to it, but you can have lunch or dinner underneath it. You can camp on the side of the gravel road.

properties.name: Des Streckfuss Rest Area
properties.description: A very large campground with good facilities and spectacular views, located well off the highway. This area offers plenty of side tracks that access both a large pool on Gorge Creek, as well as some more secluded camping sites. It is easily accessible by all vehicles and max stay is 24hrs.

properties.name: Sawpit Gorge
properties.description: Beautiful camping spot as you can camp next to the gorge. You camp on a rocky ground and there are a lot of trees around the camping spot. You can go for a swim, but there might be freshwater crocodiles. 4wd is recommended to the gorge as you go down a windy, steep and sandy road. You can do it with 2wd, but 4wd is recommended. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Elachbutting Rock Camping Area
properties.description:
This large camping area is located around the rock in the Elachbutting Nature Reserve and provides scenic views and many walking tracks. There are basic facilities including toilets and picnic tables. 

The campground is surrounded by trees which will give you shelter and shade. 

4WD recommended.

properties.name: Goldwire Rest Area
properties.description: Very big rest area about 150m off of the highway. There are flush public toilets, three large sheltered picnic areas and several bins and fire barbecues provided. This rest area fits a lot of people, it has lots of little bays and roundabouts where you can camp. You camp on a gravel ground and the rest area is surrounded by bush and trees. There are also some trees around the rest area.

properties.name: Lake Ninan Rest Area
properties.description: Large sandy camping area on the E side of Lake Ninan. Picnic table and bins available. Located off Calingiri-Wogan Hills Rd, 10km SW of Wongan Hills. Max stay: 48hrs.

properties.name: Eaglestone Rock Camping Area
properties.description: Large rest area popular with rock climbers, located just off the main road. It has basic amenities, limited shade, and is easily accessible by all vehicles.

properties.name: Myroodah Crossing
properties.description: Various campspots on both sides of Fitzroy River. No facilities, some shade from trees. Located on  Myroodah-Luluigui Rd, 10km SW of Looma. Dirt road. Max stay: 72hrs.

properties.name: Moonera Tank Rest Area
properties.description: This is a standard Eyre highway rest area. There is a dirt road that leads to a large dirt area with bush and trees separating the area. There are rubbish bins and fire rings as well as an emergency phone but no other facilities. No water tank here. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. This site is medium sized and secluded. There is road noise. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Three Springs Parking Area
properties.description: Parking area next to the sportsground on Mayrhofer St in Three Springs. Toilets, picnic tables and bins available. Facilities only open during daylight hours. Max stay: 48hrs.

properties.name: March Fly Glen Rest Area
properties.description: Shady, dirt rest area on the W banks of the river. Toilets, picnic tables and BBQ facilities available. Located on Derby Gibb River Rd, 205km E of Derby. Dirt road, small vehicles only.

properties.name: Ten Mile Rocks Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway rest area. There is a bitumen pullover that leads to a large dirt area with tracks leading into the bush. There are rubbish bins, fire pits, picnic tables and a toilet. It is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. This site is very large and secluded. There are camping spots far from the road that minimize road noise. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Coongan Pool
properties.description: This spacious and open riverside campground with no amenities is located well off the highway. It is accessible in a dry weather only via a turn just opposite the Coongan River rest area.

properties.name: Gascoyne River (South Branch)
properties.description: Camping area on the banks of the river. No facilities, shade from trees. Located just W of Great Northern Hwy, 110km S of Kumarina. Max stay: 24hrs.

properties.name: Niagara Dam
