properties.description: Dirt rest area next to Niagara Creek. Toilets available, and it's a nice spot for swimming and bushwalking. 60km NE of Menzies via Goldfields Hwy and Kookynie Rd.

properties.name: Three Mile Pool
properties.description: This spacious campground with many shaded and sunny camping spots sits on the bank of Ashburton River, only 5km from the closest township. It has no amenities, however its scenic surroundings make it a very popular spot. It's great for fishing and launching a boat.

properties.name: The Forrestania Plots
properties.description: Roadside dirt rest area. No facilities, some shade. Signposted. Located on Hyden Norseman Rd, 65km E of Hyden via E Hyden Bin Rd. Dirt road.

properties.name: Temple Gorge Campground
properties.description: Simple camping area in Kennedy Range National Park. Bush toilet is the only facility, but a nice enough spot to stay if visiting the park. Located near the E entrance to the park.

properties.name: Caroline Pool
properties.description: Nice little camping spot. You can drive next to the pool, but than you have to drive on loose sand. You can also camp just 50m away from the pool on a dirt road where there are a few bins provided as well. You can swim in the pool and you're allowed to make a fire. The campground is surrounded by bush and trees. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Wolfe Creek Camp
properties.description:
This camp area is in the national park itself. It's build up with little areas along a road where you can camp, so you have got you your own little area surrounded by bush and trees. 

The areas are big enough for caravans, but I can imagine they would have struggles with the road that leads to the camp area. You have to drive down a 20 kilometre unsealed road with really bad corrugation. 

The toilet is located next in the normal car park next to the crater.

properties.name: Bruns Beach
properties.description:
Public parking lot with clean toilets & showers, near the beach.

Check for updates in freedom camping regulations at time of parking.

properties.name: Lake Magic Salt Baths
properties.description:
Immerse yourself in the natural wonder of the Lake Magic Salt Baths, a unique oasis blending relaxation and scenic beauty. 

Carved by ancient geological forces, the salt formations create a mesmerizing landscape. Dip into the rejuvenating salt baths, where you'll feel like you're floating on a cloud!

These salt baths promise a serene and soothing experience.

properties.name: Drummond's Reserve Badgingarra
properties.description: Must be self contained. Max. Stay 72 hours. Very weak 3G mobile signal. Not suitable for tents.

properties.name: Busselton Beach and Jetty
properties.description:
The Busselton Beaches extend the length of Geograph Bay from Dunsborough to the Wonnerup Estuary and the Busselton Marina in the east. It is a lovely beach with a stunning jetty.



* Cold showers behind cafe/takeaway shop

properties.name: McCanns Rock
properties.description: Nice campground with BBQ, table and toilet. Around 10 pitches. Perfect with 4WD, but also good with Van, RV etc. Accessible.

properties.name: Acclaim Kingsway Tourist Park
properties.description: Welcome to Kingsway Tourist Park - Perth

properties.name: Ngumban Cliff Lookout Rest Area
properties.description:
This lookout rest area offers scenic views, good amenities and a dump point. It is large and level and comprises of 3 sites. Easily accessible off the highway, via a long dirt road. Once you are up there, you can enjoy a spectacular panorama overlooking the bluff and plains. 

The Ngumban Cliff Lookout Rest Area has a 24 Hour Stop Over Limit. There is a public toilet, undercover picnic tables with plenty of level ground for you to park your caravan on. It's a good overnight stopping place, but make sure your early as its a popular location.

Camping in tents is allowed.

properties.name: Barred Creek
properties.description: There are little areas along the Barred Creek Rd where you can camp. You have got a lookout on the creek which is really nice. In some areas there are some big trees where you can get shade from. In this campground is nothing but a great lookout and relaxing atmosphere provided. You camp on a dirt/grassy ground.

properties.name: Gould lockup on the Meekatharra/Carnarvon road
properties.description: 1860s lockup on the banks of a  river. Look for the buildings. Lovely wide open area some shady trees.

properties.name: Fitzgerald Free Camping
properties.description:
Self contained RV site. Signs indicate rest spot off South Coast Hwy. Was an Old School site; there is an information board shelter regarding this. The old school hard court remains. There is some camping space next to this amongst the trees. Then there is a large area (the old school oval & cricket pitch) with ample room and ample shade from large trees around the edge.
The site can be accessed of Fitzgerald Rd & Mistletoe Way.
The birdlife is cheerful & at the right time some bush nearby for wildflowers. 
There is a nearby hall still in use. (The old school building is now located at 28 Dunn St Ravensthorpe as their CRCentre).

properties.name: Pemby Transit Park
properties.description:
Please note: You must have your own toilet facilities. 

No fires are allowed.

The site is a well-grassed, spacious farmland with no facilities. Located 10 km from Pemberton on Vasse Hwy or 10 km from Karri Valley Resort, it serves as a good base for exploring the area. The chocolate shop is open daily from 9 am to 4 pm. Continue past the shop to the caravan park on the left side of the drive.

The site is dog-friendly and accommodates RVs, camper trailers, caravans, and big rigs. Gas cooking is permitted with care, but no fires are allowed. Note that Telstra reception is limited.

properties.name: Alexander Bay Campground
properties.description:
Great place to unwind! 20 levelled sites, generously sized, fenced and private in the most part, surrounded by banksia bush. Brand new toilet block with three long drops; one standard, one ambulant, with a wash hand basin externally plus one disabled (RH) / parent room with wash hand basin inside. No potable water or showers. 

Toilets serviced weekly by the Esperance Shire, so be courteous and leave as you would like to find them. Lots of bird life. Vehicle and pedestrian beach access. No mobile signal (Telstra or Optus) so no eftpos. Fees can be paid at the shire office in Esperance.

properties.name: Lake Ewlyamartup Campground
properties.description: Fantastic overnight stay on the way back from Esperance. Has clean toilets and plenty of shade

properties.name: The Window Lookout
properties.description:
The Window Lookout walk is a picturesque 1-kilometre return walk in Kalbarri National Park, Western Australia. The walk begins at the Loop carpark and descends down to Nature's Window, a natural rock arch that frames a stunning view of the Murchison River.

The walk is mostly downhill and relatively easy, but there are some steps and uneven surfaces. It is important to wear sturdy shoes and bring plenty of water, especially in hot weather.

Along the way, there are several lookouts where you can stop and admire the views of the gorge and river. The trail also passes through some interesting rock formations, including The Loop, a large hole in the ground that was created by millions of years of erosion.

properties.name: Noble Falls Walk
properties.description: The Noble Falls Walk is a picturesque nature stroll that leads to the captivating Noble Falls. Located in Gidgegannup, this 1.6-kilometre trail winds through lush bushland along the Wooroloo Brook. Visitors can relish the soothing sounds of running water as they approach the falls, which cascade gracefully over granite rocks into a serene pool. With well-marked paths and opportunities for picnicking, it's a family-friendly adventure in the heart of nature, offering a refreshing escape from the urban bustle of Perth.

properties.name: Gibb River Station
properties.description:
Gibb River Station is the half-way point on the famous Gibb River Road. It is a working cattle station and location of the Ngallgunda Aboriginal Community.  

The Station has fuel, a shop and a grassy camping area with flush toilets and hot showers.

properties.name: Dave Evans Bicentennial Tree
properties.description: The Dave Evans Bicentennial Tree is a 75-metre tall karri tree located in Warren National Park in Western Australia. It was pegged in 1988 as part of Australia's bicentennial celebrations. The tree is open to the public for climbing and offers stunning views of the surrounding forest.

properties.name: Logue Brook Dam
properties.description: Camping is in designated areas water frontage or back under the trees it is entirely up to you. Hard surface. Boats and Jet Skis launch straight off the banks. Flush Toilets. Waste Bins provided. Lake is clean and fresh water great for all activities. Waterskiing is in designated area. Fees are collected by Parks and Wildlife Officials.

properties.name: Julimar Conservation Park
properties.description: Quiet, better than the other rest area at Great Northern Hwy. Level areas with plenty of firewood. Usually no other campers in the area. Must be self contained. Plenty of wildlife, Roos, Emu, Birds etc

properties.name: Katrine Viveash Reserve
properties.description: Free camping area, near the road and close to the river. Public toilet and rubbish bins availlable.

properties.name: Elbenjo
properties.description:
At ELBENJO, our goal is to offer an affordable, low-impact sanctuary for both humans and animals.

This paid campground provides toilets, showers, and a dump point. It is dog-friendly. The shower water temperature is ambient, meaning it warms up on sunny days and cools down when the weather is cooler.

The site is accessible to motorbikes, RVs, camper trailers, caravans, and big rigs, with tent camping also allowed.

Bookings are required for tours.

properties.name: Widgiemooltha Tavern & Roadhouse
properties.description: Hot showers, washing machine and dryers

properties.name: Station Stay at Mellenbye
properties.description:
Mellenbye Station is a working cattle station. 

The station stay is open during the wildflower season in July through till early October. Perfectly located between the towns of Morawa and Yalgoo, on the sealed Morawa Yalgoo road, the station is a great base from which to explore the area. 

Caravanners, campers and travellers can enjoy sitting by a campfire, watching the night sky and exploring the areas stunning display of seasonal wildflowers.

No dogs allowed

properties.name: Meanarra Hill Lookout
properties.description:
Meanarra Hill Lookout is a popular tourist destination in Kalbarri National Park, Western Australia. It offers stunning 360-degree views of the surrounding area, including the town of Kalbarri, the Murchison River, and the Indian Ocean.

The lookout is located on top of Meanarra Hill, which is 207 meters above sea level. The ascent to the lookout is a short and easy walk, making it suitable for all ages and fitness levels.

At the top of Meanarra Hill, there is a large viewing platform with a number of benches and picnic tables. There is also a series of interpretive signs that provide information about the local Aboriginal culture and the surrounding landscape.

properties.name: Sharp Point Lookout
properties.description: Sharp Point Lookout is a stunning lookout located in Torndirrup National Park, Albany, Western Australia. It offers breathtaking views of the rugged coastline, including the Gap and Natural Bridge, as well as the Albany Wind Farm. The lookout is accessible by a short walk from the car park. The walk is well-maintained and suitable for all ages and fitness levels. Once at the lookout, there is a platform with seating where you can relax and enjoy the views. This lookout tends to be less crowded, but there is a gravel road leading to it.

properties.name: Stony Hill Lookout
properties.description:
Stony Hill Lookout is a popular tourist destination in Albany. It is located in Torndirrup National Park, and offers stunning views of the coastline, including the Gap and Natural Bridge, as well as the Albany Wind Farm. The lookout is accessible by a short walk from the car park. The walk is well-maintained and suitable for all ages and fitness levels. Once at the lookout, there is a platform with seating where you can relax and enjoy the views. 

Here are some things you can do at Stony Hill Lookout: 

-Take in the stunning views of the coastline, wind farm, and surrounding area. 
-Watch the whales and dolphins during the winter months. 
-Spot kangaroos and other wildlife in the surrounding bushland. 
-Enjoy a picnic lunch with friends and family. 
-Take a walk along the coastline or through the national park.

properties.name: Humpback Hollows Black Point Campsite
properties.description:
One of the most spectacular sites at DEntrecasteaux is Black Point, a massive outcrop of hexagonal basalt columns formed 135 million years ago by volcanic lava flow.

Black Point owes its unique appearance to the lava which flowed from the Darling Scarp and slowly cooled at the ocean. In the cooling process the lava cracked and shrunk, and close packed, hexagonal columns were formed perpendicular to the surface. These Stepping Stones  as they are known as are now slowly being eroded away by the Southern Ocean. To reach the black basalt columns that give Black Point its name, a short walk is required along the beach. In calm weather, you may be able to get close enough to the basalt pillars to hear the organ-like music they create as the waves and wind echo through their gaps.

Black Point is approximately 2 hours from Augusta and access is by 4WD only. Be sure to reduce your tyre pressure to suit the conditions once you reach the sandy section. Black Point Road is closed in winter due to the tracks becoming inundated.

There are 20 camp sites at Humpback Hollow and 10 at Seal Cove with basic facilities. Popular with fishers, surfers and sightseers, the sites operate on a first come, first serve basis. Camping fees apply.

Black Point long been known to local surfers, who have been coming here for years and helped popularise the site. Fishing from the rocks is also popular but it can be dangerous. 

No dogs

properties.name: Olive Hill Farm RV Campground
properties.description: There are only 17 caravan bays secluded on our farm within our mature Olive grove. We cater for self contained travellers and are located only 10kms from Margaret River. Pet and family friendly.
properties.fees: $10.00 per adult per night, $3.00  per child per night (0 to 15yrs)

properties.name: Pender Bay Escape
properties.description:
A beautiful and secluded bush campsite overlooking Pender Bay. A private and unique oppertunity to visit one of Australias' most treasured destinations.
Located approximately 190km north of Broome, on Western Australia’s Dampier Peninsula.
Known for its very high marine biodiversity, Pender Bay offers incredible fishing , even from the beach, as well as idyllic beach swimming and nature walks.

properties.name: Doon Doon roadhouse
properties.description: Friendly owner. Great stop over and totally free. Hot showers in disabled toilets too. Great find. $5 deposit for shower key
properties.fees: $35 for power, $25 for an unpowered site

properties.name: Roebuck Plains Roadhouse
properties.description: Camping sites on the Highway outside of Broome at Roebuck Plains Roadhouse. Nice grassy and shady sites. Toilets, hot showers, laundry, swimming pool. Grab a bite at the Roadhouse or have a drink at the bar. Very friendly staff and good food. Road trains pull in at night and traffic from the highway can cause some noise at night.
properties.fees: $45 AUD per Site (2 pax) incl. Power.

properties.name: Nature's Window
properties.description:
Nature's Window in Kalbarri National Park is a breathtaking natural rock formation that frames stunning vistas of Western Australia's rugged landscape. 

Here are its highlights:

- Natural sandstone arch framing the Murchison River Gorge
- Panoramic views of the winding river and dramatic cliffs
- Ideal spot for photography and enjoying the unique outback scenery
- Accessible via a relatively short and scenic walking trail
- A popular destination for hikers and nature enthusiasts
- A must-visit attraction showcasing the raw beauty of the Australian wilderness.

properties.name: Gwalia Abandoned Mine & Ghost Town
properties.description:
Gwalia is a ghost town in Western Australia, located 80 kilometres north of Kalgoorlie. The town was founded in 1896 during the gold rush, and it quickly grew to a population of over 3,000 people. However, the mine closed in 1963, and the town was abandoned. 

Today, Gwalia is a popular tourist destination, and visitors can explore the ruins of the mine and the town.

properties.name: Kendenup Agricultural Grounds
properties.description:
20Km North of Mount Barker or 70Km North of Albany. Community campground at the show grounds, power, brand new showers and toilet block. 4 powered sites, no water on each site but at end of shower block. 

Wineries and Stirling Ranges nearby, fabulous wildflowers in season.

properties.name: Lake Cowan Lookout
properties.description:
Lake Cowan Lookout is a scenic lookout located on the Eyre Highway, approximately 10 kilometres from the town of Norseman in Western Australia. It offers stunning views of Lake Cowan, a large salt lake that is surrounded by red sand dunes and bushland.

The lookout is a popular stop for both tourists and locals alike. It is a great place to take a break from driving and enjoy the scenery. The lookout also has a picnic table and barbecue facilities, making it a great place to have a lunch or dinner break.

properties.name: Ten Mile Lagoon
properties.description:
Ten Mile Lagoon is a lagoon located in Esperance, Western Australia. It is about 16 kilometres (10 miles) west of Esperance and is accessible by a sealed road. 

The lagoon is about 10 kilometres long and 2 kilometres wide. It is a popular spot for swimming, sunbathing, and fishing. There is also a clothing optional section of the beach.

The lagoon is home to a variety of birdlife, including pelicans, cormorants, and herons. There are also a number of fish species in the lagoon, including whiting, bream, and salmon.

properties.name: Ravensthorpe Free Campground
properties.description: Perfect for self-contained vehicles only.  With Maximum 24 hours

properties.name: Red Bluff
properties.description:
The dramatic coastal cliffs of Kalbarri's Red Bluff offer amazing views over the ocean - perfect for whale watching. 

Towering 100 metres over the ocean below, Red Bluff is the ideal spot to see humpback whales which migrate along the Kalbarri coastline.

properties.name: Pot Alley
properties.description:
Pot Alley is a picturesque ocean gorge in Kalbarri National Park, boasting spectacular ocean scenery amidst the expansive rugged gorges. 

Enjoy a swim at the lovely sheltered swimming beach and be sure to take your camera to capture the countless photo opportunities.

properties.name: Marlston Hill Lookout Tower
properties.description: Marlston Hill Lookout Tower is a 27-meter-high tower located in Bunbury, Western Australia. It was built in 1988 to commemorate Western Australia's bicentennial and offers panoramic views of the city, the harbor, and the coast. The tower is accessed by a staircase and is open to the public free of charge. It is a popular tourist destination and a great place to get a bird's-eye view of Bunbury and its surroundings.

properties.name: Lake Kununurra
properties.description: Lake Kununurra was formed after the completion of the Diversion Dam. It harbours a large variety of flora and fauna, contains wetland areas and provides a water frontage to the town, many small farms and tourist developments. It is also used extensively for sailing, rowing and skiing, supports several tour boat operations and is the landing field for float planes

properties.name: Kepwari Trails Wetland Wonderland
properties.description:
Kepwari Trails Wetland Wonderland is a 100-hectare (250-acre) wetland located in Invercargill. It is a popular spot for birdwatching, walking, and cycling.

The wetland is home to a variety of native New Zealand birds, including herons, ducks, and waders. There are also several walking and cycling trails that wind through the wetland, offering stunning views of the surrounding countryside.

The best time to visit Kepwari Trails Wetland Wonderland is during the spring and summer months, when the weather is mild and the birds are more active.

properties.name: Kelly's Knob Lookout
properties.description: Enjoy stunning panoramic views of Kununurra, the Ord River irrigation area, and nearby attractions from Kelly's Knob Lookout. Located just 1km from town, the lookout is easily accessible by car or on foot. Visit for sunrise or sunset for the most spectacular views.

properties.name: Five Rivers Lookout
properties.description:
See where five mighty Kimberley rivers meet and flow into the ocean at Five Rivers Lookout in Wyndham. Enjoy spectacular views of the Ord, Forest, King, Durack, and Pentecost Rivers, the Cambridge Gulf, and surrounding mangrove swamps, mudflats, and hills.

The lookout is located on the Bastion Range, a short drive from the town center. It is a popular spot for tourists and locals alike, offering stunning views of the Kimberley region.

properties.name: Diamond Tree Lookout Manjimup
properties.description:
The Diamond Tree Lookout is a 49m Karri tree located in the Pemberton State Forest, Western Australia. It was built in 1941 as a fire lookout tower and operated until 1974. The tree was chosen for its central location and height, which provides panoramic views of the surrounding forest and coastline.

The lookout tower is a popular tourist destination, offering visitors the opportunity to climb to the top of the tree and experience the breathtaking views. The climb is challenging but rewarding, and the views from the top are simply stunning.

Diamond Tree Lookout Manjimup provides a unique opportunity to gain a spectacular birds eye view across the treetops of the Karri forest near Manjimup. Not designed for the faint hearted, the gruelling 51-metre climb to the top of the world.

properties.name: Convoy Walk and Lookout
properties.description: Convoy Walk and Lookout on Mount Adelaide in Albany, is a must-visit for anyone interested in Australian history and culture. The walk and lookout commemorate the departure of Australian troops from Albany during World War I and World War II. The walk starts at the Longing, Memory, Sight artwork, which is a fragment of a letter sent by a soldier to his loved one. The walk then takes you through a series of 21 interpretive markers, each of which tells the story of a different ship in the first and second convoys. The lookout at the end of the walk offers stunning views of King George Sound, where the troops gathered on ships before departing for war. There is also a shelter at the lookout with interpretive material about the convoys. The walk is suitable for all ages and fitness levels. It is approximately 1.5 kilometres long and takes around 30 minutes to complete. The lookout is accessible by wheelchair.

properties.name: Cable Beach
properties.description: Broome's Cable Beach is justifiably world famous for its 22 kilometres of sun-kissed white sand, turquoise water and spectacular Indian Ocean sunsets. But what really gives it a top spot on the must-do list is the experience of taking in all its tropical splendour from the seat of a camel train.

properties.name: Bindoola Falls
properties.description: Bindoola Falls, located in the heart of the Australian Outback, is a breathtaking natural wonder that is a must-see destination for any adventurer or nature lover. This hidden gem is tucked away in the Bindoola National Park, which is home to an incredible array of wildlife and plant species.

properties.name: Gorge Rock
properties.description: Large area suit all size vans and motor homes. Self contained vehicles only. Rock to climb with small dam great views of the local area large trees and  walking tracks. Ideal over night stop small bbq area . No bins  please take your rubbish with you and leave it tidy.

properties.name: Maitland River Rest Area
properties.description: There is a nice 24 hour stopping possibility next to the river. The place is not bad, there's a little hill you can climb to have a nice view over the surrounding plains or you can relax on the river shore. Good for a night.

properties.name: Cue Tourist Park
properties.description:
The Cue Tourist Park is located adjacent to the RV Parking area at the northern end of the Great Northern Highway in Cue and just a short stroll from the town centre.  

It provides an ideal base for both tourists and prospectors alike wanting to spend time in this historic area of Western Australia.

properties.name: Four Mile Campground
properties.description:
Fitzgerald River National Park is one of Australia's largest national parks and is home to nearly 20 per cent of Western Australia's flora species. 
The Park is an ideal destination for bush walking and fishing, along with swimming, kayaking, surfing and snorkelling at Four Mile and Hamersley Beaches.
Campsites 1 - 3 are for larger groups or families,
Campsites 4 - 12 cater for small vehicle and a small tent,
Campsites 13 - 15 are for camper-vans and camper trailers. 
Four mile beach is 400m return via path.
No pets allowed, bbq facilities and picnic tables, bush toilets (drop toilets)
properties.fees:
Prices per night
$11 per adult
$7 for concession card holder
$6 per child (6-15years old)

properties.name: West Peawah River Rest Area
properties.description: This riverside overnight rest area is located just off the highway and it has good amenities and some shade, too. Suitable for big rigs with maximum stay of 24hrs.

properties.name: Normans Beach Camping Area
properties.description: Remote and very small beach campground located some 16km off the highway and accessible via a dirt track (6km). There are toilet facilities and 72hrs limit applies. Fantastic fishing spot used by commercial fishermen between Feb and Apr (best avoided durng that time). Not suitable for caravans.

properties.name: Moons Crossing
properties.description: This peaceful campground is located in a forest, by the Warren River. It is very scenic and offers good fishing, however there are no facilities. Recommended access with 4WD, some 100m off the main road via a dirt track. Popular destination for 4WD enthusiasts, as there are some creeks to be crossed in this area.

properties.name: Marshall Rock Reserve
properties.description: Beautiful rest area with no facilities, except for rubbish bins and drinking water, located well of Marshall Rock Rd, approx. 1km from Lake Mcdermott. It offers scenic views, diversity of spring wildflowers, a few walking tracks and plenty of shade.

properties.name: Marracoonda Rest Area
properties.description: Very large roadside drive-through rest area located just off the highway. For overnight stays, you can drive further into the land and park between some trees for extra privacy and minimized noise levels. There are no facilities, other than a rubbish bin.

properties.name: Goldwire Rest Area
properties.description: Large overnight rest area with good facilities, located approximately 300m off the highway. The area is spacious (with enough space to turn around) and quite shaded. There is also a dump point.

properties.name: Glen Herring Gorge - Creek
properties.description: This simple campsite with no facilities is scenically located by a gorge. Among the activities that you can enjoy here are swimming and various 4WD and walking trails. This site is remote and spacious, providing a good wilderness experience for those who need a nature fix. Accessible by 4x4 vehicles only.

properties.name: Morapoi Station
properties.description:
For travellers looking to learn a bit more about the land, Morapoi Station offers an insight into the pastoral history of the North Eastern Goldfields and the vibrant traditions and living culture of the Wangkatha people, 40000 years strong. Morapoi offers it all: from foraging for bushtucker to fossicking for gold.

Under two-hours drive north of Kalgoorlie, Morapoi station was once a fully operational sheep station but now offers an array of options for those exploring the area: from backpackers accommodation and caravan hook-ups to fully-catered ensuite rooms. 

A family-friendly base to explore the goldfields, Morapoi is the place to go if you’re after a tranquil location with proximity to all the best activities the north east has to offer: learn more about country with a traditional Wangkatha tour of ancient Indigenous sites, check out the awe-inducing beauty of the western desert; or try your luck searching for a bit of the shiny stuff.

properties.name: Wrights Bridge
properties.description: Wrights Bridge is a scenic, riverside campsite with bush camping amenities. Long-drop toilets, picnic tables and fire pits are the facilities available to campers. Activities in the area include swimming, fishing, and canoeing in the Blackwood River by the campsite. Payment is made by on-site self- registration.

properties.name: Hoffman Mill
properties.description: Hoffman Mill allows camping from November 1- Easter on a first-come-first-serve basis. Toilets, picnic tables and fireplaces are provided. Bring your own firewood, and check if there is a fire ban.

properties.name: Miners Camp
properties.description: The Miners Camp within Coalseam Conservation Park is on the banks of the Irwin River. Basic facilities are provided including toilets and BBQ facilities. Pets are not allowed.
properties.fees: AUD $7.50 Adult; $2.20 Children between the ages of 2-16

properties.name: Mason Bay
properties.description: Mason Bay is and easily accessed site, run by the Shire of Ravensthorpe with a boat ramp, fishing, swimming and whale watching. Facilities are basic and include toilets. Call for booking details. Price is $15/ night/ site

properties.name: Nyabing Caravan Park
properties.description:
Are you looking for somewhere quiet, peaceful and relaxing to stay on your travels? 

This pet friendly Caravan Parking will provide you with power, water, a sheltered area and fantastic laundry and shower facilities. 

Feel free to walk around this safe and friendly town and take in the beautiful surroundings.

FACILITIES:
 *BBQ
 *Powered & Unpowered Sites
 * Shower/Toilets
 *Coin Operated Laundry Facilities
 * Semi-Enclosed Shed for Additional Protection (Caravans)
 *Bowling Green situated next door
 *Self-Drive Tour Map & Brochures (Available from Shire Office)
 *Dump Point (image below)

properties.name: Canebrake Pool
properties.description: Canebrake Pool is located within the forest, near the upper reached of the Margaret River. There are seven designated sites with a long-drop toilet, and picnic areas. Sites are available on a first-come-first-serve basis.

properties.name: Wooramel River Retreat
properties.description:
Join our happy campers along the riverbank and experience the wonders of Wooramel!

A unique station campground nestled under the majestic gum trees on the banks of the Wooramel River.

properties.name: Carrabin Roadhouse Motel & Caravan Park
properties.description:
Carrabin Roadhouse Motel & Caravan Park provides ten van sites for caravans and long rigs. 

There are also motel rooms available. Facilities include toilets, showers, laundry area, drinking water and bins. 

There is a service station and restaurant available. 

Pets are welcome.

properties.name: Menzies shire council
properties.description: Menzies council provides this caravan park camp kitchen(fully enclosed) laundromat,full amenities. Book a the information centre on the corner

properties.name: Ilkurlka Roadhouse
properties.description:
Ilkurlka Roadhouse camping area provides sites for vehicle based camping and camper trailers. Facilities include hot showers, wood fireplace, picnic tables and shelter. 

Camping fees can be paid at the Roadhouse.

properties.name: Coorow Caravan Park
properties.description:
Welcome to Corowa Caravan Park.

Our Park is walking distance to the main street, 1.5km from Corowa Post Office.

Nestled on twelve acres amongst shady trees, the caravan park is on the banks of the mighty Murray River.

The park with it's family friendly atmosphere, has a variety of cabins, and a large range of powered and unpowered sites.

We have large shady Powered sites and a range of Unpowered sites along the banks of the Murray River.

Guests have access to the camp kitchen which provides a fridge, bbq, sink (hot water),stove, microwave, toaster, kettle and large undercover area.

Our private boat ramp enables boating and fishing off the back of the park. 

With Australia's mightiest waterway, the Murray at your doorstep, Corowa’s leisure choices - camping, bushwalking, swimming, fishing, canoeing and waterskiing – are seemingly endless.

Unfortunately. we are not a pet friendly park.

properties.name: Trayning Caravan Park
properties.description:
We are constantly working to offer good amenities for those wanting to camp or enjoy the luxury of their own caravan at the Trayning Caravan Park.

With drive through powered sites, (each with their own artificial turf), clean new ablutions, campers kitchen, laundry, BBQ’s, grassed area, great close by recreation facilities and more. This quaint little spot really is the peace and quiet you have been looking for.

Situated North on the Bencubbin/ Kellerberrin Road and close to town the park is in walking distance to everything.

- Our caravan park is dog friendly. (Dogs must be on a lead and you must clean up after them).
- Free Wi-Fi (for password please contact the Shire of Trayning Administration Office).
- Town water, powered sites, laundry and campers' kitchen, with free BBQ's.
- Communal fire pit (Seasonal). Check fire season with the Shire - Administration Office.
- Dump Point access.
- Free washing machine

properties.name: Big Brook Arboretum
properties.description: Big Brook Arboretum is suitable for tents, camper trailers, caravans and campervans. Facilities include toilets, BBQ and picnic tables. You will need to bring your own firewood and water. Advanced bookings are not available.

properties.name: Mangowine Homestead
properties.description: Mangowine Homestead provides a rest area and caravan park. There are powered and unpowered sites. Toilet facilities are available. There is an onsite caretaker and walking trails in the area. There is a maximum stay of 48 hours.
properties.fees: AUD $5 per vehicel unpowered. $7 per vehicle powered.

properties.name: Drysdale River Station
properties.description:
No bookings are taken, or are required for any camping.

We have a very large camp ground we won’t run out of space, we never turn people away.

We only have 8 power sites, very sorry bookings are no longer taken because a huge number of people booked and constantly failed to show up or to even bother to cancel their bookings.

We can only suggest that an earlier arrival may get you a power site.

Our camp area offers hot showers and toilets in a great ablution block. There is also a coin operated laundry and plenty of clothes lines. The general camping area is large, flat and spacious and the Bar and the Restaurant are just a short stroll away.

Payment for camping can be made at the station shop, 8am to 5pm, daily.
For late arrivals ( preferably not)  please pay at the Bar / Reception, between 5pm and 7.30pm.

Check in and registration is essential for all camping, prior to setting up any camp.

During the winter it gets dark quite early here, in mid dry season June / July, by 5.30pm. It is highly recommended that you be off these unfenced roads before dark

NOTE: MINERS POOL, on the Drysdale River - NO toilets, NO camping. Please request to visit for no charge day use ONLY

properties.name: New Norcia Camping Area
properties.description: New Norcia provides five overnight stopes for caravans and motor homes. Facilities include basic showers (fee applies), coin operated laundry, toilets. There is an area for self-contained caravans. Bookings can be made at the Roadhouse. Powered sites cannot be pre booked.

properties.name: Halfway Mill Roadhouse Caravan Facility
properties.description:
This was the first roadhouse built along the Brand Highway. It was originally named The Big Mill Roadhouse and Half Way Mill Roadhouse due to a large windmill that once stood on the site, which has since been removed. The roadhouse is roughly halfway between Geraldton and Perth, hence the name.

The Halfway Mill Roadhouse and caravan park provide fuel, meals, and powered sites for travellers.

properties.name: Grand Kookynie Hotel
properties.description:
The Grand Hotel is a Historic Goldfields Hotel situated 200 kms north of Kalgoorlie in the old townsite of Kookynie. It was Built in 1902 and is a good example of the architecture of the period. 

The Hotel is a pleasant blend of old world charm and tradition and hidden modern conveniences.
Facilities include accommodation, tent and caravan sites, pool table, beer garden. Open 7 days.

State Winner (WA) 2009 Hotel & Motel Accommodation

Very good food available at the hotel.

properties.name: CMCA Flax Mill Caravan Park Boyup Brook Wa
properties.description: The caravan park includes ensuite van sites, powered sites, unpowered river sites for tents/camper trailers, unpowered sites for caravans and RVs, and self-contained RV sites, with discounts for CMCA members across all styles of accommodation. Note, river camping sites are for tents and camper trailers ONLY

properties.name: Wagin Caravan Park
properties.description:
The Caravan Park is located in Scadden Street off Arthur Road Wagin to the west of the town, with lots of shaded camping spots, a very clean ablution block, a gas BBQ and a very new Camp Kitchen. 

To make a booking at the Caravan Park please contact our Caravan Park.

Please note: The Caravan Park Caretaker only accepts cash payments, if you require eftpos facilities you can pay at the Shire Office during business hours Monday to Friday 9 am - 4.30 pm.

There is also an RV area at the Showgrounds in Ballagin Street Wagin.

properties.name: Pingrup Caravan Park
properties.description: Pingrup Caravan Park offers sites for vehicle based camping, camper trailers and caravans. Facilities include toilets, water, hot showers, BBQ and picnic tables. There is a caretaker on site.

properties.name: Bindoon Oval
properties.description: Bindoon Oval Camping area is located along the Great Northern highway and provides overnight camping. The site is only open  from April to September and is suitable for tents, caravans and large rigs. Facilities include toilets, showers, children's playground, and drinking water.

properties.name: Narrogin Caravan Park
Lake Mason Homestead
properties.description:
Once a cattle station, Lake Mason is a 149,557ha reserve situated 50km north of Sandstone.

The landscape has a gently undulating terrain with an extensive salt lake system in the centre. There are several breakaways and low hills to the west and north. 

The area around Lake Mason Homestead offers opportunities for bird watching, bushwalking and camping. Simple facilities and barbecues have been provided and although untreated water is provided by a bore it is always advisable to bring your own drinking water.

No park entry fee / No fees for camping.

Not Bookable

properties.name: Crossing Pool Campground
properties.description:
Crossing Pool camping area is situated on the banks of the Fortescue River. 

It offers a range of facilities including toilets, picnic tables, and BBQs. The camp site is suitable for vehicle based camping and camper trailers. 

This is a great sopt for swimming, canoeing and fishing at the Deep Reach Pool and Crossing Pool. You will need to supply your own water. 

There is a park ranger on site.

properties.name: Windjana Gorge Campground
properties.description:
Windjana Gorge campground is situated near the gorge. The shaddy campsites are suitable for vehicle based camping, caravans and camper trailers. 

Facilities include toilets, picnic tables, wood fireplace, public phones and drinking water. In the area you can enjoy bushwalking. There is a ranger on site. Firewood will need to be collected outside of park and brought in not from park itself

properties.name: Sues Bridge Campground
properties.description:
Sues Bridge campground features an undercover camp kitchen, toilets, picnic tables, dishwashing sinks, and a firepit. 

There 25 camp sites available. 9 are suitable for camper trailers and caravans. The other 16 are for tents and regular size campervans.  Generators are not allowed. 

In the area you can enjoy swimming and launching canoes and kayaks in the Blackwood river. Bookings cannot be made.

properties.name: Grass Tree Hollow Campground
properties.description: 30 minutes from Pemberton, Grass Tree Hollow campsite is situated on the edge of Carey Brook. There are 7 shady, baisc campsites for vehicle based camping. Campers own BBQs, stoves and heaters may be used unless a fire ban has been declared. You will need to bring your own firewood. Visitors enjoy fishing, birdwatching, or the 2.5km walking trail through the forest.

properties.name: Honeymoon Pool - Stones Brook Campground
properties.description:
Honeymoon Pool-Stones Brook campground has 20 camp sitves suitable for tents only. Located in the Wellington National Park, the Collie River offers a great place for swiming. 

Facilities include camp kitchen, BBQ, pcinic tables and benches. Campfires are not allowed.

properties.name: Boranup Campground
properties.description:
Boranup is a small, shady campground contained on the edge of the Boranup karri forest.

Bookings are essential for one of seven campsites each with a compacted earth surface (some sloping) that vary significantly due to the forest setting.

All campsites have a picnic table, benches and a fire ring and are unpowered.

There are no-flush pit toilets.

Campfires when conditions permit and in the provided fire rings only. Usual permitted season: April - November. Check current campfire conditions. Bring your own firewood.

Pets are not permitted.

Generator use is not permitted.

Do not empty waste from portable toilets into campground toilets. Carry waste out of the park for disposal in an authorised dump point.

properties.name: Bungarra Campground
properties.description:
Located in Cape Range National Park, Bungarra Camp is only 500 metres from the beach and Ningaloo Marine Park via a walking track where recreational fishing is permitted within the allocated zone.

Campers are advised that boat fishing is not permitted.

The nearby Ningaloo Marine Park also offers first-class diving and surfing, with other highlights including the chance to see whalesharks, marine turtles and humpback whales.

Cape Range National Park also offers walking trails and scenic lookouts.  

Bungarra Camp itself features five camp sites suitable for tents, large caravans or camper trailers or large campervans. None of the sites has shade.

Campers are advised that campfires and generators are not permitted at any time and no fresh water is available. 

Bookings cannot be made, and available sites are allocated at the park entry station. Pay on arrival at the park.

Peak season is April (or from Good Friday in years when Easter falls in March) to October, and there can be long queues, particularly during public and school holidays.

November to March is cyclone season: check alerts for notification of parks closures.

Park entry fees apply at Cape Range National Park.

properties.name: Osprey Bay Campground
properties.description:
Osprey Bay campground is situated along a small sandy beach with a rock-shelf shoreline. There are 44 camp sites suitable for large campervans and trailers. Tents are permitted but the surface is compacted gravel. Activities available include swimming, snorkelling, canoeing and kayaking. 

There is no drinking water or power supply. There are two seperate camp site areas. Generators are permitted in only one area. Bookings are required from April to October.

properties.name: Fernhook Falls Campground
properties.description: Fernhook Falls Campground consists of 8 campsites and 2 huts. Facilities include picnic tables, BBQ facilities and toilets and there is an information centre. Activities include walking, canoeing and kayaking. Campers own liquid or gas fuel BBQs, stoves and heaters are permitted.

properties.name: Walardi Campground
properties.description:
Walardi is a medium-size campground. It is the closest campground to the Domes and Cathedral Gorge.

Booking
Bookings are essential and can be made up to 180 days (approximately six months) before arrival through Park Stay WA. Campsites can only be booked for the tourist season (May to September). For other periods, booking will be available when the seasonal opening and closing of the park is confirmed. 

Specific campsites cannot be reserved. Select from campsites vacant on arrival at the campground.

If you are an outdoor education provider, licensed commercial tour operator or are organising an event (friends, family and other social groups camping together does not constitute an event), contact Purnululu Visitor Centre to discuss your requirements.

Mobile phone and internet - there is INTERMITTENT OPTUS coverage only in Purnululu National Park and free wifi available at the visitor centre. 

Campsites: Thirty-seven campsites.

All campsites are unpowered.

Check campsite details carefully when booking.

Facilities:
- No-flush pit toilets.
- Picnic tables and benches.

Campground Rules:
- No campfires at any time.
- Dogs are not permitted.
- Generator use is not permitted.
- Do not empty your portable toilet waste into campground toilets. Carry waste out of the park for disposal in an authorised dump point.
- Carry all waste out of the park. No bins provided. Leave no trace.
- Drones are not permitted.

Fees: A per person camping fee and a per vehicle park entry fee apply.

Camping fee must be paid by Mastercard or VISA when booking.

Vehicle entry fee (or park entry fee) may be paid when booking online on arrival at Purnululu National Park. Payment is not required for trailers including camper trailers and caravans.

properties.name: Homestead Campground
properties.description:
Homestead Camp is located in the stunning Avon Valley National Park.

Close to jarrah, marri and powderbark forest, the valleys themselves are forested with wandoo, making for peaceful bushwalks through the area.

It's also a great place to see a wide variety of wildflowers and bird life in the spring.

The campground itself is accessible only by four wheel drive and features tent sites, picnic tables, fire rings, toilets and water (untreated).

It is suitable for tents and small caravans or camper trailers only.

Campfires are usually permitted between 1 April and 30 November but fire restrictions may be imposed at any time and without notice. Bring your own firewood.

Untreated water is available. Bring your own drinking water. Camping fees apply.

properties.name: Stargazers Campground
properties.description:
Stargazers Campground is a small public campground. Facilities include picnic tables, toilets and gas BBQs. 

The area is surrounded by eucalyptus woodland. Activities include Bushwalking. 

There is a pay station installed at the entrance of the Campground.

properties.name: Drummonds Campground
properties.description: Drummonds Campground features tent sites, picnic tables, fire rings and is suitable to SMALL campervans or camper trailers only. Site facilities include picnic tables and a toilet. Activities include bushwalking. Campfires only permitted in the fire rings. Campers own liquid or gas fuel BBQ's, stoves and heaters can be used.
properties.fees: AUD$7.50 per Adult AUD$2.20 per Child

properties.name: Tulki Beach Campground
properties.description:
There are 11 campsites at Tulki and bookings are required during peak season ( April to October) Campsites are suitable to tents, camper trailers, caravans or motorhomes. 

There is a toilet on site. 

Suitable activities include swimming, snorkelling, canoeing and kayaking.

properties.name: Eadine Springs Rest Area
properties.description: Quiet rest area separated from a highway by a wall of trees, which reduces the noise and provides shelter. It is not suitable for big rigs due to limited space. There are no facilities, except for rubbish bins and picnic tables.

properties.name: Cobbler Pool
properties.description:
The camping area is closed during summer months, due to the extreme risk this creates for the Shire and the Community.

This is a large riverside camp ground with no amenities, located within an easy reach from the main road and close by the Cobblers Pool. Follow the dirt track and choose the spot that best suits your needs.

properties.name: Three Rivers Rest Area Southern Branch
properties.description: This is a typical Main Roads Western Australia 24 hour stopping area 148 km NW of Meekatharra and 276 km S of Newman. There is a large bitumen pullover suitable for trucks and larger vehicles. Adjacent is a dirt parking areas with a toilet, dump station, covered picnic area, and rubbish bins. There is some shade. It is right on the road so it is not secluded and it is noisy. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Lake Nallan Nature Reserve Camping
properties.description: This is a camping spot 20 km N of Cue or 96 km SW of Meekatharra. It is a scenic lakeside camping area at Lake Nallan. Follow the dirt turnoff for approximately 200 meters and reach the lakeside. Camp anywhere around the lake. This is a secluded and quiet camp area but some road noise is heard. There are rubbish bins and shade but no other facilities. All types of vehicles can access this area. No Fires. Maximum Stay: 48 hours.

properties.name: Caiguna Blowhole Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area at the Caiguna blowhole. There is a short dirt pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with little trees, shade, or bush. There are rubbish bins and some information about the blowhole, but no other facilities. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: The Yardie Creek Top Trail
properties.description:
The Yardie Creek Top Trail is located in the spectacular Yardie Creek Gorge, one-hour's drive from Exmouth. The ancient gorge has deep blue water, red limestone cliff faces and a wonderful array of birds and wildlife including the rare black-footed wallaby and red kangaroos. From the top, the views into the creek and out to the Ningaloo Reed are purely spectacular.

The 1.5 kilometre walk trail slowly climbs up the red rock cliffs over a flat path which then becomes harder as it narrows and requires navigation of rocks and small creek line gullies. The trail follows the gorge, becoming more difficult as you ascend the range, however, the views into the gorge are well worth the effort. From the top of the gorge walls, look out for the wide variety of birds and yellow-footed rock wallabies that inhabit the rock walls.

All activities start at the Yardie Creek car park where there are toilets and picnic areas.

Yardie Creek Gorge, located in Cape Range National Park, Western Australia, is a stunning geological formation characterized by sheer red limestone cliffs that rise majestically along the tranquil waterway. Visitors can enjoy scenic boat tours within the gorge, spot diverse birdlife, and explore hiking trails offering panoramic vistas. The gorge is also home to rock wallabies and provides picnicking facilities. Yardie Creek Gorge is a captivating destination within Cape Range National Park, offering a unique blend of natural beauty and outdoor experiences.

properties.name: Hamelin Pool Marine Nature Reserve
properties.description:
Hamelin Pool Marine Nature Reserve is a protected marine nature reserve located in the UNESCO World Heritage listed Shark Bay in the Gascoyne region of Western Australia. Hamelin Pool Marine Nature Reserve is also home to a variety of other marine life, including fish, turtles, and dolphins. The reserve is a popular destination for boating, swimming, snorkeling, and fishing. 

There is a small caravan park and general store nearby.

properties.name: Cliff Head North Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a parking area 51 km N of Leeman or 6 km S of Brand Hwy jcn on Indian Ocean Dr. It is a large gravel area with beachside camping. There is a long drop toilet and rubbish bins but no other facilities. It is a large area that can accommodate 15-20 vehicles comfortably. There is no shade. It is quiet and peaceful but some road noise is heard from the highway. Maximum stay: 72 Hours now it's $20 a day

properties.name: Greens Island Campground
properties.description:
Greens Island is a spacious campground located in a bend on the Donnelly River. The layout is a large central grassy clearing surrounded by 21 campsites under shady trees. 

The campsites have picnic benches, fire rings, non-compacted soft ground suitable for tents and your dog, controlled and on a leash, is welcome to camp too. 

There is a toilet, untreated water, firewood and fire rings. The area is spacious, there are 28 camp sites. Look for a white tyre at the turnoff.

properties.name: Malcolm Dam
properties.description: This scenic and open campground is located 3km off the main road via a dirt track. The campsites are scattered around the dam and there are no amenities, other than picnic tables and some rubbish bins. There is enough space for big rigs and the site is easily accessible by all vehicles.

properties.name: Bush Bay Camp Spot
properties.description: Camp Spot 101 km N of Wooramel Roadhouse or 43 km S of Carnarvon. Turn W 91 km N of Wooramel Roadhouse or 33 km S of Carnarvon. 6 km N of New Beach. 10 km dirt road. In wet weather, 4WD required. There are no facilities here. The road is corrugated. Campsites near the shore are low-lying and may be below high tide. This is a quiet and secluded site, but busy with many long term campers. There is no shade.

properties.name: Queerarrup Lake Camping
properties.description: This is a camping ground 28 km NW of Woodanilling. Turn N off Robinson Rd 18 km W of Woodanilling. Follow signs to the lake carpark. The gravel carpark is not very large - suitable for 6-8 small vehicles, but there are other places to park large vehicles. This area has a barbecue, rainwater tank, picnic area, drop toilet, rubbish bins, recycling bin, and a boat ramp. No fires. It is secluded, quiet, and scenic. The road to the area is dirt and corrugated in parts. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Boddington RV Stop
properties.description: This is a parking area at Boddington for self contained vehicles only. It is a large grassy area next to the war memorial. There are picnic tables, potable water, and a rubbish bin but no other facilities. There are public toilets 200m down the walking track. It is a shady site next to the river. All types of vehicles can access this area. Maximum stay:  48 Hours

properties.name: Louis's Lookout Rest Area
properties.description:
This is a rest area 4 km North of Borden at Great Southern Highway Junction. It is a lookout over the fields and Stirling Range. 

The road is sealed and right off the highway and leads to a large area with picnic tables and rubbish bins. There is a plaque showing the Stirling Range and some historical information. 

The area, being open and not very sheltered, will have some road noise. There is little shade. All vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Hann River
properties.description: Basic camping area next to the river. No facilities but some shade provided by trees. Located on Gibb River Rd, 100km NE of King Leopold Ranges.

properties.name: Lake Poorrarecup Camp Area
properties.description:
This is a camping ground 42 km SW of Cranbrook. Turn S off Cranbrook-Frankland Rd 33 km W of Cranbrook or 13 km E of Frankland onto Poorrarecup Rd. There is a 9 km dirt road in good condition. 

The camping area is large and consists of a shady, lakeside parking area. It is grass and dirt but close to the lake it is sandy. There are toilets, a playground, picnic area, covered shelter, fire pits and rubbish bins. No dogs. No fires during fire danger season. This is a secluded and quiet peaceful site. 

All types of vehicles can access this area - tall vehicles be careful for low hanging trees in camp area.

properties.name: Russ Creek
properties.description: Shady rest area on the banks of the creek. No facilities available here. Located off Gibb River Rd, 270km W of Kununurra.

properties.name: Revelly Bridge Picnic Area
properties.description: This is a picnic area 9 km NE of Nannup or 31 km SW of Balingup, on Balingup-Nannup Rd. Cross the bridge over to the forested pine area. There are no facilities and just signage prohibiting campfires (October to May). There is plenty of space for a large number of vehicles. Any type of vehicle can access this area. There is shade.

properties.name: Baxter Rest Area
properties.description: This is an official designated 24 hour stopping bush camp rest area on the Eyre Highway. There is a long bitumen pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and bush. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables, and a toilet. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Martup Pool Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a rest area 32 km N of Kojonup or 24 km S of Arthur River. There is a large open dirt area off the highway that is suitable for all types of vehicles. It is noisy and there is shade. There are picnic tables and rubbish bins. Smaller vehicles can take the dirt tracks in the back to camp near the river. There are some low hanging trees on these tracks and no way to turn around large vehicles. The bush camp sites are more secluded than the rest area.

properties.name: Woodlands
properties.description: Simple dirt rest area on Mort Harslett Dr. Picnic tables and lots of shade available. Located 50km W of Norseman. Dirt road.

properties.name: New Beach Camp Area
properties.description:
The New Beach/ Bush Bay campground is located 40km south of Carnarvon is a mangrove paradise, and perfect for drone lovers who are seeking some impressive aerial shots of the Shark Bay World Heritage Area. 

New Beach/ Bush Bay is a pet-friendly campground, however, we recommend keeping your pets on a lead at all times due to 1080 baits in the region. Bush Bay is an extremely popular fishing beach, and a great spot to launch a tinnie. 

There are heaps of spots to get your boat close to the water at Bush Bay, though pick your location carefully, as the beaches are soft, launching at a high tide is much easier too. You can catch Whiting and Flat Heads just off the beach, though if you launch a tinnie, you have the opportunity to catch some larger fish and do some squidding.

properties.name: Lake Ballard
properties.description: Free camping area on the S bank of the lake. Compost toilets and picnic table available. Located 55km E of Menzies along dirt road. Road closes when raining, check at Menzies before travelling.

properties.name: Woorlba Homestead Rest Area
properties.description: This is an official designated 24 hour stopping bush camp rest area on the Eyre Highway. There is a long bitumen pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and bush. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables, an emergency phone, and a toilet. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Giles Breakaway Rest Area
properties.description: This scenic camping area is located off the main road and it's accessible via a dirt track best suited for a 4WD. There are no amenities, however, it provides spectacular views of the breakaway.

properties.name: Minnivale Campsite
properties.description: This is a grassed parking area located off the main road, in a small town with no shops. There are facilities limited to one toilet, cold shower and picnic tables. There is also a dump point and an old tennis court which is no longer used. The area is quiet and donations are welcome.

properties.name: Oak Park & Gnamma Holes
properties.description: Large picnic and camping area in the park. Drop toilet, sheltered picnic table and BBQ facilities available, some shade from trees. Located on Bothering East Road, 16km SW of Konnongorring via Wongan Rd.

properties.name: Eulin Crossing Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a camping area 20 km SW of Moodiarrup or 49 km NE of Boyup Brook. Turn SE 16 km from Moodiarrup or 45 km from Boyup Brook onto Kulikup N Rd for 4.3 km. Turn W into Eulin Crossing Rd. Follow for 1 km, track down to camp spot. This area could be difficult to access in wet weather. It is a small area - large vehicles will not be able to turn around here, but the track goes through the track with two entrances, one quite steep. There is a picnic table and some chairs but no other facilities. The camping surface is grass in the bush and a dirt surface next to the river. There is a dirt boat ramp so do not block it off. This spot is very popular with the local farmers and their speed/ski boats especially on weekends and in the holidays.

properties.name: Onslow Turnoff Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a parking area 44 km N of Nanutarra Roadhouse or 119 km S of Fortesque River Roadhouse, 1 km S of turnoff. It is a sealed pulloff with a dirt area. There is an information sign about the surrounding area. There is a picnic area and rubbish bin but no other facilities. There is also free wifi provided by the Pilbarra District Council. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Muluks Rest Area
properties.description: Rest area is just next to the highway. There are three sheltered picnic areas and a few garbage bins provided and you are allowed to make a fire. You park on the side of the sealed road, and the rest area is surrounded by bush and trees.

properties.name: Cave Hill Nature Reserve
properties.description: Free camping spot at the reserve. Toilet, picnic table and BBQ facilities available. Is also a nice area for rockclimbing and exploring nature. 35km SW of Widgiemooltha via dirt road. 4WD only.

properties.name: Mount Robinson Rest Area
properties.description: This nice overnight rest area with basic facilities is located well of the highway. It offers scenic hilly views and a few walking tracks. Suitable for big rigs. Turn off the highway on the bitumen access track.

properties.name: Fraser Range Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway rest area. There is a bitumen pullover that leads to a small dirt area. There are rubbish bins, fire pits, picnic tables and a toilet. There is also a dump station. There are level areas, but some of the site is unlevel. It is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. There is access down to the salt pan of the lake when dry that is only accessible with 4wd. This site does not go too far from the road, so road noise is present. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Baladjie Rock
properties.description: Popular camp spot W of Lake Baladjie. No facilities with limited shade, but beauitful area where you can get good photos. Located on dirt road, 5km N of Koorda-Bullfinch Rd. 25km W of Bullfinch.

properties.name: Eyres Place Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical highway rest area. There is a bitumen area at the front and a memorial stone for a construction worker who lost his life building this road. Behind the bitumen are dirt tracks leading into the bush. There are rubbish bins and fire pits. It is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Some larger vehicles and trucks will use the bitumen area. All types of vehicles can access this area. Because it is next to the highway, it is noisy.

properties.name: Lake Way Rest Area
properties.description: Rest area located just off Goldfields Hwy. Sheltered picnic table, limited shade available. Located 55km S of Wiluna.

properties.name: Jilah Rockhole Rest Area
properties.description: This is an official designated 24 hour stopping bush camp rest area on the Eyre Highway. There is a dirt pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and bush separating. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables, and a toilet, as well as fire rings. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Bea Bea Rest Area
properties.description: The rest area is located just 200m off of the highway. There are little bays on the side where you can camp, or you can camp in the big area where an information board and sheltered picnic table is provided as well. There are several bins around the rest area and you camp on a gravel dirt ground.

properties.name: Wilroy Nature Reserve
properties.description: Simple dirt parking area in the reserve. Rubbish bins, some shade from trees. Located on Mullewa-Wubin Rd, 18km SE of Mullewa next to the railway.

properties.name: Lake Nallan Nature Reserve
properties.description: Free camping area on the S bank of the lake. No facilities, lake is sometimes dry. Only camp in the two designated areas. Located just E of Great Northern Hwy via dirt road, 20km N of Cue. Max stay: 48hrs.

properties.name: Wannamal Rest Area
properties.description: Large dirt rest area E of Wannamal. Flush toilets, picnic tables, bins and BBQ available, some shade from trees. Located on Bindoon-Moora Rd, 30km N of Bindoon. Signposted from road.

properties.name: Borden Rest Area
properties.description: This is a parking area in Borden opposite the general store. There is a covered picnic area, rubbish bin, barbecue, flush toilets, and water. It is a sealed carpark and is not very shady but is quiet at night since this is a small town. There is no signage in regards to RVs or camping. Maximum stay: 20 Hours

properties.name: Buntine Rocks
properties.description: Free camping area at the rocks, with great views over farming land. No facilities, no shade. Located N of  Buntine E Rd, 3km NE of Buntine. Dirt road.

properties.name: Dynamite Bay
properties.description: Dynamite Bay is a stunning bay in Green Head which is sheltered from the strong winds off the coast by a low lying rocky cliff that circles around the beach. Swim in the calm turquoise waters or laze on the soft sandy beach.  Make a day of it and bring along a picnic that can be enjoyed on the sand.

properties.name: Lake Indoon
properties.description: This beautiful camping area with fantastic facilities is located on the lake shore, well off the road. It offers scenic views and allows swimming and basic water sports. It's a great base for exploring the area, with the nearby Stockyard Gully Reserve being a must-see. Please leave this spot as you found it! To get there, turn off Coolimba Eneabba Road and follow the dirt road.

properties.name: Turtle Cliff Lookout Walk
properties.description:
Turtle Cliff Lookout in Ningaloo Reef is a mesmerizing coastal trail that unveils the breathtaking beauty of Western Australia's marine paradise. 

Over a short but scenic stretch, travelers are treated to panoramic views of the azure Indian Ocean and rugged limestone cliffs. 

The trail's charm lies in its connection to nature; visitors often encounter nesting turtles and vibrant marine life.
