properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Glenbrook Estate Campground
properties.description:
The Glenbrook camp site although large in area caters for only a small number of campers giving a sense of privacy and space. Campers are free to choose their own site.

The kitchen facilities include gas barbecue, electric kettle, fridge, microwave oven and large benches. A clean ablution block comes with hot showers.The adjoining 70 ha of quality bush with several kilometres of walk trails allows you to enjoy bushwalking and day and night animal spotting.

properties.name: Lucky Bay Brewery
properties.description:
A beer from Lucky Bay Brewing is more than just a beer. With a lot of love, effort and science we turn the product of local farmers into a beer that celebrates rural WA.

Lucky Bay Brewing is also the only brewery in WA that uses raw barley direct from local farmers which reduces our carbon footprint.

properties.name: Vlamingh Head Lighthouse
properties.description:
Vlamingh Head Lighthouse is a heritage-listed lighthouse that stands proudly on a rugged headland at the mouth of Fremantle Harbour in Western Australia. 

Built in 1897, the lighthouse is the oldest operating lighthouse in the state and plays a vital role in guiding ships safely into the harbor.

properties.name: Myalup Caravan Park
properties.description: Family-friendly caravan park offering casual and long term sites for tents and caravans.

properties.name: Wadjemup Lighthouse
properties.description: The Wadjemup Lighthouse, an essential part of Wadjemup's maritime history, was erected in 1896 on the island's highest point to prevent frequent nautical disasters. Replacing the original stone lighthouse, it stands impressively at 38 meters, ranking as Australia's fourth tallest lighthouse of its kind. This advanced structure introduced cutting-edge technology to the island, boasting a holophotal revolving light flashing every 20 seconds, greatly improving navigation for passing ships and reducing coral shore groundings. Initially powered by electricity in 1936, it achieved full automation in 1990. Today, with its powerful, far-reaching light spanning 26 nautical miles, the Wadjemup Lighthouse remains a vital guide for safe navigation towards Fremantle port.

properties.name: Twilight Bay
properties.description: The beaches of Esperance are rated among the best in the world – and Twilight Bay is one of the towns most loved. Here, impossibly white sand meets unbelievably clear turquoise water creating a beautiful vista and perfect swimming conditions.

properties.name: Surfers Beach
properties.description: You will be enthralled by the magnificent waves at Surfers Beach, just 15 minutes' drive north of Exmouth. Also known as 'Dunes Beach', the reef break here is recommended for experienced surfers only. Surfers Beach is one of the most popular surf spots on the North West Cape for surfing.

properties.name: Sunset Beach
properties.description: Sunset Beach is one of the most popular Geraldton beaches for windsurfing and kite surfing. Hire your equipment in town, and whilst you are there you can arrange to take a lesson with a former National Champion before taking on the waves and famous Geraldton wind on your own.

properties.name: Salmon Bay
properties.description: Located on the southern part of the island, Salmon Bay boasts a lovely stretch of coastline, comprising white sandy shores and crystal clear water, sure to take anyone’s breath away. Suitable for swimmers of all ages.

properties.name: Roebuck Bay
properties.description:
Roebuck Bay is one of 12 Ramsar Nature Reserve wetland sites in Western Australia and is one of Broome’s most beautiful natural attractions. The changing colours in the ebb and flow of Roebuck Bay are amazing. 

At low tide, the milky turquoise waters retreat to expose a horizon of mud flats. During the cooler months you can witness the Staircase to the Moon. This spectacular natural phenomenon is created by the rising of a full moon reflecting off the tidal flats of Roebuck Bay. The bay is also home to some incredible wildlife including hundreds of birds, making it popular for bird watching.

properties.name: Redgate Beach
properties.description: Redgate Beach near Margaret River is a popular destination for surfers, locals and visitors. The stunning undulating terrain and exclusive bays offer an interesting backdrop with a safe surfing beach suited to beginners and experts alike.

properties.name: Port Beach
properties.description: Port Beach is conveniently located near the popular tourist hub of Fremantle. With attractive views out to Rottnest Island, and a popular café adjacent to an enclosed playground, you will easily see why it is a favourite with Perth locals.

properties.name: Point Moore Lighthouse
properties.description:
Point Moore Lighthouse is a 34-meter-tall lighthouse located at Point Moore, Geraldton, Western Australia. It was built in 1878 and is the oldest surviving Western Australian lighthouse under Federal control. The lighthouse is constructed of cast iron and is painted in distinctive red and white stripes. The lighthouse was built to mark the northern entrance to Geraldton Harbour. It is an important navigational aid for ships sailing between Perth and the Kimberley region. 

The lighthouse is open to the public for guided tours. The tours take visitors to the top of the lighthouse, where they can enjoy stunning views of the Geraldton coastline.

properties.name: Peppermint Grove Beach
properties.description: Enjoy relaxing on beautiful Peppermint Grove Beach near Busselton. Take a dip in the tantalizing waters of the Indian Ocean, or relax on the beautiful sandy beach and soak up the glorious sun. For the fishing enthusiasts, try your hand at beach fishing in the designated fishing areas.

properties.name: Ocean Beach
properties.description:
Denmark’s Ocean Beach is a popular destination for beach lovers, surfers and nature lovers.  The pristine white sandy beach and crystal blue waters make this a picture perfect destination, even if the water is a little chilly. 

Take your board out for a spot of surfing or boogie boarding or enjoy a swim.

properties.name: Myalup Beach
properties.description: Popular Myalup Beach in the State’s southwest offers a perfect opportunity to relax on the pristine white sand and soak up the famous Western Australian sun. Take a dip in the refreshing Indian Ocean or build sand castles with the children on the beach.

properties.name: Little Salmon Bay
properties.description: Little Salmon Bay is one of the most popular bays on Rottnest Island. It is a favourite spot for families as it is sheltered and calm and is also a great spot for snorkelling. Snorkelers can follow a snorkel trail to learn more about the different types of fish on Rottnest Island.

properties.name: Injidup Beach
properties.description: Get away from the hustle of every day and relax at Injidup Beach near Yallingup in the south west. This relaxed beach has a summer holiday vibe and is the ideal spot for the family to go swimming. Also popular for local surfers, while rocky outcrops create great conditions for snorkelling and diving.

properties.name: Horrocks Beach
properties.description:
Horrocks Beach is a past winner of Australia’s Best Australian Beaches category. It's a popular and picturesque swimming beach in the beautiful seaside town of Horrocks. 

Enjoy swimming, fishing, beach combing or indulge in a range of water activities. During late spring, visit the specially constructed platform to look out for Humpback whales on their migration south.

properties.name: Hopetoun Beaches
properties.description:
The secluded beaches of Hopetoun on Western Australia’s far south coast are among the most pristine and untouched in the country. 



Here, it’s easy to find an entire stretch of coastline all to yourself for swimming, snorkelling and lazing on the sand.



Isolated coves offer beachside picnicking, and camping.

properties.name: Goode Beach
properties.description: When in Albany, make sure you visit the lovely Goode Beach. Nestled in the King George Sound it is surrounded by numerous islands and enjoys views out to Mount Manypeaks. Goode Beach has several popular walk trails to explore the surrounding coastline.

properties.name: Dongara Port Denison Beaches
properties.description: There's plenty on offer at the beaches of the twin towns of Dongara and Port Denison - from tranquil bays perfect for swimming to excellent fishing spots, surf breaks and beaches where strong sea breezes keep windsurfers on the move.

properties.name: Cottesloe Beach
properties.description:
Perth's iconic Cottesloe Beach is as pretty as a picture. It's one of the city's most popular spots for swimming, snorkelling, surfing and drinking in ocean sunsets over a glass of wine, a refreshing beer or a relaxed dinner. 

'Cott', as it's affectionately known, can be reached by car, bus or train from Perth.

properties.name: Conspicuous Beach
properties.description: The spectacular coastline at Conspicuous Beach in the state’s south is extremely popular for fishing and surfing. Whilst the rough waters are not recommended for swimming, surfers will take delight in the breakers off the coast.

properties.name: Busselton Beachfront
properties.description: The picturesque Busselton Beachfront is home to the longest timber pier in the Southern Hemisphere, Busselton Jetty. The beachfront has a vast array of attractions to keep you entertained.

properties.name: Back Beach - Geraldton
properties.description:
Back Beach is one of the most popular surfing beaches in Geraldton. For the surfing enthusiast make sure to bring your surf board and practice your skill on the medium to large waves with the locals. 

The Surf Life Saving Club patrols the beaches during the summer weekends.

properties.name: Pemberton YHA
properties.description: Pemberton YHA, the only hostel in town, is situated in an original mill house cottage, that has been fully refurbished with modern kitchen and bathroom, wood fire, and a gas barbeque.

properties.name: Cherokee Village Mobile Home and Tourist Park
properties.description: Cherokee Village Mobile Home and Tourist Park is located just 17 kilometres north of Perth, with 22 powered sites, 11 fully self-contained cabins with bathroom, reverse cycle air-conditioning, television and all linen is supplied.

properties.name: Yallingup Beach
properties.description:
Yallingup Beach has it all – from big waves offshore, to a sheltered lagoon perfect for safe family swimming. It’s also a popular place to learn to surf. 

Go surfing and swimming at popular Yallingup Beach near the Margaret River wine region.

properties.name: Eagle Bay Beach
properties.description: This is a scenic beach.

properties.name: Orlov Trail
properties.description:
Orlov Trail and the Bells Rapids River Walk offers a picturesque journey along the tranquil Swan River. 

Spanning approximately 5 kilometers, the trail showcases the region's natural beauty with native flora and fauna. Admire the striking Bells Rapids, known for its powerful white-water rapids, and embrace the stunning views of the surrounding landscape. 

Ideal for nature enthusiasts and hikers, this trail provides an immersive experience in the heart of Western Australia's scenic wilderness.

properties.name: Swan Settlers Market
properties.description:
Nestled in the heart of the Swan Valley, Swan Settlers Market is a vibrant hub featuring a diverse array of enthusiastic artisans, cultivators, and creators! 

Entrance is complimentary, and everyone is invited. Bring your family and friends to explore a multitude of stalls offering fresh produce, handcrafted arts, delightful treats, fashionable items, and accessories. 

Immerse yourself in an international food court, a gin distillery with a cellar door, tempting confections, preserves, chutneys, an assortment of cheeses, and, of course, delectable coffee and cake!

properties.name: Oyster Stacks Snorkelling and Diving Area
properties.description:
The Oyster Stacks Snorkelling Area is accessible off the beach in the Ningaloo Reef region. 

It is a mesmerizing underwater haven for travelers seeking vibrant marine life. Crystal-clear waters reveal a kaleidoscope of coral formations, hosting a diverse ecosystem. 

Navigate through an enchanting maze of colorful corals teeming with tropical fish, rays, and friendly reef sharks.

Perfect for snorkelling or shore diving.

properties.name: Wave Rock & Star Gazing Walk
properties.description:
As night blankets the Wave Rock Walk, celestial wonders unveil themselves in one of the best star gazing destinations in all of Australia! 

Away from city lights, the velvety sky transforms into a black canvas painted with an abundance of stars. The crisp air and serene surroundings enhance the experience, allowing travelers to lose themselves in the vastness of the universe. 

The Milky Way stretches like a luminous ribbon, and constellations become vivid storytellers against the inky backdrop.

properties.name: The Malleefowl Travel Stop Sculptures
properties.description:
The Malleefowl Travel Stop is along the highway between Kondinin to Hyden, located at the turn off to Karlgarin. 

The Malleefowl sculptures were created by local residents Merv Trestrail and Colin Richter as part of a community arts project.

Malleefowls are known to nest around the town ship of Karlgarin and around McCann's Rock, so keep an eye out!

properties.name: Hyden Street Art
properties.description:
Hyden Street Art in Western Australia is a vibrant display of creativity, transforming the town's walls into an outdoor gallery. Adorned with striking murals and colorful graffiti, the art captures the spirit of the community and showcases the region's rich culture. 

From larger-than-life wildlife portraits to abstract designs, each piece tells a unique story and adds a splash of energy to the town's atmosphere. 

Take a leisurely stroll along Hyden's streets to discover this hidden gem, where urban art meets outback charm.

properties.name: Lake Magic
properties.description:
Lake Magic lives up to its name as a serene oasis nestled within the vast, untouched landscapes of the Goldfields region - this is a perfect place to see in the sun rise!

Surrounded by ancient eucalyptus trees and red earth, this ephemeral salt lake captivates travelers with its surreal beauty. The lake undergoes a stunning transformation, evolving from a crystalline expanse to a shimmering pink hue, especially during the sunset.

properties.name: Mitchell Falls
properties.description:
The four-tiered Mitchell Falls, a renowned Kimberley landmark, stands as one of Australia's most breathtaking waterfalls. 

Named Punamii-Uunpuu by the Wunambal people, the falls were sculpted by the Mitchell River through sandstone, creating captivating emerald pools that cascade from one level to the next. 

You can witness these stunning waterfalls from the air or embark on a close-up walk to the falls. Regardless of your choice, a visit to Mitchell Falls guarantees an unforgettable experience

properties.name: Hadiqua
properties.description: Information supplied by the Visitor Information Centre network helping provide tourist information across Australia

properties.description: Information supplied by the Visitor Information Centre network helping provide tourist information across Australia

properties.name: Bunkers Beach House
properties.description: Tucked into the dunes of the stunning Bunker Bay, this is al fresco dining at its finest

properties.name: Beach to Bay Broome Tour
properties.description: Join Yawuru man Bart Pigram and witness the natural beauty and wonder of the coastline of the Indian Ocean and historical Roebuck Bay. As you journey from beach to Bay learn to identify certain flora, fauna and sites that are still used by the Djugun and Yawuru people. Visit Roebuck Bay and Dampier Creek, a globally significant marine ecosystem. Bart combines ancient stories, cultural artefacts and family history with the pearling phenomena that Broome was built on.

properties.name: Lancelin North End Caravan Park
properties.description:
Welcome to Lancelin Holiday Park

Famous for its aqua beaches, epic sand dunes, windsurfing and laid-back vibe, the Lancelin Caravan Park is the perfect spot for that relaxing weekend or a beautiful extended holiday. 

Experience Lancelin Holiday Park is a camper’s paradise thanks to our impeccable caravan park facilities, huge range of camp sites, and ideal beachside location.

Our Lancelin camping site is less than 2 hours north of Perth, Western Australia and just off Indian Ocean Drive which seamlessly joins the Brand Highway to the north, making it easily accessible, no matter if you’re staying or passing through.

The campsites are conveniently located at the south end of Lancelin (also known as the south end caravan park), and is just a stone’s throw from the pristine beach and rolling waves of the Indian Ocean, giving you direct access to coastal walks, fishing, and water activities.

When camping with us, you’ll enjoy the tranquillity and uncomplicated nature of a beautiful beachside location and if you’ve had enough of the water, the much-loved Lancelin sand dunes are easily accessible from the other side of town. On top of this you’ll enjoy our easy access location plus all the creature comforts you could want including laundry, bathroom facilities, heated pool and spa.

Pitch your tent at one of our 100+ powered campsites and enjoy a comfortable but genuine camping experience.

With our Lancelin campsite, you and your family can enjoy the best of Lancelin right at your fingertips.

No matter the season or the sun’s UV rating, our undercover, temperature-controlled pool and spa is perfect for all travellers and families.

Did you know that Experience Lancelin Holiday Park is pet-friendly? With the exclusion of our new 2 bedroom cabins, we have a range of pet-friendly sites available to include your furry friend in your travel plans. See more information and otherwise get started on our pet policy and registration form.

properties.name: Shelley Beach Lookout
properties.description:
Shelley Beach Lookout is a popular tourist destination located in West Cape Howe National Park. It offers stunning views of the coastline, including the white sand of Shelley Beach, the turquoise waters of the Southern Ocean, and the rugged cliffs of the national park. The lookout is also a popular spot for hang gliding and paragliding, with a dedicated launch pad at the top. On a clear day, you can see for miles up and down the coast, and it is a truly breathtaking sight. 

To get to Shelley Beach Lookout, there is a short walk from the Shelley Beach Campground. The walk is well-maintained and suitable for all ages and fitness levels. Once you reach the lookout, there is a platform with seating where you can relax and enjoy the views.

properties.name: Little Beach
properties.description: Clear water, white sands. Totally worth drive ?

properties.name: Wylie Bay
properties.description: 20 kilometre 4WD beach drive. Very beautiful. Track run easy.

properties.name: Windy Harbour and Salmon Beach
properties.description: A trip to Windy Harbour and Salmon Beach offers a number of activities to ensure a memorable visit. Take a pleasant scenic drive to the lighthouse on the edge of the harbour for exceptional panoramic views of the coastline.

properties.name: Turquoise Bay
properties.description: Dive into the pristine waters of the aptly named Turquoise Bay near the town of Exmouth and you're swimming within a few metres of Ningaloo Reef. Known as one of Australia's best beaches, and amongst the top twenty beaches in the world, Turquoise Bay is the perfect spot to spend an afternoon relaxing or swimming.

properties.name: Smiths Beach
properties.description: Smiths Beach near Yallingup on the south west coast is where the locals go for summer holidays. Here, the swimming, fishing and surfing are top class. Sheltered areas offer great conditions for family swimming, while further along, surf breaks are popular for boogy boarders and surfers.

properties.name: Shelley Beach
properties.description: The white sands of Shelley Beach are surrounded by the rugged wilderness of West Cape Howe National Park. It’s the only area of this spectacular coastal landscape that can be accessed in a two wheel drive, making it a favourite stop for beach-lovers, campers, anglers and bushwalkers.

properties.name: Sandy Bay
properties.description: For a lazy holiday of swimming and relaxing, head to Sandy Bay near Exmouth on Western Australia's mid north coast. The shallow waters and wide expanse of endless white sand make this a great choice for families.

properties.name: Peaceful Bay
properties.description:
Peaceful Bay by name and by nature, this white-sand beach is sheltered from the Southern Ocean swell, with clear turquoise waters ideal for swimming, snorkelling, diving and fishing. 

It's a chilled-out seaside holiday spot just 40-minutes' drive from Denmark, or a five-hour drive from Perth.

properties.name: Mississippi Hill and Rossiter Bay
properties.description: Check out the picturesque views from Mississippi Hill and the stunning white sandy beaches of Rossiter Bay to find out why Cape Le Grand National Park is renowned as one of the most spectacular national parks in Australia. Walk around the massive granite rock outcrop that is Mississippi Hill and visit the memorial to the explorer Edward John Eyre, who named both the hill and the bay.

properties.name: Meelup Beach
properties.description: Families will love the pure white sand and gentle rolling waves of Meelup Beach, near Dunsborough. Meelup Beach has been a favourite for family holidays for generations. Here, the protected bay offers ideal swimming conditions.

properties.name: Hippo's Yawn
properties.description:
Hippo's Yawn is a little known rock near Wave Rock in Hyden. The rocks resemblance to a yawning hippo has given it its name. 

Climb through the throat of Hippo's Yawn and be sure to catch the interesting shot on camera.

The 20-minute walk to Hippo’s Yawn starts a five minute drive from the town of Hyden, which is a four hour drive from Perth.

In spring, there is an abundance of wild flowers in the area.

properties.name: Eighty Mile Beach
properties.description:
For endless stretches of white sand lapping onto turquoise water and excellent fishing and bird watching, head to aptly named Eighty Mile Beach half way between Broome and Port Hedland. 

Here you can see magnificent sunsets over the Indian Ocean and enjoy the glorious solitude of sharing your slice of beach.

properties.name: Chinaman's Beach
properties.description:
The tranquil setting of Chinaman’s Beach on the Murchison River in the heart of Kalbarri, makes it a popular swimming spot. Take advantage of the warmth of year round sunshine to swim in the refreshing clear waters. 

Explore the marine life under the water or hire a windsurfer or paddleboat.

properties.name: Cape Naturaliste Lighthouse
properties.description:
The Cape Naturaliste Lighthouse is one of the most popular attractions in the Margaret River Region and an easy climb of 59 stairs makes this lighthouse accessible even for small children.

Only 12 kilometres from the town of Dunsborough, the Cape Naturaliste Lighthouse and cottages reveal the fascinating maritime history of the Cape region.

Half-hour guided tours provide a captivating insight into the functions of this working lighthouse with visitors to the top balcony of the lighthouse tower rewarded with breathtaking panoramic views of the Indian Ocean, Cape Naturaliste, the Leeuwin-Naturaliste National Park and the beautiful Geographe Bay coastline.

properties.name: Binningup Beach
properties.description: Binningup Beach is located in the southwest of Western Australia and offers the perfect opportunity to relax on the pristine white sand and soak up the sun. Take a dip in the refreshing Indian Ocean or watch the children create pieces of sand art on the beach.

properties.name: Bill's Bay Shark Nursery
properties.description:
The tranquillity of Bill's Bay with its pristine beaches and protected waters has a wonderfully relaxed seaside holiday ambience. The bay is located in the tiny town of Coral Bay.

Walk just 20 minutes north along the beach at Bill’s Bay and watch as up to 200 reef sharks congregate in the shallow waters between October and March.

At its best, you can spot up to 200 young reef sharks swimming in the waters.  It's truly an unforgettable experience.

properties.name: Cable Beach View Point
properties.description: Beautiful view point and access to the beach

properties.name: Weanu Gorge/Oxer Lookout
properties.description: Weano Gorge, nestled within Western Australia's Karijini National Park, offers a breathtaking natural spectacle. Carved by eons of water erosion, its towering red cliffs surround visitors with ancient geological wonders. Oxer Lookout provides a vantage point, revealing the stunning intersection of four deep gorges, an awe-inspiring testament to Earth's geological history.

properties.name: Nanga Beach
properties.description: This is a public access beach on the West side of Shark Bay World Heritage Area. Go past the caravan park to the beach access. The caravan park is a full-service stop with petrol, hotel/motel accomodation, small shop and camping sites.

properties.name: Wave Rock
properties.description:
Wave Rock is a natural rock formation that is shaped like a giant breaking ocean wave. It is located in the Wheatbelt region of Western Australia, about 340 kilometres east of Perth. 

The rock is about 15 metres high and 110 metres long, and is made of granite. It is believed to have been formed over millions of years by the wind and rain. 

Wave Rock is a popular tourist destination and is known as one of Australia's most iconic landmarks.

properties.name: Wooramel Roadhouse
properties.description: A typical roadhouse offering petrol, food and accommodation. The meals were very hearty and tasty, facilities were usable. Very pleasant staff.

properties.name: Brockman Stewart Rest Area
properties.description: Nice spot to spend one night (only), with wheelchair access toilets, picnic tables and an information desk. A lot of shade and covered from the highway so not much noise at night.

properties.name: Greenbushes Pool
properties.description: Great spot for large RV to tents. Toilets, tape water , playground & swimming

properties.name: Prevelly Caravan Park
properties.description: A beachside location in Margaret River

properties.name: Lake Poorrarecup
properties.description:
This nice camping area with fantastic facilities and a boat ramp is located beside the lake, well off the road. Boating and swimming are permitted here, however there is a sign warning for amoebic meningitis. There are trees around to provide shade and shelter.
Please be advised that pets are not allowed at the lake sites.

properties.name: Herron Point Campground
properties.description:
Herron Point Campground is a nature-based campsite on the sandy white shoreline of the Peel-Harvey Estuary. It's a quick getaway only one-hour south of Perth and 15-minutes from the Pinjarra townsite. 

With sites available for caravans, camper trailers and tents, Herron Point is an idyllic destination for your next adventure.

What you need to know

Herron Point camping ground provides beach side camping for tents and caravans. Facilities include toilets, bins and mobile phone coverage. 

There is a maximum stay of 48 hours. 

There is a caretaker onsite.

properties.name: Dampier Transit Caravan Park
properties.description:
CLOSED BETWEEN NOVEMBER - MARCH.  OPEN APRIL - OCTOBER

Small site for about 20 vans, 3 days max stay, washing mashines available

properties.name: Urchin Point Campground
properties.description: Urchin Point Camp is located in Dirk Hartog Island National Park, making it the perfect destination for a snorkelling and diving holiday. The camp itself is one of six designated campgrounds in the area. Accessible only by four-wheel drive (4WD).

properties.name: Cape Keraudren
properties.description: Cape Keraudren camping area provides sites for vehicle based camping, caravans and camper trailers. There are toilets available. You will need to bring your own water and firewood. Activities include fishing, boat ramp, and walking trails. Camping fees are paid to the reserve ranger.

properties.name: York Travellers Rest Caravan Park
properties.description:
York Travellers Rest Caravan Park has the facilities to cater for overnight or extended stays for the “Grey Nomads”, couples, families and groups by offering tent sites, powered sites for caravans and motor homes (large and small) and we are pet friendly. Nestled under the shadow of Mt Bakewell, backing onto the Racecourse and shaded by many beautiful Australian Gum Trees with peaceful wide open spaces, in a natural bush setting with an abundance of bird life and a star-filled sky at night.

Being just an hour and a half country drive east of Perth in the Avon Valley, York is a relaxing place to unwind while on any trip and makes it a great stopover on the way to or from any destination.

properties.name: Green Haven Tourist Park
properties.description:
Green Haven Tourist Park has a range of powered sites with plenty of trees to provide shade, and a large grassy area for camping.

The camping site area is located conveniently near our clean ablution block, that contains both laundry and shower facilities.

Enjoy stress free meal times under the cover of the communal camp kitchen, surrounded by untouched natural beauty.

properties.name: Turner Holiday Park
properties.description:
Welcome to Turner Holiday Park, an idyllic spot to relax, unwind and let nature do what it does best. Find yourself on the banks of Goorbilyup (the Blackwood River), where the river meets the ocean and take the opportunity to fish, swim or stroll along the coastal path that leads into Taalinup (Augusta) town.

Turner Holiday Park offers accommodation for all types of travellers. Our powered and unpowered campsites are situated in spacious, grassy and shady areas close to the river. Enjoy access to all camp amenities, including four amenity blocks, electric BBQs, laundry and camp kitchen.

properties.name: Mandu Mandu Gorge
properties.description:
Mandu Mandu Gorge, situated in Cape Range National Park, Western Australia, is a remarkable natural attraction renowned for its rugged beauty. 

This gorge is a striking geological formation, flanked by towering red rock walls. Hikers can explore its rocky terrain along designated trails, taking in panoramic vistas of the surrounding landscape. 

Mandu Mandu Gorge also offers opportunities for wildlife spotting, with chances to encounter native fauna. It's a captivating destination for those seeking the natural wonders of Western Australia's Coral Coast.

properties.name: Blythwood Rest Area
properties.description:
This rest area is a great spot for travellers with pets. 

It offers free parking for caravans and camper trailers and has good phone reception. The area is well-maintained and tidy. The staff are friendly and helpful, and the facilities have been well-kept. 

The location is fantastic, with stunning views. It's a great place to rest and relax while travelling through Perth. Highly recommend!

properties.name: Blythwood South Rest Area
properties.description: Basic rest area suitable for self contained vehicles. Limited facilities on site.

properties.name: Janet Millet Lane RV 24hr Rest Stop
properties.description:
The Janet Millett Lane RV stop is conveniently located across the Avon River from the town centre. This free area offers limited parking for self-contained RVs for a maximum of 24 hours. 

An RV dump point is available on-site. For refillable fresh water, head over to Avon Park.

**Nearby Amenities**

The RV stop is close to shops and the popular Swinging Bridge.

**Extended Stays**

If you'd like to stay longer than 24 hours, consider these options:

Local Caravan Parks: There are two caravan parks in the York area that offer amenities like toilets, showers, and powered sites.

Visitor Centre Contact: For more RV park recommendations, contact the York Visitor Centre at 9641 1301 or info@york.wa.gov.au.

properties.name: BIG4 Bridgetown Caravan Park
properties.description:
BIG4 Bridgetown Caravan Park - Your South West Escape

Discover the beauty of Bridgetown, Western Australia, at BIG4 Bridgetown Caravan Park. Nestled along the picturesque Blackwood River, our park offers a tranquil retreat for families, couples, and solo adventurers.   

Relax by the river, explore the charming town of Bridgetown, or embark on a scenic drive through the stunning Blackwood Valley. With a range of accommodation options, from powered and unpowered sites to cozy cabins, we have everything you need for a comfortable stay.   

Enjoy our fantastic facilities, including a camp kitchen, BBQ areas, and kayak hire.

 Book your unforgettable getaway today!

properties.name: Lake Campion
properties.description:
Located just outside Perth, an hour north of Merredin, Lake Brown in the Lake Campion Nature Reserve is a striking salt lake, dry for most of the year and covered with a white salt crust. Occasionally, pressure ridges create unique patterns on the surface.

At night, the lake glows faintly under starlight, with only the sound of a gentle breeze in the vast, empty landscape. The Milky Way arcs overhead, and there's no sign of human presence.

While remote, Lake Brown is a popular camping spot, especially along its western shore. A rocky granite ridge with caves, boulders, and bush offers an excellent vantage point of the lake and surrounding fields. Nearby is Eaglestone Rock, a large granite formation sometimes visited by Wedgetail Eagles.

properties.name: Heartwalk Art Kalgoorlie
properties.description:
Heartwalk - Art in the Heart of the Kalgoorlie CBD, is all about enlivening the Central Business District with vibrant and contemporary murals by Australian Artists from the Goldfields and beyond.

Take a stroll at your own pace around the CBD and visit each of these amazing murals by talented artists.

Tours are available with local artist, Linda Rae, bookings can be made online or at the Kalgoorlie Boulder Visitor Centre.

More than 40 local, indigenous and West Australian professional artists were contracted to create high quality murals in the windows of empty shops and blank walls in strategically selected locations throughout the CBD, transforming the city centre into a vibrant arts and cultural precinct.

Collect your walking trail map from the friendly team at the Kalgoorlie Boulder Visitor Centre, or contact 08 9021 1966 for more information.

properties.name: Wylie Bay Sand Dunes
properties.description:
Esperance may be known for its whitest of all sands however it also a land of towering sand dunes to rival Lancelin.

The sand dunes are located nearby Wylie Bay and only accessible by 4WD. Make a day of it by unleashing the inner daredevil by hopping on a sandboard or partake in a tour with Tour Esperance to get wild along the dunes for that epic shot.

properties.name: Honeycomb Gorge Trail
properties.description:
Honeycomb Gorge Trail is a 600 metre trail in the Kennedy Range NP.

The trail follows a stony creek bed to a large amphitheatre containing a seasonal waterfall and pool. 

Marvel at the honeycomb cavities that have been eroded into the cliff face.

properties.name: East Mount Barron Trail
properties.description:
The trail to the summit of East Mt Barren is short yet challenging, rewarding hikers with breathtaking views of Culham Inlet, the Eyre Range, Hamersley Inlet, as well as the peaks of mid Mt Barren and Thumb Peak. 

The area is also known for its year-round display of beautiful wildflowers

The trail is 3km long.

properties.name: Wyalup-Rocky Point RV Stop
properties.description:
Wyalup Rocky Point is a place of Indigenous significance. Wyalup means a "place of mourning" as in the past the area was a Noongar burial ground. The waves plummet over these ancient and rare rock formations. Sunset time is the best, when the light creeps down over the evening landscape, providing a dramatic backdrop.

The 130 million-year-old Basalt Rock can only be seen on Wyalup Rocky Point in Bunbury, at Capel and Black Point in the Southern Forest and Valley’s region. It was part of the Kerguelen large igneous province that formed over a period from about 130 to 95 million years ago as Australia, India and Antarctica split apart.

Less than a kilometre from Bunbury’s central business district, the area has a beach lookout, interpretive information, barbecues, playground and picnic facilities.

There is a wide, level path surrounding the picnic area which connects the parking with the beach lookout, accessible toilets and change room.

A free fully self-contained vehicle 48-hour camping location is also here. A permit is required to stay, contact the Bunbury Visitor Centre for a permit or visit the website.

properties.name: Chappel's Bridge
properties.description:
This free site offers a public toilet and is pet-friendly, though baiting has been carried out in the area. Fires are prohibited year-round.

The site is accessible for four-wheel drive vehicles, but a large sign at the Glenoran Fire Shed entrance clearly states "No Caravans." Be cautious when using Google Maps; many access tracks have been overgrown for over 20 years. Only Chappells Rd remains passable. Some visitors have removed posts to gain access beyond the approved routes, but management may restrict or close access in the future. In the past, steel stakes were placed inside bollards to prevent this.

There is a single bay near one table and fireplace, and a day-use area near the old bridge site with a table and fireplace. A car pull-off bay is also nearby. The old riding hut, which once had a table and fireplace, has since been destroyed. The site also includes a double car bay.

Please note: Tiger snakes are common in the area. For a longer stay, Greens Island is a more suitable option for overnight or extended visits.

properties.name: Hellfire Bay
properties.description:
Hellfire Bay is one of the most beautiful bays situated within the protected bounds of Cape Le Grand National Park. It is a great spot to enjoy a picnic or a refreshing dip in calm conditions. The bay is thought to have been named after St Elmo's fire – a bluish flame-like electrical discharge that sometimes occurs above a ship's masts.

This secluded beach nestled between giant, granite rocks, boasts some of the most impressive turquoise ocean views in Western Australia. As this beach is a little less well-known, you may even be lucky enough to have the entire beach to yourself, making you feel like you’re on your private island.

The Recherche Archipelago sits in the distance. with the silhouettes of islands popping up through the ocean. This scenic bay is a perfect spot to swim in calm conditions followed by a picnic on the sand, with barbeque facilities at hand.

properties.name: Fraser Gallop Winery
properties.description:
At the highest point in the Wilyabrup Valley - the heart of the Margaret River Wine Region - you will find Fraser Gallop Estate. Spectacular vineyard views, matched with world-acclaimed wines, make this a cellar-door visit to remember.

Visit the Fraser Gallop Estate Cellar Door, open daily and features all current-release wines and more.

properties.name: Joffre Falls Lookout Walk
properties.description:
On the western side of the park is Joffre Gorge, a spectacular curved waterfall forming a natural amphitheatre.

Especially impressive after rain, water cascades down the step-like cliff face to a dark pool and then, as the gorge narrows, the rushing, white waters tumble over smooth black rock.

Joffre Falls walk trail

Follow the marked route into the bottom of the gorge to the first pool downstream of the waterfall.

Distance 1.5km
Time 2 hours return.

properties.name: Dolphin Cove
properties.description:
Dolphin Cove is a secluded spot along the coastline of Cape Le Grand National Park, known for its tranquil beauty and the chance to spot dolphins in the bay. The cove gets its name from these frequent visitors, and your best chances of seeing them are early in the morning or late afternoon.

The calm, shallow waters make it an excellent location for swimming, particularly for families. It’s also one of the top snorkelling spots along the Great Ocean Road, offering vibrant underwater views with colourful fish and starfish.

properties.name: Beedelup Falls
properties.description:
Discover this small and attractive series of rocky cascades. The falls are pleasant all year round, but the best time to see them in full flow is in winter or early spring. Visitors can access Beedelup Falls from a 300m walk trail from the car park. The trail takes you across the suspension bridge over Beedelup Brook. Walk trails leave from the falls to the Karri Valley Resort.

Beedelup Loop Walk
Set out on a 4.5km moderately hard walk, which meanders through karri forest via Karri Valley Resort. This walk can be broken up into shorter sections.

There is an accessible lookout which has spectacular views of Beedelup Falls and the Karri Valley Resort.

properties.name: Branco's Lookout
properties.description: Welcome to Branco's Lookout. This is the highest lookout at El Questro, where the sun sets behind as you take in this incredible sweeping view

properties.name: Beresford Foreshore Lookout
properties.description:
The Beresford Foreshore is one of Geraldton's open spaces and attracts thousands of visitors. The stretch hugs the coastline with barbecue facilities, spots to sit and enjoy the view, first-class amenities, grassed areas, bowls for dogs to drink water out of as well as a playground that resembles a pirate scene.

Beresford Foreshore is also home to Lucy Humphrey's Horizon, which has won several Sculptures by the Sea accolades. The 1.5-metre sphere turns the world upside down and has quickly become a community favourite with hundreds snapping their photos and posting online.

properties.name: Warren River Lookout
properties.description:
This spectacular lookout is accessible by car along the Heartbreak Trail or via a short walk from the Bicentennial Tree. It provides views over the often mist shrouded river below and a pleasant place for a picnic.
An interpretive sign answers the question ‘Why is the Warren River salty?’

properties.name: Lake Lefroy Red Hill Lookout
properties.description:
Kambalda's Red Hill Lookout offers an easy walk up to the summit where you will be rewarded for your efforts with a magnificent view right across the expanse of Lake Lefroy, one of the region's most spectacular shimmering white salt lakes.

An undercover picnic table is provided at the summit for you to relax and enjoy the view.

properties.name: Granny’s Pool
properties.description:
The idea of a wild southwest is articulated along the Augusta shoreline. Granny’s Pool is a hamlet from this Southern Ocean expanse.

Tucked up in Flinders Bay, an ocean outcrop of rock rings around the pool and breaks the southerly swells, creating a swathe of calm blue. Stillness in the midst of stunning coastal ferocity.

Family-friendly is a theme along the Flinders Bay coastline, and the landscape surrounding Granny’s Pool is no exception. Hunt for crabs. Snorkel in the shallows. Take breaks beneath nearby shade trees. As the furthest point of land on the southwest coast, exploration forms an enormous part of Augusta’s character and history.

properties.name: Schroeder Pool Free Campground
properties.description:
This free camping area has no facilities – no water taps, no toilets and no fire places. So you’ll need to pack out all your waste. It is a shady clearing in the forest, perhaps 20 meters in diameter, about 50 meters from the Blackwood River. The gravel access road is rough but is nonetheless suitable for 2WD vehicles if driven carefully.

There are other camping spots nearby to discover. For example, near Hut Pool, just to the east, where the Great North Road crosses the river. If you have a 4WD you can explore the many bush tracks shown on the map.

The Blackwood River here has several large pools suitable for swimming, canoeing, fishing for bream and marron in season. There are many vehicle and walking tracks, some courtesy of marron hunters, that are pleasant for hiking.

properties.name: Eleven Mile Lagoon
properties.description: Great for a swim in the calm lagoon or a wander through the rock pools at low tight.

properties.name: Goon Tycoons Winery
properties.description:
At Goon Tycoons in the Yallingup Hills, you can enjoy both wine tastings and picnic-style cheese boards overlooking wonderful scenery which encompasses vineyards, native untouched forest and an enormous body of water full of bird life. 

Their wines are designed to promote the unique varieties and grower sites they’ve found on our endless quest for great vineyards.

properties.name: Amelia Park Wines
properties.description:
Located in the heart of the beautiful Margaret River Wine region of Western Australia, Amelia Park Wines was established in 2009.

A long list of awards confirm Amelia Park on the list of the Best Wineries in the Margaret River Region and in the top 5% of wineries in Australia. In November 2014, Amelia Park was named Margaret River Winery of the Year at the Melbourne International Wine Competition

Amelia Park was named the Best Cellar Door in Margaret River, by acclaimed Gourmet Traveller WINE Magazine, three years in a row. The Cellar Door is located in the picturesque Wilyabrup Valley, the heart of Margaret River, capturing views over the gorgeous vineyard whilst wine tasting.  An exception tasting experience to go with the exceptional wines.

properties.name: Mimbi Caves Campground - Jarlarloo Riwi
properties.description:
Modern amenities, hot showers, a barbecue shelter, secluded campsites and a friendly welcome await you at Mimbi Caves Campground.

Nestled at the foot of the Emmanuel Ranges and just a short drive off Great Northern Highway, the campground has a Gooniyandi name “Jarlarloo Riwi”; Jarlarloo means Coolamon tree and Riwi means camp.

Come and camp and experience the indigenous guided tours offered at the nearby Mimbi Caves, one of Australia’s most spectacular and significant natural geological sites. Mimbi Caves is a place of deep spiritual significance to the Gooniyandi people as well as being one of the most significant Devonian fossil sites in the world, and is a must-see when in the region.

The Mimbi Campground has 21 camping sites.

properties.name: Big Mertens Falls (Mertens Gorge)
properties.description:
Big Mertens Falls, or Mertens Gorge as it's now called. Now these falls are big, though not as big as the Mitchell Falls.

If you walk along the top of the falls to the far right you get the best view of them. But be extremely careful here, it's a looong way down...

properties.name: Little Mertens Falls
properties.description:
The falls are a one hour round trip (1.6km return) from Mitchell Falls Campground, which allows time to explore and swim.

You can swim above and below the falls. Rock ledges, rapids, pools, natural spas and a fern-lined cave are all features of this beautiful oasis. Take care, especially near the edge, and respect the spiritual importance of this site to Wunambal Aboriginal people.

properties.name: Aunauyu (Surveyors Pool)
properties.description: This is a scenic pool surrounded by blocky layers of King Leopold sandstone. It is located approximately 37 kilometres from the campground, with a moderate 2km return walk to the pool and falls (allow approximately one hour).

properties.name: Wilyabrup Cliffs Lookout Walk
properties.description:
This 1 km trail takes you through picturesque farmland before entering Leeuwin-Naturaliste National Park, culminating at the top of impressive sea cliffs. Rising 30 meters, these cliffs stretch along the coast for approximately 500 meters and are favoured by rock climbers, providing stunning elevated views of the shoreline. 

You can also venture north along the intersecting Cape to Cape Track for additional vistas. From the cliff's edge, a pathway leads south to access a track that runs beneath the cliffs.

A viewing platform and toilet facilities are situated about 50 meters inland from the cliff edge.

properties.name: Zebedee Springs
properties.description:
A rejuvenating soak awaits at Zebedee Springs, accessible via a short walk through a prehistoric forest of Livistona and pandanus palms, leading to a series of inviting thermal pools and waterfalls. This is just one of the many incredible experiences within the vast one-million-acre El Questro wilderness.

To reach Zebedee Springs and El Questro, you can drive along the iconic Gibb River Road in a four-wheel drive from Kununurra, book a transfer by road or air, or join a guided tour. The springs are open to the public from 7 am to noon, with afternoon access reserved for Homestead guests. 

The walk from the car park is 1.5 kilometers round trip. Guided tours can also provide a full or half-day experience that includes a relaxing dip in the thermal pools alongside visits to other natural attractions in the park.

properties.name: Champagne Springs
properties.description:
Champagne Springs, located in El Questro Wilderness Park, is a stunning natural attraction known for its crystal-clear waters and picturesque surroundings. The site features thermal springs that create vibrant, inviting pools, perfect for a refreshing swim. 
Accessible via a 9km walk through lush vegetation, visitors can enjoy the stunning atmosphere and breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape, making it a popular spot for relaxation and exploration.

- 9km return
- 5-6 hours to complete
- Grade 5
- Hard/Moderate
- Take lots of water!
- Start early in the morning

properties.name: Amalia Gorge Walking Trail
properties.description: The Amalia Gorge Walking Trail offers a stunning journey through diverse landscapes, featuring towering cliffs and lush vegetation. This moderate trail takes you along the gorge's edge, providing breathtaking views and a chance to spot local wildlife along the way.

properties.name: Dales Campground
properties.description:
Dales Campground is large and located near Dales Gorge, Fern Pool, Fortescue Falls, and Circular Pool.

**Booking**
Reservations are required and can be made up to 180 days in advance for one campsite. For outdoor education providers or licensed tour operators, contact the Parks and Wildlife Service Pilbara Region HQ for arrangements.

**Campsites**
The campground offers 153 gravel sites of various sizes in six areas. Generators are allowed in select areas, and all sites are unpowered. Review the campsite details when booking.

**Facilities**
Amenities include no-flush pit toilets and a chemical dump station. Showers are available for a fee at the Karijini Visitor Centre (12 km away) during open hours. Sheltered picnic tables are at the nearby Dales Picnic Area.

**Campground Rules**
- No campfires or dogs allowed.
- Generator use is restricted to 8 am–8 pm in specific areas.
- Dispose of portable toilet waste at designated dump points.
- Carry all waste out of the park; no bins provided.

**Fees**
A per-person camping fee and vehicle entry fee apply, payable by Mastercard or VISA when booking. Payment is required for motor vehicles only; trailers are exempt.

properties.name: Hancock Gorge and Kermits Pool
properties.description:
Hancock Gorge is simply breathtaking. 

After descending a ladder, you'll journey deep into the gorge, navigating narrow chambers and stunning rock pools. This short trail is among the park's most thrilling, leading through a narrow canyon to a natural amphitheater and continuing through the famous Spider Walk to the emerald waters of Kermits Pool.

Both are accessed via a Class 2 trail from the nearby Weano Recreation carpark, there’s also a spur trail connecting to the Oxer and Junction Pool lookouts. Visitors should exercise caution when entering Hancock Gorge.

properties.name: Knox Gorge and Lookout
properties.description:
The Knox Lookout offers breathtaking views of Knox Gorge and its junction with Wittenoom Gorge. It's especially beautiful in the early morning or late afternoon when the sunlight highlights the vibrant colors of the steep rock faces.

From the lookout, a path leads to the Knox Gorge trail, which descends into the gorge and follows the base until it narrows into a slot canyon. This 2-kilometer round-trip trail involves some rock scrambling and a bit of ledge walking.

properties.name: Homestead Valley Walk
properties.description:
The Homestead Valley Trail starts at the Bloodwoods car park and leads into Homestead Valley Gorge, showcasing stunning views of the red rocks along the escarpment. The trail includes a few short steep sections, with handrails to assist hikers, and features a shaded seating area at the end. This walk is a 4.5-kilometer round trip.

The Bloodwoods serves as a starting point for the Mini Palms Trail, Homestead Valley Trail, and the southern section of the Escarpment Trail. It offers amenities such as toilets, shaded picnic spots, and the Bloodwoods Lookout. The parking area is situated 19 km from the visitor center and is located within Purnululu National Park, about 230 km (3 hours) south of Kununurra and 2,890 km (30 hours) north of Perth.

properties.name: Mini Palms Gorge Trail
properties.description: The Mini Palms Gorge Trail spans 4.4 km round-trip from the Bloodwood carpark. The path features steep inclines, narrow ledges, and sizable boulders that you'll need to navigate by climbing over, ducking under, or squeezing between. Ascend the stairs to reach two viewing platforms nestled among the Livistona palms.

properties.name: Echidna Chasm Trail
properties.description:
The start of the walk is exposed to the sun, along an uneven, dry creek bed lined with Livistona Palms. 

Once you reach the boulders, which require 3 points of contact to scramble over, the trail becomes a Class 5. 

Between 11am- 1pm when the sun is overhead, Echidna Chasm lights up in brilliant shades of oranges and reds, creating the perfect photo opportunity. 

- Distance 2km return
- Class 4 and 5
- Time allow 1 hour

properties.name: El Questro Gorge
properties.description:
This hike is one of the more challenging options on the station, but it’s also incredibly enjoyable. The trail winds through a narrow gorge with steep rock walls, making it an exciting adventure. It’s best to tackle El Questro Gorge later in the day, as much of the path is shaded. At the halfway mark, you'll encounter a challenging boulder that may require some effort to navigate; it’s perfectly fine to turn back if needed. However, if you have the time and upper body strength, pushing on is definitely worthwhile!

- 7.2 km
- 3 to 5 hours

properties.name: Pigeon Hole Lookout
properties.description:
Situated roughly 100 kilometers from Kununurra in East Kimberley, El Questro is a favored stop for travelers along the Gibb River Road and for numerous visitors arriving from the eastern regions of Western Australia. 

Spanning 700,000 acres, this private estate boasts stunning gorges, natural thermal springs, exciting driving routes, hiking trails, and breathtaking viewpoints.

properties.name: Mt Barnett Station Roadhouse
properties.description:
Manning Gorge is located on Mount Barnett Station, about half way along the Gibb River Road. Access is via the Mt. Barnett Roadhouse.

The roadhouse is very well equipped, well set up and offers good service and a basic campground. This is also where you pay your entrance and camping fee for Manning Gorge.

(You pay that first, and then you drive on for a few more kilometres to the camping area and gorge.)

properties.name: Manning Gorge Campground
properties.description:
The camping area at Manning Gorge offers basic facilities nea the amazing swimming hole.

No bookings are taken for the campsite. Travellers can pay their fees at the roadhouse during opening hours or to the campsite caretakers after hours. 

The fees are $25.00 per adult for the first night and $15.00 for any additional nights. Children under 14 are free of charge.

properties.name: Blue Haven Beach
properties.description:
Journey down a steep and winding staircase to find the beautiful Blue Haven Beach. Tucked away from the wind, with rock faces on either side, this is the perfect spot for swimming and sun baking on a sunny Esperance day. Depending on the tides, there can be limited beaches available to set up for the day, but the rocks are a perfect spot to lay on and soak up the sun.

Whilst taking a refreshing dip out in the bay, don’t forget to turn around and admire the rugged coastline. The rock faces and cliffs contrast beautifully against the blue water and white sand, reminding you of just how incredible these hidden beaches are.

Blue Haven is one of the many beaches along the Great Ocean Drive, which twists and turns alongside the coastline offering fantastic views and building anticipation for that very first dip in Esperance’s beaches.

properties.name: Crawley Edge Boatshed
properties.description:
The iconic Crawley Edge Boatshed, situated on the banks of the Swan River at Matilda Bay in Crawley, is one of Perth city’s insta and wedding photo hotspots for tourists and locals alike using the hashtag #blueboathouse.

The Boatshed is known for being the most photographed attraction in Perth ahead of Elizabeth Quay, Cathedral Square and the Bell Tower.

A well known landmark, it was built in the 1930s and since the 1940s has been owned by the Nattrass family who paid five pounds for the original structure and has been rebuilt several times since.

properties.name: Quinninup Falls
properties.description:
Quinninup Falls is a breathtaking destination in Warren National Park, Western Australia. 

This stunning site features cascading waterfalls that flow into a serene pool, making it perfect for nature lovers and adventure seekers alike. Surrounded by lush forest, the falls offer picturesque views and a peaceful nature escape

properties.name: Pemberton Pool
properties.description:
Pemberton Pool is located within the Pemberton Forest Park, nestled on the Lefroy Brook next to the Pemberton Mountain Bike Park. Pemberton Forest Park covers 120 hectares and has 22 kilometres of mountain bike tracks and dual use trails.

The historic swimming pool was constructed in the late 1920's for the families of the timber workers and has been an iconic destination for generations of locals and visitors. It is the perfect destination for a barbecue, a picnic, swimming in summer and appreciating the native flora and fauna.

properties.name: King Waves Kill Sign
properties.description:
An iconic stop at Quobba Station as you travel along Australia’s Coral Coast. Located near the Quobba Blowholes.

It's not just a great photo stop - it also offers a very real warning to the waves in the area.

properties.name: The Bungle Bungles
properties.description: Rising 300 metres above the grass-covered plains that surround them, the orange and black sandstone domes known as the Bungle Bungle are one of the world’s most fascinating geological landmarks.

properties.name: Piccaninny Creek
properties.description:
Piccaninny has several different trails to choose from, from a short 700m return walk to a minimum 20km return overnight hike along Piccaninny Creek into the gorge system. Piccaninny parking area is 27km from the visitor centre.

**The Domes**
- Distance 700m return
- Class 3
- Time allow 30 minutes

This short, uneven loop takes you up close among the beehive domes, where you can clearly see the different layers of the sediment and the protective banding of the orange iron oxide and grey cyanobacteria. 

**Cathedral Gorge**
- Distance 2km return
- Class 4
- Time allow over an hour

A spectacular walk amongst the towering beehive domes that leads to the iconic natural amphitheatre and permanent pool. 

**The Window** 
- Distance 6 km return walk
- Class 4
- Time allow 2 hours

Walk further along the Piccaninny Creek bed amongst the beehive domes and large potholes, to a natural window in a sandstone structure. Please do not climb the Window.

**Whip Snake Gorge**
- Distance 10km return walk
- Class 4
- Time allow 4 hours 

Continue pass the Window along the Piccaninny Creek bed, where the trail veers to the left taking you into one of the many gorges within the range. This small natural amphitheatre contains rock figs, gums, ferns, and mosses.

**Piccaninny Gorge Trek**
- Distance approximately 20km return to the 'Elbow'. Total walking distance could be 40km+ if you explore all the gorges.
- Class 6
- Time allow 2 days minimum

properties.name: Yamaji Art Centre
properties.description:
Yamaji Art is a 100% Aboriginal owned & operated art centre in Mid West, Western Australia.

Yamaji Art represents artists from more than five broad Cultural groups from the region: Amangu, Nhanagardi, Naaguja, Badimaya, Wajarri, Wilunyu and as a contemporary urban based art centre, represents others currently residing in Geraldton or the region, including Nyoongar, Yinggarda and Ngaanyatjarra artists.

Works produced by Yamaji Art artists have been showcased in exhibitions nationally and overseas.

properties.name: Hovea Falls
properties.description:
Hovea Falls is a stunning natural attraction nestled within the picturesque John Forrest National Park, just 30 minutes from Perth. 

The falls cascade over a rocky outcrop into a serene pool below, creating a tranquil oasis surrounded by lush vegetation and towering gum trees. The area is perfect for picnicking, with designated spots offering stunning views of the falls.

properties.name: Karri Aura Tourist Park
properties.description:
Karri Aura Tourist Park: Your Peaceful Getaway 

Escape to the tranquility of Karri Aura Tourist Park,  just 4.4kms from Denmark town, in a beautiful rural setting with views over the natural karri forest to Mount Shadforth and the ocean beyond.. Our park offers a serene escape for nature lovers and those seeking a peaceful retreat. Enjoy spacious caravan and camping sites, cozy cabins, and a range of on-site facilities to make your stay comfortable and enjoyable. Explore the nearby forests, hike to stunning waterfalls, or simply relax and soak up the natural beauty of the region. Karri Aura Tourist Park is your perfect base for exploring the wonders of Pemberton and the South West. Book your stay today and experience the magic of the karri forests.

properties.name: Kalbarri Skywalk
properties.description:
The Kalbarri Skywalk offers breathtaking views of the Murchison River gorge and the spectacular surrounding landscape. You will feel like you are floating on air as you take a thrilling walk out along two cantilevered viewing platforms that hang in mid-air 100m high above the gorge.

While you're there, discover how the gorge formed millions of years ago and learn about the local Nanda Aboriginal people. See how many Australian native animal sculptures you can find and maybe discover a fossil or two at this world class tourism attraction.

Enjoy a brew with a view, or stop in for breakfast, lunch, coffee, cold drinks and more at the Skywalk Cafe, located next to the Kalbarri Skywalk. The Skywalk Cafe's opening hours are seasonal.

properties.name: Wedge Lookout
properties.description:
A picnic spot looking over wedge island. 

It has bins and a picnic table.

7 parking spaces.

properties.name: Buddha's Overnighter
properties.description:
This Shady Camping Area is situated on the outskirts of the national park, about 4 km from Hamersley Gorge. It offers essential amenities, including toilets available at Hamersley Gorge. 

Additionally, a large skip bin is located within the camping area, along Hamersley Gorge Road, and at the Toll truck bay for convenient waste disposal.

properties.name: Pinnacles Sunset Dinner and Stargazing Tour From Perth
properties.description:
Leave behind city life for a one-day treat of some of Western Australia’s best natural wonders. 

Where the river meets the sea, walk the foreshore and witness the vast array of unique birdlife, flocking to the Moore River estuary. Stroll along a boardwalk made of ancient Tamala Limestone and climb the Yoodook Karla Kada Staircase to see where ships, long ago wrecked against the coastline. An important meeting place for local Aboriginal tribes in the area, you’ll learn how native plants were once used for both food and medicine.

Highlights:

- Pinnacles Guided Walk
- Picnic dinner under the stars
- Knowledgable and informative guide
- Small Group Touring
- Visit to the beautiful Yanchep National Park
- Spot wild kangaroos and view koalas

properties.name: Caiguna East Free Camp
properties.description: Great free camp with dozens of massive flat private bush spots to park any and every those of vehicle. Easily accessible off the hiway on Southern side of the Eyre Hiway. Look for the rusted 44 gallon drum at the dirt road this is the entrance. Would recommend for a great quiet place felt safe.

properties.name: Jam Patch campsite
properties.description: Free campsite for self contained vehicles. There’s a loo here plus a few waking trails.

properties.name: Cullen Wines
properties.description:
A tasting experience at Cullen comes with priceless views over the rolling vineyards. Immerse yourself into the biodynamic journey through seated wine experiences, biodynamic dining and a self-guided biodynamic spiral garden tour. Stroll through the garden at your own pace and follow the fascinating biodynamic process that lies in the heart of Cullen. 

Even without the stunning views, Cullen would be a must on any wine lover’s bucket list visiting the region. One of the founding wine producers in the region and going strong for over 50 years, they have won too many prestigious awards to mention.

properties.name: Broome Whale Watching Charters
properties.description:
Get ready for an incredible afternoon with the whales as they migrate their way along the Kimberley Coast past Broome on this whale watching cruise. Relax in comfort on one of the daybeds or stake out your spot on one of the three viewing decks as you venture out to sea. Marine Biologist travel on board with you to provide commentary as you witness nature at its best, right in front of your eyes.

Passengers will have uninterrupted views from the safety and comfort of the vessel, where you get up-close and personal with the largest population of Humpback whales in the world! Join Broome's fastest, purpose-built vessel for marine charters that is set-up for passenger comfort with multiple viewing platforms. The Broome whale watching season runs from July to September and sightings are guaranteed during this time. Book your Broome whale watching tickets here before the season comes to an end.

properties.name: Margaret River Beerfarm
properties.description:
**Welcome to one of the most unique places you will ever have a pint!** 

​​At Beerfarm, we’re committed to reducing our footprint every step of the way. We run an ever-growing array of solar panels across our brewery’s rooftops to minimise our energy use and have a thorough wastewater plan in place to reduce our water consumption during the beer making-process, while managing our waste water post-brew.

Our herd of Black Angus cattle roam the surrounding paddocks and are fed a diet of grass and spent grain from the brewing process, in a circular economy to keep our product as local as possible.

While recycling, up-cycling and composting are our bread and butter, each day we strive to improve our efforts in sustainable practises wherever we can. But our commitment to the future focuses on more than just energy and waste management, it’s also about our people and our community.

[Take a video tour of the Beerfarm here](https://youtu.be/CvazVhHg4ns)

properties.name: Tunnel Creek Walk
properties.description:
At Dimalurru (Tunnel Creek) water has carved a large tunnel through the limestone of the Napier Range. The tunnel is up to 20m high and 15m wide in some parts! 350 million years ago this was part of an ocean reef system.  

There is a Kimberley feel all-around. Sunlight arcs onto the cathedral-like cavern with a sense of mystery. Adding to the spectacle, large stalactite rock formations hang from the walls.  

A deep history, as well as beauty exists here. It was used as a hideout late last century by the Aboriginal leader Jandamarra who was killed outside its entrance in 1897. 

Take a walk through the 750m tunnel which takes you from one side of the Napier Range to the other. Keep your eye out for the many bat species and freshwater crocodiles that live in the cave. The roof has collapsed through to the top of the range near the centre of the tunnel. Take a torch, wear sneakers and be prepared to get wet and possibly cold and always let someone know where you are. 

You’ll never forget a walk into the tunnel of surprises. It's Crocodile Dundee and Indiana Jones all in one spot!

properties.name: Moore's Hut
properties.description: Hidden hut for 4wd enthusiasts, not super family friendly.

properties.name: Burkett rest area
properties.description: Rest area for self contained. No facilities. Good for one rest.

properties.name: Cranbrook Rest Stop
properties.description: Albany hwy/Cranbrook turnoff. Level bitumen parking  area. Vans park one side of toilet bock, trucks on the other side. Facilities include 2 flushing toilets, 1 disabled toilet with baby change room and 2 hot showers. There is also 2 undercover picnic tables, rubbish bins and over head parking bay lights. Room for big rigs.

properties.name: Rooney's Bridge Camp
properties.description: Small clearing next to Warren River. Room for approx 6-8 campervans/trucks. Approx 100m off of the South Western Highway. 4wd accessible only as there are several steps down on the track in. Beware of mozzies. Fires ok. Road noise ok.

properties.name: Blue Holes
properties.description:
Blue Holes Beach is a fish habitat area located just south of Kalbarri, with protected waters and rock pools creating a natural aquarium for marine life and safe area for kids to splash about in.

The section of coast gets its name from an inshore limestone reef system, which creates a mix of permanemently submerged and permanently exposed sections. A myriad of fish, including over 70 species of finfish, and coral can be seen swimmingl through the tranquil waters and crawling along the ocean floor, making it a popular snorkelling location. Spot dart, moon wrasse, raccoon butteryfly fish, humbugs, western rock lobster and other crustaceans such as banded hair shrimp and beds of oysters, along with 10 types of sponge and 11 species of coral.

Walk along the pristine sandy beach and examine rock pools along the shore. Swim in the sheltered waters and laze about on the soft sand. Then settle back after a rewarding investigation of the Blue Holes to see the beautiful Western Australian sunset.

Blue Holes and Kalbarri are approximately 6 hours' drive north of Perth.

There are toilets onsite.

properties.name: 6 Mile Creek
properties.description: Got sent here by caretaker of Turf Club to stay the night. Dirt track, parking right at the beach. Don't go around the bottom without a 4WD

properties.name: Fremantle Prison
properties.description:
Built by convicts in the 1850s and decommissioned as an operating maximum security gaol in 1991, Fremantle Prison is the largest convict-built structure in Australia and the most intact convict establishment in the southern hemisphere. 

It is currently the only World Heritage listed building in Western Australia.

There is no General Admission to Fremantle Prison, visitors must select and book a tour.

properties.name: Marvel Loch Campers Rest
properties.description:
Free camping spot in Marvel loch.

Ablution block and hot showers, with a pub across the street.

properties.name: Cape Leeuwin Lighthouse
properties.description:
A stunning lookout offering panoramic views of the Indian Ocean and the Cape Leeuwin Lighthouse, located on the southwestern tip of mainland Australia. The lighthouse is perched on a clifftop, surrounded by massive rocks and large stones in the sea. 

The water is a brilliant blue, and the lighthouse can be seen from afar, standing tall against the sky.

properties.name: Mary Pool Rest Area
properties.description: This free campground offers toilets and a dump point. It is accessible to 2wd & 4wd. There are clean toilets with flashing water. Lots of shady places. In the morning and afternoon are friendly cows on the campground. Entry to campsite is south of the Mary River. Northern entry is closed.

properties.name: Ocean Drive Car Park (permit required from visitor centre)
properties.description: Free overnight (max 48 hours) rest area for fully self contained vehicles only - need permit from Bunbury Visitor Centre

properties.name: Ullaring Soak
properties.description: Large area with fire pits, shelter, gravel, flat sites suitable for camper trailers, campervans,  caravans. Toilet.

properties.name: Lake Nunijup
properties.description: Beautiful lake camping. Clean flushing toilets. Good flat camping spots with fire pits.

properties.name: Injidup Natural Spa
properties.description:
Injidup Natural Spa takes the humble rock pool to a whole new level. It’s a popular spot to swim both for its natural beauty and the fun phenomenon that occurs when the swell is up. 

On a good day, waves from the Indian Ocean crash into the rock barrier between the pool and the open ocean, creating a waterfall of whitewash that cascades into the pool below. Sit beneath it, and it feels as though you’re in a natural spa. 

While it’s most fun when the waves are crashing, the pool is still a beautiful spot to visit and take a dip when it’s calm too.

properties.name: Twilight Cove
properties.description:
Twilight Cove is a stunning spot with magnificent 70m high cliffs and a broad, sweeping beach where the white sand crunches underfoot. 

At this point on the southern coastline, the Baxter Cliffs turn inland in a north-eastward arc and become the escarpment that separates the Hampton Tablelands from the coastal Roe Plains.

There is great fishing off the beach here as well as a cold shower.

properties.name: Mauritaus Beach
properties.description:
Mauritaus is located within a recreation zone of Ningaloo Marine Park and is suitable for fishing and swimming.

The beach can be accessed via a sandy track from the car park.

During the summer months Mauritius beach is one of the many beaches along the Jurabi Coast used by female marine turtles as a nesting ground. Female turtles can be seen coming ashore from dusk to dawn to lay her eggs. Please follow the Turtle watching code of conduct when visiting turtle nesting beaches.

properties.name: Beacon Lookout
properties.description:
Beacon Lookout is a must-see for any visitor to Tamborine Mountain. Offering stunning panoramic views of the surrounding countryside, including the Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast, and the Hinze Dam, it's the perfect place to take a break from driving and soak up the scenery.

The lookout is also a great place to spot wildlife, with kookaburras, king parrots, and other native birds often seen flying around the area. And if you're feeling adventurous, Beacon Lookout is also a popular spot for hang gliding and paragliding.

properties.name: Galvans Gorge
properties.description:
Galvans Gorge is the most easily accessible gorge along the iconic Gibb River Road in the Kimberley, making it a perfect spot to take a refreshing swim. A short bushwalk leads you past a serene waterway adorned with waterlilies to a welcoming plunge pool, surrounded by granite formations and fed by a waterfall.

Located just 1 kilometer off the Gibb River Road—a 660-kilometer four-wheel-drive track originally established for cattle droving between Wyndham and Derby—this stunning oasis is only reachable during the dry season from May to October. It's conveniently situated between overnight stops at Mount Hart Homestead and Manning Gorge.

This site has drawn visitors for thousands of years, evident in the ancient Wandjina rock art that can be seen on the rock walls near the main pool.

Take a moment to relax on the rocks beneath the waterfall for a refreshing back massage before continuing your journey to your next destination.

properties.name: Cape Peron
properties.description:
Sitting at the confluence of two major currents, Cape Peron attracts an impressive array of marine life with turtles, manta rays, sharks, dugongs, dolphins and schools of fish often seen from its cliffs. However, this location is perhaps best known for its wonderful contrasts of white beaches, red cliffs and blue waters.

Try your hand at fishing here to see what might be lurking offshore. It is a special purpose zone for wildlife observation within the Shark Bay Marine Park because of the prevalence of dolphins and dugongs, so set netting, spearfishing waterskiing and freestyle jet skiing are not permitted.

properties.name: Jingemia Cave
properties.description: Picnic area with toilet close to a 200m walking path that takes you to the Jingemia Cave. Informational panels provide some background on the geology and history of this place.

properties.name: West Beach
properties.description:
West Beach is a scenic beach set in a small bay, with opportunities to explore water-washed rock formations and enjoy fishing or whale watching.

A formed path provides easy access to this delightful beach where the rocks have been sculpted by nature into intriguing shapes. The wave-washed surfaces of these weathered schists show delightful detail in alternating bands of light and dark minerals that include glistening mica and small deep pink garnets.

A lookout with seating on the path is a good vantage point to enjoy the views and spot whales and their newborn young during winter when they may shelter close to shore.

Please keep in mind that in certain conditions waves may wash over the reefs and there could be strong currents present, making the pools potentially unsafe.

properties.name: Nilgen Lookout and Wildflower Walk
properties.description:
A picnic area and lookout located in the Nilgen Nature Reserve.

From the parking area the walk to the lookout is 200m (15 minutes return), along a concrete path. Enjoy sweeping coastal views from Ledge Point in the south to Wedge Island Nature Reserve in the north.

The Nilgen Wildflower Walk is a 600m loop (30 minutes return) on which you can discover a variety of wildflowers that bloom in this banksia woodland and coastal heath.

Pets are not permitted.

No camping or overnight parking.

properties.name: Yanchep Crystal Cave
properties.description:
Crystal Cave in Yanchep National Park is an underground wonderland full of natural cave decorations such as stalactites, stalagmites, helictites, flowstones, columns and shawls. 

Join a 45 minute guided tour to experience Perth's only metropolitan tourist cave. 

Tours of the cave take place every day of the year.

properties.name: The Koala Boardwalk
properties.description:
Yanchep National Park  has been home to a colony of koala's since 1938.
