There are 5 koalas (as of 2024) Miffy, a seven-year-old female, Louie and Franklin Doogsie, 18-month-old brothers, 19-year-old Kate and 14-year-old Koodah.

There's a raised boardwalk where you can see them lazing among the branches of the trees and learn more about these fascinating creatures.

The 3.15pm daily koala talk has been suspended until further notice but you can come and see the koalas between 8am and 4.30pm every day.

properties.name: Woody Island Nature Reserve
properties.description:
Woody Island Nature Reserve off the coast of Esperance is just the spot for nature lovers.

Surrounded by pristine bushland and ocean, there’s plenty of time for bushwalking, hiking, swimming, snorkelling and fishing.

Woody Island is part of the 100 islands that make up the Recherche Archipelago or Bay of Isles, as locals know it. It’s the only island that is open to the public from a cruise/charter. All sorts of marine life thrive in the waters surrounding Woody Island including fur seals, sea lions and dolphins.

On land, you might see marsupials like bandicoots and wallabies as well as a range of birds, including rare sea eagles.

To learn more about the local wildlife, visit the interpretive centre on the island. There’s a swimming platform and an underwater snorkel trail – or you can just relax and soak up the tranquillity.

properties.name: Tin Horse Highway
properties.description:
Drive along the Tin Horse Highway and check out the quirky collection of tin horses lining the road out to the Jilakin Race Track. 

The Kulin locals have strategically placed their tin horse masterpieces in the paddocks lining the 12 kilometre stretch of road which is known as The Tin Horse Highway.

properties.name: The Loop and Z Bend
properties.description:
The Loop and Z Bend are sections of the Murchison River aptly named because of the enormous loops and Z bend they have created as they flow through the gorges. 

Located in the spectacular Kalbarri National Park you will be spellbound by the view from the lookouts at the top of the gorge.

properties.name: The Gap and Natural Bridge
properties.description:
Lookouts at both the Gap and Natural Bridge provide outstanding views of the Southern Ocean and the coast from Bald Head to West Cape Howe.

Visitors to the Gap can venture onto a universally accessible new viewing platform 40 metres directly above the surging seas in all but the worst weather conditions.

properties.name: The Basin
properties.description:
This unique swimming spot is a favourite with holidaymakers and each year friendships are made and renewed on the white, sandy beach at The Basin.

Just follow the signposts out of the settlement past the tennis courts to this aptly named pool. It seems to have been scooped out of the reef, its clear turquoise water reflecting the white, sandy bottom.

Surely one of life's true delights is to lie on the soft sand at The Basin, under a cloudless blue sky, watching the carefree swimmers in the foreground and just beyond in the Indian Ocean, a procession of pleasure-seeking yachts and launches.

properties.name: Swan Valley Food and Wine Drive Trail
properties.description:
The award winning Swan Valley Food and Wine Trail is a 32 kilometre scenic loop drive in the heart of the Swan Valley, 25 minutes from Perth. 

Starting at the visitor centre in Guildford, this Top Trail takes in more than 150 wineries, lively breweries, fine restaurants, bustling cafes, distilleries, shops and more.

properties.name: Summit Trail Mount Augustus
properties.description:
The very challenging 12 kilometre return Summit Trail takes walkers to the top of Mount Augustus, 852 kilometres north of Perth. 

Mount Augustus is the largest monolith on earth, 2.5 times larger than Uluru!

This Top Trail is twice as high as Uluru (Ayres Rock), allowing the experienced walker to be rewarded with extensive views over the surrounding plain to the distant ranges.

properties.name: Scarborough Beach
properties.description:
For teens and surfers, Scarborough Beach is a firm favourite.

The regular swell, impressive surf breaks and long stretch of white sand attract swimmers, surfers, body-boarders. Scarborough Beach is also popular for kite surfing and wind surfing, especially when the afternoon sea breeze is in.

properties.name: Reddell Beach
properties.description:
Reddell Beach is a favourite beach amongst the Broome locals, with the stark contrasts of red pindan bordering the white sandy beach. Examine the unusual rock formations with their intricate erosion patterns along the pristine stretch of beach. 

The calm refreshing waters are ideal for swimming or paddling, while you can also looking for dinosaur footprints in the rock!

properties.name: Pentecost River Crossing
properties.description:
The Pentecost River in the East Kimberley region is famed as one of the best spots in the area to go barramundi fishing.

The epic four wheel drive track, the Gibb River Road, crosses over the Pentecost River and this crossing is the ideal place to throw in a fishing line.

properties.name: Mount Matilda Walk
properties.description: Mount Matilda near Wongan Hills offers a spectacular interpretive flora walk to its peak. Choose between the two hour Mount Matilda Walk suitable for all levels of fitness or the more challenging three hour loop, which covers a distance of seven kilometres.

properties.name: Mount Barker Lookout
properties.description: For panoramic views of the Great Southern region, the Mount Barker Lookout is a must-visit. The lookout offers sweeping vistas of rolling hills, vineyards, and farmland, making it a perfect spot for capturing the essence of rural Australia.

properties.name: Mount Augustus
properties.description:
The world's largest monolith, Mount Augustus, is twice the size of Uluru. It's an awesome sight, whether you're gazing up at the 860-metre high summit from its 49-kilometre scenic base trail (four wheel drive only) or snapping shots from the Emu Hill Lookout. 

At sunrise and sunset the colours change from cool greens to vibrant reds and orange's.

properties.name: Moochalabra Dam Rock Art
properties.description:
Moochalabra Dam, near Wyndham, is a lovely spot for a picnic under the huge Boab tree. It is a great base from which to explore the nearby Aboriginal cave paintings or to watch the local wildlife.

Moochalabra Creek crossing appears just before the dam turn-off where you will see lush green growth shaded by large trees.

properties.name: Marrinup Mountain Bike Trail
properties.description:
he Marrinup Trail meanders through some of Australia's oldest rocks, which are more often exposed on this part of the Darling Scarp near Dwellingup, south of Perth. The mountain bike trail passes through native jarrah forest and redgum. The interesting 'Cage in the bush' Prisoner of War (POW) camp is located a short distance from the trail.

Proceeding clockwise, this easy to follow loop trail starts at the old Marrinup town site which was destroyed by bush fire in 1961. The 7.9 kilometre Top Trail has a single track suitable for both the novice and experienced rider. The trail can be shortened to about four kilometres by using the short course return route. It varies from narrow, challenging tracks with flat sections and hill climbs to true gravel roads, with the ball bearing like bauxite gravel making things pretty interesting for mountain biking.

properties.name: Lake Grace Lookout
properties.description: Lake Grace Lookout provides a spectacular panoramic view of the vast lake system of Lake Grace. Climb to the top of the lookout to take advantage of the views across this fascinating salt lake which stretches 50 kilometres in length and is seven kilometres wide.

properties.name: Kings Park Botanic Garden Walks
properties.description:
Within the 17 hectare Kings Park Botanic Garden you can explore the extraordinary biodiversity of every region of Western Australia. Follow one of two walk trails and you'll encounter more than 3,000 flowering plant species, from the 750-year-old boab tree to delicate everlastings.

The park lies 1.5 kilometres from Perth central business district, overlooking the Swan River and iconic cityscape. A seven-minute bus ride, ten-minute drive, or 25-minute walk will get you to the start of the trail, at the end of Fraser Avenue. Make the Visitor Information Centre your first stop to pick up a park map.

The most popular walk through the Botanic Garden is the Lotterywest Federation Walkway, taking you up into the treetops for one of the best panoramas of the river and city. Allow 40 minutes return.

If you have more time to explore, follow the Lotterywest Federation Walkway to the tranquil Water Garden and Pioneer Women's Memorial Fountain. Allow at least an hour to complete the loop trail.

properties.name: Jurien Bay Sea Lion Safari
properties.description:
To see inquisitive wild sea lions, head to Jurien Bay, about a three-hour drive north of Perth. Take a sea lion watching cruise and you'll find these graceful swimmers love to show off in front of the camera.

The Australian sea lion is the world's rarest species, with a population of less than 12,000. Jurien Bay is one of the best places to see these amazing creatures in their natural habitat.

properties.name: Jurabi Turtle Centre
properties.description:
A guided turtle viewing experience at Jurabi Turtle Centre is the best way to see some of the world's most threatened species of marine turtle, as they make their nests on the white-sand beaches of World Heritage listed Ningaloo Reef. 

Jurabi Turtle Centre is open year round. Take a walk through the displays and discover more about the marine turtles found along the Ningaloo Coast. Learn about their lifecycle, the threats they face and how to view mating and nesting turtles and turtle hatchlings in the natural environment.

From December through to early March join a guided Turtle Eco-Education tour and scout for female turtles making their way on to the beach to lay their eggs. Towards the end of the season you may even be lucky enough to encounter turtle hatchlings as they emerge from their nest, making their way to the ocean to start their long journey to adulthood.

Guided Turtle Eco-Education tours increase the chance of finding and observing nesting female turtles in the natural environment. Viewing nesting female turtles and hatchlings with a guide minimises your chance of disturbing them which will increase the chance of female turtles successfully laying eggs.

properties.name: Jakes Point
properties.description:
Kalbarri is home to the iconic left-hander called Jakes Point, recognised as a National Surfing Reserve and one of the state's most famous remote surfing breaks. 

Jakes breaks from two foot and up and best ridden by experienced surfers.

properties.name: Ivanhoe Crossing
properties.description:
This concrete causeway was built over the mighty Ord River and remains in flow year round. The crossing is a great place to cast a line in search of the elusive barramundi, or to enjoy sunset across the river.
Depending on road openings, it may be possible to drive over the crossing, however it is important to bear in mind that the crossing itself is wide, and the current from the river very strong. 

Estuarine crocodiles can be seen at Ivanhoe Crossing, so the area is not safe for swimming. Please pay attention to the safety signage at the crossing itself.

properties.name: Fern Pool
properties.description:
Fern Pool is one of the most accessible and picturesque swimming spots in Mother Nature’s ultimate adventure park – Karijini National Park. 

These cooling waters are fed by a natural spring and framed on all sides by lush green ferns, with a cascading waterfall completing the serenely beautiful setting.

properties.name: Elizabeth Quay
properties.description: Celebrating Perth’s love affair with the Swan River, Elizabeth Quay is transforming the foreshore into a free playground for all ages to enjoy the city’s active lifestyle, abundant sunshine, amazing views, alfresco dining, outdoor markets and lively festival scene.

properties.name: Elephant Rocks
properties.description: Visit the massive rounded boulders of Elephant Rocks near picture perfect Greens Pool in Denmark. These granite domes resemble elephants set off the shallow waters only a short walk from Greens Pool. It’s the perfect place for that holiday photograph.

properties.name: Monkey Mia Conservation Park
properties.description:
The Dolphins of Monkey Mia in the Monkey Mia Conservation Park, Shark Bay World Heritage area are famous for their almost daily ritual of swimming to shore to interact with people.

As many as five wild bottlenose dolphins regularly visit the beach, usually in the morning, moving up and down the shoreline within arms reach of the crowd, making for a unique wildlife experience.

properties.name: Dales Gorge and Circular Pool
properties.description:
Go bushwalking at Dales Gorge and Circular Pool - two of the best spots for a picnic at Karijini National Park in Western Australia’s north-west.

Two billion years in the making, Karijini National Park is one of the country’s most spectacular natural attractions offering amazing hiking trails through ancient gorges.

properties.name: Coral Bay Walk Way
properties.description:
The Coral Bay Walk Way is a stunning walk fringing the coastline along Ningaloo Reef. 

As a result of the reef's closeness to the shore, you have a unique opportunity to witness dolphins, manta rays and a large range of fish swimming through the crystal clear waters from a number of vantage points along the shore.

properties.name: Cockburn Range
properties.description:
See the majestic orange cliffs of Cockburn Range in the Kimberley on a four wheel driving trip along the Gibb River Road, between the Great Northern Highway and the Pentecost River.

Imposing and spectacular views are also on offer from the highway into Wyndham.

The Cockburn Range is shaped like a vast round fortress and rises more than 600 metres above the plains.

From a distance, there’s no hint of the deep gorges and permanent pools which lie hidden within.

Cockburn Range sits entirely on land owned by El Questro Wilderness Park. El Questro offers trips to the range or there are other private bushwalking tours available. A scenic flight affords another amazing view.

Cockburn Range is about a 1 hour drive from Kununurra in the Kimberley.

properties.name: Cathedral Gorge Walk
properties.description: The moderate four kilometre return Cathedral Gorge walk trail is located in Cathedral Gorge, an astonishing geological formation with amazing acoustics, located within the ranges of Purnululu National Park or the Bungle Bungle Ranges.

properties.name: Cape Leveque
properties.description:
Hit the red dirt road for a four wheel drive adventure to remote Cape Leveque on the tip of the Dampier Peninsula north of Broome. 

This rugged and pristine slice of the Kimberley is famous for its Aboriginal heritage which continues to thrive.  

Lying at the end of Dampier Peninsula about 200kms north of Broome, the remote iconic Cape Leveque makes for a refreshing alternative to the Kimberley’s more visited coastal destinations. It resides at the head of this famous peninsula and is best known for its bright red sandstone cliffs and its pure waters. 

You can snorkel the azure waters or jump aboard the glass-bottom boat for a look at the brightly coloured fishes. July to October time even has humpback whales prowling the waters.

The Aboriginal heritage of Cape Leveque dates back some 7,000 years and they still reside here, many working in the tourist trade, operating guided walks and running the eco resort. The best way to appreciate the area is by taking a bush tucker tour with an Aboriginal guide. They teach you how to make a spear for fishing, after which you get to barbecue your catch.

properties.name: Bunker Bay
properties.description:
Sheltered and pristine, Bunker Bay entices with pure white sand and gentle lapping waves perfect for swimming, snorkelling and fishing.

Located within the famous Margaret River Wine Region, the bay is protected by the rocky outcrops of Cape Naturaliste and is one of the few north-facing beaches in Western Australia.

It is ideal for families wanting a relaxing day at the beach, as well as divers and snorkelers who enjoy amazing marine life just offshore.

The fishing is also good - throw in a line and you might snare a herring, whiting or skippy.

Nearby are world class surf breaks, including The Farm, while just a short drive away you're surrounded by award winning wineries, restaurants, craft stores and galleries.

properties.name: Boranup Karri Forest
properties.description:
For a scenic drive through towering timber forests, visit Boranup Karri Forest, located just south of Margaret River.

Part of the Leeuwin-Naturaliste National Park, this area is famous for its vibrant wildflowers that blanket the forest floor in spring. Boranup Karri Forest is notable for being the westernmost region where the tall, pale-barked karri trees thrive, with some reaching heights of over 60 meters and covering the hilly landscapes.

The picturesque drive through the forest is accessible for conventional vehicles, allowing you to marvel at the enormous trees lining the road. A brief walk leads to Boranup Lookout, offering sweeping views of the forest and coastline. There are several picnic and barbecue spots available, along with a campground at the southern end of Boranup Drive.

You can easily access Boranup Forest from Caves Road, just a short drive south of Margaret River.

properties.name: Bluff Knoll - Stirling Range Lookout
properties.description:
Located in the Stirling Range National Park, Bluff Knoll is the highest and one of the most spectacular peaks in south Western Australia. 

Requiring some fitness, the moderate five kilometre return hike is a picturesque two hour journey to the panoramic views from the bluff before the one hour descent to the base.

The Stirling Ranges offers rugged mountain terrain and sweeping views that are perfect for dramatic Instagram shots. Of all the places to visit, Bluff Knoll is arguably the most iconic. 

This 6.8km return, Grade 4 trail is well signed and takes you to the top of Bluff Knoll1,095 meters, it offers sweeping views of the surrounding mountain range and the vast landscape below.

properties.name: Blowholes and Point Quobba
properties.description: Located just 75 kilometres north of Carnarvon along a bitumen road, this natural phenomenon is an awe inspiring sight to see. Powerful ocean swells force water through sea caves and up out of narrow holes in the rocks, jets of water erupt into the air, sometimes to a height of 20 metres, creating a spectacular sight.

properties.name: Bell Gorge
properties.description:
Beautiful Bell Gorge, with its stunning waterfall, bushwalking and bird watching, lies within the Kimberley's rugged King Leopold Range Conservation Park.

During the wet season great volumes of water cascade down the waterfall, making it the perfect place for a refreshing swim.

Make sure you bring your camera!

properties.name: Woottating Parking Area
properties.description: Just bush. Only SC and 4WD

properties.name: Temple Gorge Campground
properties.description:
Venture inland from Carnarvon and step into Western Australia's rugged outback. Welcome to the Kennedy Range, a dramatic landscape shaped by ancient forces.

This vast sandstone plateau stretches between 12 and 25 km wide and 75 km long, rising 80 meters above the surrounding red earth plains. The range’s geology tells a fascinating story, with rocks formed beneath an ancient sea. Keep an eye out for marine fossils embedded in the exposed rock.

The plateau’s red sand dunes, shaped 20,000 years ago, are now covered with shrubland and spinifex grass. On the western side, spring-fed oases provide vital water for wildlife, especially in droughts, and hold cultural significance for the area’s traditional owners.

The best way to explore this stunning landscape is on foot. Several trails lead you through the park’s dramatic gorges, but be sure to check safety advice before setting out in this remote region.

Spring is an ideal time to visit, when wildflowers like everlastings bloom, creating a striking contrast against the red earth. For stargazers, camping at Temple Gorge Campground offers breathtaking views of the night sky, where the vastness of the plateau seems small next to the infinite stars above.

properties.name: Wydgee Rest Area
properties.description: Exposed large drive-through rest area located directly by the highway. There are no facilities or shade.

properties.name: Woorlba Homestead Rest Area
properties.description: Exposed large drive-through rest area located directly by the highway. There are long drop toilets, picnic tables and a dump point, but not much shade.

properties.name: Wagerup Rest Area
properties.description: This long drive-through overnight rest area with no other amenities than a BBQ, is separated from the highway by a wall of trees. Suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Sawtooth Gorge (Sawpit Gorge)
properties.description: This is a very scenic remote campground with no facilities located by the Black Elvire River. It is accessible by 4WD only, via a 4km dirt track, just off the main road. Not suitable for big vehicles with 72hrs max stay limit.

properties.name: James Price Point Free Camping Area
properties.description: This beautiful camping area with no amenities is located right at the beach, close to Manari Road. It offers scenic views, fishing and swimming. 4WD recommended with maximum stay of 72hrs.

properties.name: Pinjarra Information Centre
properties.description: This spacious overnight rest area with no amenities, except for a dump point and a picnic table, is located close to the main road and the river in Pinjarra town. Suitable for big rigs with maximum stay of 24hrs. There are shops, cafes, restaurants, museums and parks nearby.

properties.name: Olwolgin Bluff Rest Area
properties.description: Decent size gravel drive-through bay located directly by the highway. No facilities and limited shade.

properties.name: North Bannister Rest Area
properties.description: A roadside rest area located just off the highway. It is well sheltered from the traffic noise by lush trees. You can drive even further into the bush for some extra privacy. There are no facilities.

properties.name: Najada Rockhole Rest Area
properties.description: This unsealed rest area is separated from the highway by bushes and has basic amenities, incl. rubbish bins and picnic tables. There is some shade, too.

properties.name: Munrillup Rest Area
properties.description: This large and gravel drive-through rest area with basic amenities is separated from the highway by a wall of trees to limit the noise. There is a dirt area behind, which is suitable for camper trailers.

properties.name: Muluks Rest Area
properties.description: This rest area with basic amenities is located off the highway, on the bank of the creek. It offers scenic views and is easily accessible by all vehicles.

properties.name: Mt Pleasant Rest Area
properties.description: This large drive-through overnight rest area with bitumen surface is located well off the highway and has no amenities, except for rubbish bins. There is a good shade, phone signal and it's quiet. 24hrs maximum stay.

properties.name: Mount Gibson Rest Area
properties.description: Long and exposed sealed drive-through rest area with toilet facilities and picnic tables. It is separated from the highway by a string of trees, which limits the traffic noise. There is not much shade or privacy and the site is frequented by trucks.

properties.name: Moorine Rock Hotel Motel
properties.description: This pleasant hotel offers accommodation. You can  enjoy delicious meals and drinks prepared by the pub's kitchen while staying here.

properties.name: McDermid Rock Rest Area
properties.description: This campsite is situated 1.5km off the highway, via a dirt track. It is large and secluded with basic amenities. The main attractions here are McDermid Rock Wall Trail, bush walks and bird watching. There is limited shade and it's not suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Leycesters Rest Area
properties.description: This large rest area with basic amenities and circular layout is located by the river, close to the highway. It has a bitumen surface, a limited shade and it's suitable for big rigs. 24hrs maximum stay applies.

properties.name: Lennonville Rest Area
properties.description: This basic and secluded waterside rest area with no facilities is located 1km off the highway and is very spacious, with plenty of space to park your van. There is a very limited shade and it is suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Koorda Native Flora Reserve
properties.description: This scenic rest area with good amenities is located off the road, approx. 15km from town. It offers spectacular views, a variety of wildflowers and a few walking tracks.

properties.name: Israelite Bay
properties.description: This is a beachside camping area with no facilities, accessible only by 4WD. The surrounding is very scenic, with many lakes, dunes, woodlands and rugged coastline. Fishing and swimming are permitted and the area offers access to historical sites, pleasant treks and spectacular views.

properties.name: Herbert Parker Rest Area
properties.description: This is a riverside overnight rest area with scenic views located just off the highway. It has no facilities other than a rubbish bin and is easily accessible by all vehicles. There is enough space for several campers, but not much shade.

properties.name: Greenhills Inn Bar and Cafe
properties.description: This campground is located beside the hotel in a parking area and has basic amenities and plenty of shade. The hotel's bar offers a big choice of meals and drinks. Only for self-contained caravans and motorhomes.

properties.name: Barrabup Rest Area
properties.description: St Johns Brook Conservation Park provides sites for vehicle based camping and campervans. Facilities include pit toilets, fire rings and picnic tables. Campfires are permitted with restrictions. Generators are not allowed. Advanced bookings cannot be made.

properties.name: Dundas Rocks Rest Area
properties.description: Quiet unsealed rest area, located in the bush, approx. 2km east from the highway. It offers scenic views and a shade, but no facilities, except for rubbish bins and a few picnic tables. Not suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Culver Repeater Station Rest Area
properties.description: This camping area, located next to the repeater station, is suitable for all vehicles, including big rigs. It has no amenities, but there is strong mobile phone signal. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Buldania Rocks Rest Area
properties.description: This rest area is accessible via a narrow and slightly overgrown dirt-track, just off the main road. It is a large level clearing in a bush. No facilities are available here.

properties.name: Afghan Rock Rest Area
properties.description: Very large rest area located by the highway, yet quite secluded and private due to many trees and its circular layout. 24hrs limit. No facilities.

properties.name: Roebucks Plains South Parking Area
properties.description: Just a parking area on the side of the highway. You are able to hear every noise from the highway. There is nothing but a few bins provided. You camp on the side of the sandy dirt road and the parking area is surrounded hey bush and trees.

properties.name: Albert Tognolini Rest Area
properties.description: This is a parking area 179 km NW of Newman or 17 km S of Auski Roadhouse. It is a large parking area at the top of a hill that provides a scenic lookout over the gorges. The road is sealed but parking areas are dirt and grass. There are rubbish bins but no other facilities. There is some shade from small trees but it is mostly open. It is far from the road but some road noise is heard because it is higher than the road. It is a scenic and secluded area. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: 25 Mile Well Rest Area
properties.description: This is a camping area 41 km N of Meekatharra and 215 km S of Kumarina Roadhouse. There is a medium dirt pullover on the highway. Adjacent to this is a large dirt area in the bush with tracks leading to camp sites. There are open areas and some areas surrounded by bush. There are rubbish bins but no other facilities. There is little shade and road noise is heard. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Garden Rock Camping
properties.description: This is a camping spot 16 km SE from Cue. There is a long dirt road that is in good condition when dry but maybe only be 4WD accessible when wet. The rocks are signposted with a small sign at the GPS location. Follow the track 200 meters to the rock. There are no facilities here, just some man-made fire rings. Better suitable for smaller vehicles but it is possible to access with a longer vehicle, turnarounds may be difficult. There is little shade. It is very quiet and secluded.

properties.name: Mount Gibson Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Main Roads Western Australia 24 hour stopping area at Mount Gibson. There is a large bitumen pullover suitable for trucks and larger vehicles. Adjacent is a dirt parking area with a toilet, dump station, picnic area, and rubbish bins. There is some shade. It is right on the road so it is not secluded and it is noisy. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: White Wells Rest Area
properties.description: This is a parking area 47 km NE of Wubin or 107 km SW of Payne's Find. It is a typical highway pullover with a dirt surface and trees and bush dotting the landscape. There are historic white wells in the middle of the area. There are picnic tables, rubbish bins, and fire rings but no other facilities. There is some shade. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Buntine Rocks Camping
properties.description: This is a camping spot 18 km NW of Wubin or 25 km SE of Latham. It is a large grass and dirt area with a bumpy dirt access track (2wd OK). There is a rubbish bin and fire ring but no other facilities. It has a nice view over the surrounding farmland. There is some shady trees and open areas. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Moora RV Short Stay Area
properties.description:
This is a parking area in the town of Moora for Self-Contained Vehicles. Maximum stay: 24 hours. 

It is a medium sized sealed parking area with rubbish bins and a dump station. 

It is not secluded or quiet as it is in a small town but at night noise dies down. 

All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Nuytsland Nature Reserve Camping
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area. Two dirt tracks south side of highway lead to a gravel pit and numerous branching tracks that lead to bush camp sites and clearings. There are no facilities. Most sites are open and exposed, there is no shade. There are sites that are further from the road than the typical rest area. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Natural Bridge Lookout
properties.description:
Sightseeing stop in Kalbarri National Park. Turnoff Highway on Sealed road leads to carpark. A Short 5 minute walk leads to Natural Bridge Lookout. 

Take Care on unstable cliffs.

properties.name: The Blowholes - Torndirrup National Park
properties.description: The Blowholes in Torndirrup National Park, located near Albany in Western Australia, are a captivating natural spectacle. These geological formations are created when powerful ocean swells rush into underwater caverns and then forcefully surge out, producing impressive plumes of seawater that resemble "blowholes." The Blowholes are especially mesmerizing during periods of rough seas and high tides, creating dramatic sprays and sounds akin to the earth's breath. Visitors to Torndirrup National Park can witness this awe-inspiring phenomenon while enjoying the rugged coastal scenery and exploring the park's other natural wonders.

properties.name: Canal Rocks
properties.description:
The beautiful granite outcrop that makes up Canal Rocks is part of the rugged Leeuwin-Naturaliste National Park known for its excellent fishing and scenic bushwalking. 

A series of rocks jut into the ocean creating a natural canal hollowed out by the force of the sea.

properties.name: Sugarloaf Rock
properties.description:
Sugarloaf Rock is one of the region’s most spectacular coastal landforms and unique environments. It is no wonder that it is one of the hallmark images of Australian Landscape Photographer of the Year, Christian Fletcher and it has graced the cover of the Australian Geographic magazine. 

With its ever-changing colour, it is difficult to decide when it’s best to see it. Perhaps it is when the weather is stormy with crashing seas, perhaps it is when it is calm and sunny and the water is crystal clear. 

Perhaps the greatest sight is when the sun sets over the Indian Ocean and the colour of the rock changes every minute. If you wait long enough at sunset, you can even see the working Cape Naturaliste Lighthouse light up!

properties.name: Mettams Pool
properties.description:
It is less than two metres deep inside this naturally formed lagoon. A good range of fish species resides within the pool, particularly in the holes and crevices in the southern section. They include red-lip morwong, banded sweep, bullseyes, wrasse, schools of buffalo bream, sea mullet, tarwine and blowfish. Sand whiting and Australian herring can be seen in the open water.

You may also notice a few anemones growing within the pool, while cushion stars, abalone and other shellfish species hide in the rocky reef top. While the snorkelling inside the lagoon is easy, the surge can be strong on the outer edge of the reef. Beware of cobblers in the weed near the shore.

properties.name: Lake Argyle Lookout
properties.description: Enjoy stunning panoramic views of Lake Argyle, the second-largest man-made freshwater lake in the Southern Hemisphere, from Lake Argyle Lookout. The lookout is easily accessible by car and offers a great place to relax and enjoy the beauty of the Kimberley region.

properties.name: Twilight Beach
properties.description:
Twilight Beach is a stunning destination located near Esperance, Western Australia, known for its crystal-clear waters and soft, white sands. This picturesque beach is perfect for swimming, sunbathing, and enjoying a range of water activities. The vibrant turquoise waters are ideal for snorkeling and exploring the underwater world, while the gentle waves make it a great spot for families.

The beach is surrounded by scenic coastal landscapes, with rocky outcrops and dunes adding to its charm. Take a leisurely stroll along the shoreline, or relax under the shade of a tree while soaking in the stunning views.

Twilight Beach is also famous for its breathtaking sunsets, where the sky transforms into a canvas of vibrant colors. It's a perfect spot for evening picnics or simply unwinding as the day comes to an end.

Conveniently located just a short drive from Esperance, Twilight Beach offers facilities such as picnic areas, restrooms, and parking, making it an ideal destination for a day trip or a longer stay. Whether you’re looking for adventure or relaxation, Twilight Beach is a must-visit gem on the Western Australian coast.

properties.name: Bandy Creek Harbour
properties.description:
Located just outside Esperance, Bandy Creek Harbour offers a picturesque marina with crystal-clear waters and dramatic coastal views. The harbour's boats, beaches, and surrounding landscape make for a serene and photogenic scene.

There is a toilet onsite, but overnight stays are not permitted at this location.

properties.name: Yanchep Lagoon
properties.description:
Yanchep Lagoon is an extremely popular swimming and snorkelling spot and well worth a visit. It boasts calm, crystal clear water, with waves averaging just over 1 metre along the beach. The safest swimming spots are the southern lagoon beach and the south end of the main lagoon.

Cast a line or grab your snorkel and experience the beautiful Yanchep Lagoon. Beach fishing is a popular activity at Yanchep Lagoon and Yanchep Beach to the north. During the permissible and license season, abalone fishing is also a popular activity for locals and visitors to Yanchep Lagoon and Fisherman’s Hollow to the south. 

When abalone fishing, ensure you know catch limits, wear appropriate clothing, check the conditions on the day and swim with a friend. Although Yanchep Lagoon may appear safe, be aware of strong currents and waves washing over the reef when collecting abalone.

Please note that swimmers should swim between the flags and be cautious of the strong current which flows out of the lagoon into deeper water. If you are caught in a rip, stay calm, raise your hand and await rescue. Fishing is not permitted between the red and yellow flags and spearfishing is prohibited at all times.

properties.name: Dardanup Hall Car Park
properties.description:
For a quick, no-fuss overnight stay, the Dardanup Hall Car Park is a convenient spot. It's a charming country town with easy access to local attractions and services.

There are only 3 designated parking spaces available.

Complimentary short-term parking for caravans and motorhomes (tents are not permitted). 

Maximum stay is 24 hours.

Public toilets and drinking water are available.

Note: Toilets may occasionally be locked due to maintenance, so it’s advisable to bring your own if needed.

Please ensure you take all rubbish with you and leave the area clean to help maintain this facility for others.

properties.name: Lesmurdie Falls
properties.description:
Lesmurdie Falls located in the Lesmurdie Falls National Park in the hills east of Perth, are one of the more spectacular waterfalls on the Darling Range escarpment.

Commencing at the top, this moderate two kilometre walk circuit meanders down to the base of the falls, up close to the lush vegetation.

properties.name: Dongara Town Oval
properties.description: This is a parking area at Dongara. Entry via Waldeck St. Self Contained Vehciles only. It is in the middle of town and the parking area is a grass field. Two hour limit on generators and must be shut off by 10 PM. No hanging of washing. It is in a large area and is suitable for many vehicles. All types of vehicles can access this area. There is little shade. Maximum stay: 24 Hours

properties.name: Kumarl Siding Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area 73 km S of Norseman or 24 km N of Salmon Gums. It is a large gravel area with many dirt tracks leading into secluded and shady bush sites. There are also trees and bush in the gravel that provide shade. There are fire pits, rubbish bins, and picnic tables here. All types of vehicles can access this area. It is near the road, so there is road noise, but some of the tracks into the bush will be quieter. Maximum stay:  24 Hours

properties.name: Sherlock River
properties.description: This campground is not signposted. The GPS location is set on the turnoff from the highway, so watch it carefully. You camp next to the river, but can't really get to it as there's a barbed wire fence around the camp area. The camp area is not very big, and you can hear noises from the highway as it's just next to it.

properties.name: Beringbooding Rock
properties.description: Located slightly off the beaten track, this site offers overnight stays with basic facilities, as well as photogenic views.

properties.name: Harms Lake Parking
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway rest area. There is a long bitumen pullover that leads to a small open dirt area with some trees and bush. There are rubbish bins but no other facilities. There aren't any bush camp sites here - you can park on the dirt shoulder of the pullover in view of the road and rest area. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Peawah Rest Area
properties.description: Rest area quite close to the highway. There are toilets, a dumpstation, a information board, several bins and a sheltered picnic area provided. You can camp on the side of the gravel road or on red dirt. At the back of the rest area are some trees for shade. The rest area is surrounded by bush and trees.

properties.name: Meridian Rest Area
properties.description:
No camping NOV - FEB

This is a rest area 4 km W of Ravensthorpe or 109 km E of Jerramungup. It is a Liona™s Project rest area because this area crosses the 120 Degrees East meridian. There is a large rock and sign giving information about the meridian line. 

There are picnic tables and rubbish bins. The rest area is a medium sized dirt surfaced bush camp. There is an open dirt pullover with some smaller spots that pull into secluded bush sites. It is near the road so there is some road noise, but overall it is a quiet site. All types of vehicles can access this area. No Fires.

No camping NOV - FEB

properties.name: Woorlba East Rest Area
properties.description: This is a parking bay on the Eyre Highway. A dirt pullover leads to some rubbish bins but no other facilities. There is no bush or trees separating the road from the area. It is loud and not peaceful. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Thomson Brook Wines Parking
properties.description: Self-contained vehicles can stay on the Thompson-Brook Wines property for a maximum of 96 hours. Check in at the Cellar door on arrival. Purchase of wines may apply. The area is a large grass field adjacent to the winery. The dirt road to the winery is corrugated but is passable by any type of vehicle. No facilities are available. There isnâ€™t any shade. The area is quiet and peaceful and there is no road noise. Large vehicles take care entering and exiting.

properties.name: Koorarawalyee Rest Area Boorabbin
properties.description:
This is a Main Roads Western Australia 24 hour stopping area on the western end of Boorabbin National Park. It is a a dirt and gravel level area with bush and trees throughout the camp. 

There is a toilet, dump station, picnic tables, fire pits, and rubbish bins. 

All types of vehicles can access this area. There is some road noise since it is adjacent to the highway.

properties.name: Boondi Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area at Boondi. It is a dirt pullover next to the highway that is accessible to all types of vehicles. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables but no other facilities. There is some, but limited shade. There are some bush camping sites and some open sites. It is loud and next to the road.

properties.name: Mt Thirsty Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical highway rest area. It is a medium sized dirt-surfaced area with tracks leading into the bush (some of the tracks are bumpy). There are rubbish bins and fire pits. It is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. All types of vehicles can access this area. Because it is next to the highway, it is noisy.

properties.name: Cockburn Rest Area
properties.description: Free camp site for both self contained and non self-contained vehicles, just on the side of the main street . There are picnic tables and clean toilets on site. During high season it is very busy. Good view all around but a lot of road noise.

properties.name: Kookynie Well Rest Area
properties.description: Decent size drive-through bay located directly by the highway. No facilities and limited shade.

properties.name: Ravensthorpe East Rest Area
properties.description: Parking Area 5 km E of Ravensthorpe. This is a typical highway rest area with a level dirt surface. There are trees providing shade and some bush separating the area from the highway. There are picnic tables and rubbish bins. No Fires. This area is close to the highway so road noise is present. Any vehicle can access this area.

properties.name: Jilakin Rock Picnic Area
properties.description: This is a large flat parking area 17 km E of Kulin. Turn N 14 km E of Kulin onto Jilakin Rock Rd North. There are no facilities here. It is a large dirt and gravel clearning with some bush surrounding. Any vehicle can access this area. It is quiet at night with the occasional vehicle passing creating some road noise.

properties.name: Tenindewa Pioneer Well
properties.description: This flat and open site is located some 2km further from the siding and offers flat and open camping ground with no facilities. There are plenty of walks available here, with the most popular one being a stone footway across a salt pan. The surroundings are very scenic and serene at this site.

properties.name: Victoria Rock - Goldfields Woodlands National Park
properties.description: This scenic campground with basic facilities is located by the rock and offers scenic views, walking tracks and wildlife.

properties.name: Fitzgerald River Parking Area Jacup
properties.description: This is a parking area 80 km W of Ravensthorpe or 33 km E of Jerramungup. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables. There is a sign prohibiting fires during the danger season and an informational sign. It is near the road and loud due to road noise, but sheltered from view due to the bush. It is large and can suit many vehicles. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: 90 Mile Sign Parking Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area. There is a short bitumen pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and bush. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables but no other facilities. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. There is a dirt track leading further into the bush for more seclusion. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Coalfields Road Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area 23 km W of Collie or 13 km E of South West Hwy/Coalfields Rd Junction. There is no signage. The surface is gravel and dirt and level. There are a few picnic tables and plenty of shade. The area is used as a road-train assembly area, and big-rigs overnight here. There are rubbish bins but no other facilities. The area is quiet and peaceful if there are no road trains.

properties.name: Pear Creek
properties.description: Simple rest area on the E bank of Pear Creek. No facilities, limited shade. Located on Newman Tabba Tabba Rd, 137km SE of South Hedland. Small vehicles only, limited space available.

properties.name: Bluebird Rest Area
properties.description: A road side drive-through gravel rest area located a fair distance off the highway. For some extra privacy during overnight stays you can drive further into the bush. There are no facilities, just a picnic table.

properties.name: Boolaboola Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway rest area. There is a short dirt pullover that leads to a large dirt area with tracks leading into the bush. Some tracks go far into the bush. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables but no other facilities. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. This site is medium sized and secluded. There is road noise. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Najada Rockhole
properties.description: This is a rest area 30 km W of Eucla or 35 km E of Mundrabilla. There is a short dirt pullover that leads to a small dirt area surrounded by bush. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables but no other facilities. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. This site is medium sized and secluded. There is road noise. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Ross Road Parking Bay
properties.description:
Large dirt park area on Wubin-Mullewa Rd. 

Picnic table and bins available, some shade from trees. 

Located 72km S of Mullewa. 

Signposted from road.

properties.name: Grotto Creek
properties.description:
The rest area is located at the end of a gravel road, just 200m off of the road. 

There is a little parking area and that's all there is provided in this campground. 

The gravel road you have to drive on is really rough and caravans may struggle to get in. 

The campground is surrounded by a few trees and bush.

properties.name: Afghan Rock Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical parking area on the Eyre Highway 177 km W of Caiguna or 5 km E of Balladonia. There is a long bitumen pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and bush. There are rubbish bins, and picnic tables but no other facilities. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. On the west side of the rest area, there is a 3 km dirt track that leads through pastoral land to Afghan Rock. Shut the gate behind you. This camp is more secluded than the rest area, but has no facilities. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Mt Burnside Rest Area
properties.description:
This is a small rest area 56 km NW of Walpole or 64 km SE of Manjimup. 

There is no signage. 

The surface is dirt and can be muddy in wet weather. RV's and larger vehicles can access this area. 

There is a picnic table and no other facilities. 

There is shade. 

Since it is right on the highway, road noise is present.

properties.name: Hearder Hill Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway rest area. There is a short dirt pullover that leads to a large dirt area with tracks leading into the bush. Some tracks go far into the bush. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables but no other facilities. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. This site is medium sized and secluded. There is road noise. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Windsor Rest Area
properties.description: Large unsealed roadside bay located directly by the highway. No facilities and limited shade.

properties.name: Norseman East Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical highway rest area. It is a medium sized dirt-surfaced area with tracks leading into the bush. There are rubbish bins and fire pits. It is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. All types of vehicles can access this area. Because it is next to the highway, it is noisy.

properties.name: Greenbushes Free Campsite
properties.description:
This is a small rest area 2 km N of Greenbushes or 8 km S of Balingup, near N exit to Greenbushes. 

GPS will direct near dirt road turnoff, follow 400 meters to the end near ablution block. 

The turnoff is dirt/gravel but accessible by any vehicle. 

There are some low-hanging tree branches to be aware of. 

There is a rubbish bin, sports fields, toilets with water. 

There is space for about a half-dozen vehicles to park comfortably. 

There is ample shade.

properties.name: Wattle Ridge Winery
properties.description:
This is a vineyard that allows self-contained vehicles to park on the property. Purchase or custom may be required. 

Check in at the cellar door during opening hours. 

The road is a dirt paved road and is a large road that any RV can access.

properties.name: Trigwells Bridge
properties.description: This is a parking are 24 km SW of Moodiarrup or 36 km NE of Boyup Brook. It is a medium sized gravel area next to the road. There are trees that provide shade and there is also a dirt track down to the bridge, suitable for small vehicles only. There is a picnic table but no other services. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Canna Old Camp
properties.description: Basic bush camp SW of town. No facilities, but showers and toilets available nearby in Canna village. Located on Canna Rd, 40km N of Morawa.

properties.name: Leycesters Rest Area
properties.description: Rest area about 200m off of the highway. There is a public toilet, two sheltered picnic tables, a few garbage bins and a dump station provided. You're allowed to make a fire. The rest area is really big so you don't have to worry about a parking spot. You can camp on a sealed or a gravel road. The rest area is surrounded by bush and trees. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Jillbunya Rockhole
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area. There is a short bitumen pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some sparse bush. There are no facilities. Most sites are open and exposed, there is no shade. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Brockway Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area 15 km S of Norseman or 56 km N of Kumarl. It is a highway pullover in a forested area with a dirt surface. There is an open dirt parking area with a rubbish bin and no other facilities. There are some dirt tracks that lead deeper into the forest into shady bush camp sites. All types of vehicles can access this area. There is road noise because it is close to the highway.

properties.name: Disappointment Rock
properties.description: Located slightly off the beaten track, this site offers overnight stays with basic facilities, as well as photogenic views.

properties.name: Roebuck Plains Parking Area
properties.description: Very big parking area on the side of the highway. There is nothing but a few bins provided. This parking area will fit a lot of vehicles. You just park on the side of the very wide dirt road. The parking area is surrounded by bush and trees.

properties.name: Querijup Pool Camping
properties.description:
This is a camping spot 6 km SE of Mayanup. Travel E on Blackwood Rd for 1.1 km, turn S onto Scotts Brook Rd for 5.5 km. 

The area is just a large grassy and forested area near the pool. 

The surface is dirt and grass and unlevel. Small vehicles are suitable but no larger vehicles. 

There are no facilities. 

It's quiet, secluded and peaceful.

properties.name: Indarra Rest Area
properties.description: Very large drive-through dirt rest area with good facilities. It is separated from the highway by a string of trees, which limits the traffic noise and provides shade.

properties.name: Peak Charles Campground
properties.description: Camping area in Peak Charles National Park. Toilets available and some shade from trees. Located 120km SW of Norseman, via Coolgardie-Esperance Hwy. Camp area is at the end of 50 km dirt road, 4WD recommended.

properties.name: Bannister Rest Area
properties.description: This is parking area 11 km N of Crossman or 4 km S of Bannister. It is a small dirt area that is directly next to the highway. There are some trees providing shade. There are picnic tables and rubbish bins here. It is very loud as it is directly next to and open to the highway. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Hillside Parking Bay at Marble Bar Turn Off
properties.description:
Gravel rest area on Great Northern Hwy. 

Toilets, dump point, and bins available, no shade. 

Located 90km S of Indee, just S of the Marble Bar turnoff

properties.name: Lyndon River West Rest Area
properties.description: Exposed drive-through rest area located directly by the highway. There are toilets, picnic tables and BBQs, but not much shade. It is prone to flooding, so please use only in dry weather.

properties.name: Stock Well 9
properties.description: Simple dirt rest area next to the well. Picnic tables, some shade. Located on Carnavon Mullewa Rd, 90km S of Murchison. Turn E, follow dirt track to well.

properties.name: Kwolyin Camp
properties.description:
Kwolyin Campsite is situated on what used to be the old football oval. You wouldn't know it. Pristine bush, with orchids, flowering annual, and sandalwoods surround the camp. Rarely can you sit in a picnic shelter and look on at orchids on the sides of the shelter. Or, park your caravan in a dedicated bay in the bush. 
The camp boasts toilets, a camp kitchen, large & small shelters, dedicated tent camping, and caravan bays, campfires with BBQ plates (April till Sept only), bush walks, and a pioneer walk trail through the old campsite & more.

properties.name: Domblegabby Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area surrounding a water tank. There is a short dirt pullover that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with little trees, shade, or bush. There are rubbish bins and picnic tables, and also a untreated water tank, but no other facilities. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Jibberding Rock
properties.description: Large dirt rest area off Great Northern Hwy. No facilities, some shade from trees. Located 23km NE of Wubin, just N of Rabbit Proof Fence Rd.

properties.name: Yarla Kutjara Campground
properties.description: This nice, spacious camping area with toilets is located close to the road (approx. 500m). It offers nice views, wildlife and birdwatching opportunities. There is an information board, too.

properties.name: Limestone Well Parking Area
properties.description:
Simple dirt rest area on Great Central Rd. 

No facilities, some shade from trees. 

Located 235km NE of Leonora.

Photo Credit: The Little Adventures

properties.name: Pumphreys Bridge Camp Area
properties.description: This is a camping area at Pumphreys Bridge. Via Wandering - Narrogin Rd, 43 km N Narrogin. The area is a large grassy field just below the bridge. It is suitable for all vehicles. There are picnic tables, fire pits, and rubbish bins here. Across the street there is a playground, toilets, tennis courts, and a sports complex. This is a quiet shady and peaceful site but is popular with caravanners.

properties.name: St Lukes Church Parking Area
properties.description: This is a parking area in the small mining town of Westonia. The church allows self-contained vehicles to park in the dirt carpark for a maximum of 72 hours. There is a rubbish bin but no other facilities. Shade is limited. It is quiet at night, as this town is small and off the highway. There is a church service on the third Sunday of the month. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Coongan River
properties.description: Simple dirt rest area on the E side of the river. Rubbish bins and some shade from trees, no other facilities. Located on Newman Tabba Tabba Rd, 160km SE of South Hedland.

properties.name: Bunjil Rocks
properties.description: Free camping area next to the rocks. No facilities, some shade from trees. Located 29km S of Perenjori or 13km N of Latham. At the Bunjil Rocks signpost on Mullewa-Wubin Rd turn W for 1 km.

properties.name: Rabbit Proof Fence Parking Bay
properties.description: This is a highway pullover at an information bay about the Rabbit Proof Fence. The surface is sealed with dirt shoulders. It is next to and visible from highway, so it is loud and noisy. It is not very secluded either. There are rubbish bins here. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Carlabeencabba Rockhole Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area. There is a 300 meter long dirt road that leads to a medium sized open dirt area with some trees and surrounded by bush. There are rubbish bins, and an emergency phone that is currently out of order. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Toapin Weir Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a camping area at the old historic Toapin Weir. This is a small camping area with an open carpark and a shady grass and dirt area. All types of vehicles can access this area. The dirt road to access this area is dirt and slightly corrugated. Look for a small wooden sign on the right at the Toapin Weir. There are picnic tables, a toilet, a barbecue, rubbish bins, and a rainwater tank. Maximum stay: 20 Hours

properties.name: Needilup Rest Area
properties.description: This is a parking area 14 km W of Jerramungup or 25 km E of Ongerup, behind the hall. There are no facilities here - an old toilet block and hall and parking area only. There is some shade and plenty of seclusion. All vehicles can access this area. It is large and campers can spread out. There is some road noise but it is light at night.

properties.name: Grimwade Settlement
properties.description: This is a camp area 13 km NE of Balingup or 16 km E of Kirup, via Grimwade Rd. 4WD recommended as the turnoff leads to a network of forest roads. There are no facilities or any defined camp area - pull in wherever appropriate. There is shade and shelter from weather. It is very remote and secluded.

properties.name: Leinster South
properties.description: Large dirt rest area on Goldfields Hwy. No facilities, limited shade. Located 128km N of Leonora.

properties.name: Burracoppin Centenary Park
properties.description: This is a small camping area next to the highway in the locality of Burracoppin. It is an open area adjacent to the Centenary Park. The surface is grass and dirt and suitable for all vehicles. There is little shade. There is little seclusion as well, as it is visible from the highway. There are toilets, a playground, rubbish bins, a covered picnic area, and fire pit.

properties.name: Bindoon Hill Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a standard highway pullover just north of Bindoon on Highway 95. It is a medium sized sealed pullover on the high point of a hill. There is a rubbish bin, picnic area, and barbecue here. This site is used as a truck stop. It is near the road and loud. There is no where to park except on the sealed area, so it is not that secluded. It is a shady site. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Kathala Pass Free Camping and Rest Area
properties.description:
This is a typical Eyre highway rest area at two large rainwater collection tanks. 

There is a 200 meter dirt road that leads to a large dirt area with tracks leading into the bush. the bush is short here and there is no shade. 

There are rubbish bins and picnic tables and untreated rainwater but no other facilities. 

This site is medium sized and secluded. 

There is road noise. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Kulyalling Park
properties.description:
This is a picnic area 10 km N of Pingelly or 10 km S of Brookton. Follow turnoff and cross track tracks, signs direct toward camping area. This is a quiet, shaded, dirt area with bush and vegetation separating camp sites. 

There are picnic tables and fire rings as well as rubbish bins, but no other facilities. It is next to the railroad and not far from the highway so there is some noise, but it is far enough away to be light. 

All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Olwolgin Bluff Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway bush camp rest area. There is a short dirt pullover that leads to a small sized open dirt area with some trees and bush. There are rubbish bins, picnic tables and fire rings but no other facilities. This is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. Because it is close to the road, it is not very peaceful or secluded, but some bush sites are quiet and private. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: White Wells Rest Area
properties.description: This spacious and shaded rest area with no amenities, other than picnic tables and BBQ, is located off the highway. Suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Wagerup Rest Area
properties.description: This is a parking area 6 km N of Yarloop or 6 km S of Waroona. It is on the Northbound side of the highway. It is a long large dirt and gravel parking area. In the middle there is a grassy area with a grill and picnic table. There are also rubbish bins here. It is mostly shady and because it is direct off the road it is noisy. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Ellendale Rest Area
properties.description: Rest area is located about 100 meters from the highway. There is a dump station, a few bins, four picnic tables and public toilets provided. There are some little trees around the rest area for shade. You camp on the side of a big gravel road that leads through the rest area. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Burkett Road Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area 116 km NE of Minilya Roadhouse or 111 km SW of Nanutarra Roadhouse. This is a bus transfer station that is also a standard Main Roads Western Australia rest area. The surface is dirt and gravel and all types of vehicles can access this area. There is a toilet, rubbish bins, a covered waiting area and a dump station here. It is at the junction of major highways. There is no shade or bush here.

properties.name: Garden Rock
properties.description: Free parking area next to the rock. No facilities. Signposted. 15km E of Cue via Cue-Wondinong Rd. Dirt road. Need a 4WD when wet.

properties.name: Karri Gully Picnic Site
properties.description: This is a picnic area on the Brockman Hwy. 19 km E of Nannup or 27 km W of Bridgetown. It is a small rest area with a dirt surface and large RVs will not fit or take up most of the space. There is a firepit, long drop toilet, and access to the Bibblimun Track. Maximum stay: 24 Hours

properties.name: Green Range Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area 25 km SW of Wellstead or 73 km NE of Albany. It is a typical highway pullover with a dirt surface, picnic table, and rubbish bin. No Fires. The area is close to the highway so it is loud. There is shade. There is bush surround the area so it is not in view from the road.

properties.name: Aldersyde Parking Area
properties.description: This is a parking area 28 km E of Brookton or 63 km W of Corrigin. It is at the junction of two roads. There is a sealed loop and a small dirt parking area. There is a rubbish bin here. There are a few large trees but very little shade. The parking area is about 50 meters from the highway and exposed to the road, so it is loud. Any type of vehicle can access this area.

properties.name: Paynes Find Rest Area
properties.description: This spacious, circular drive-through rest area with no amenities is located just off the highway. There is very little shade and it's suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Mt Pleasant Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical Eyre highway rest area. There is a medium length bitumen pullover that leads to a small level dirt area with some tracks leading into the bush. There are rubbish bins and an emergency phone but no other facilities. It is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. This site is medium size but close to the road. All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Little Panton River Parking Area
properties.description: Little rest area just 100m off of the highway. There are two sheltered picnic tables and one garbage bins provided. You camp on a gravel ground and the rest area is surrounded by bush and some trees.

properties.name: Lake MacLeod Rest Area
properties.description: This is a standard Main Roads Western Australia rest area 49 km S of Minilya Roadhouse or 90 km N of Carnarvon. It has the standard facilities - ecotoilet, dump station, picnic tables, and rubbish bins. The surface is dirt and all types and sizes of vehicles can access this area. There is no shade or shelter from weather.

properties.name: Lennard River Rest Area
properties.description: Dirt rest area on the S bank of Lennard River. No facilities, some shade from trees. Located on Derby Gibb River Road, 80km E of Meda. Dirt road.

properties.name: Buldania Rocks Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a camping area at the Buldania Rocks. Follow dirt track back into the bush. There are small bush camping sites along this track for many kilometers. There are no facilities. The track is suitable for 2wd in good weather. This site is not suitable for long vehicles. It is secluded, quiet, and peaceful.

properties.name: Pinjarra Parking Area
properties.description: This is a standard RV-friendly overnighting area in Pinjarra, similar to those you will find in towns throughout Western Australia. The area is a grass field and level, and large enough to accommodate dozens of vehicles. Any type of vehicle can access this area. There is a rubbish bin. There are some trees that provide little shade. No dumping of waste water. No Camping (self-contained only). A Dump Station is provided. Maximum Stay: 24 Hours.

properties.name: Yerdani Well Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a rest area at the old Yerdani Well. It is a highway pullover with a level dirt surface. There is bush camping and open spaces. Some shade is available. There are fire pits and rubbish bins but no other facilities. All types of vehicles can access this area. Road noise is heard at this site.

properties.name: Cockburn South Rest Area
properties.description: This is just a parking area next to the highway. You will hear every noise from it as it's right next to it. There are only two garbage bins provided and you park on grass or the on the side of the dirt road.

properties.name: Dundas Nature Reserve Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical highway rest area. It is a medium sized bitumen area with a few grassy areas for tents. There are rubbish bins and fire rings. There is an emergency phone. There is some shade, but most of the bitumen is exposed. All types of vehicles can access this area. Because it is next to the highway, it is noisy.

properties.name: Greenough River
properties.description: Simple dirt rest area on the S bank of Greenough River. No facilities. River water levels can be low, so might not be good for fishing. Located on Carnavon Mullewa Rd, 45km N of Mullewa. Dirt road.

properties.name: Curara Farm Bush Camp
properties.description: Simple dirt rest area. No facilities, limited shade. Signposted. Located 24km N of Mullewa via Carnarvon Mullewa Rd.

properties.name: Avon Park Rest Area
properties.description: This is a parking area in the town of York. Self Contained Vehicles only, since toilets are locked in the evening due to vandalism. This is a town park that is used frequently by the community so it is busy with families and sporting events. However, it is quiet at night, but in the early morning traffic picks up and it becomes noisy. There are four 240V hookups for vehicles, a barbecue, rubbish bins, playground, a dump station, and toilets open until 7 PM. There is not much shade in the area for RV parking. Maximum Stay: 24 hours.

properties.name: Kulin Overnight Stop
properties.description: This is a parking area at Kulin, behind the pubic toilets and information bay. Self Contained Vehicles only. It is a large dirt area suitable for self-contained RVs. It is not very shady or sheltered. Since it is in town, road noise is heard, but at night this is a very quiet place. Maximum stay: 72 Hours

properties.name: Arrino Siding
properties.description: Gravel rest area in Arrino. Toilets, rubbish bins, picnic tables and BBQ available.Some shade from trees. Located on Midlands Rd, 17km NW of Three Springs.

properties.name: Borden Recreation Ground
properties.description:
Self Contained vehicles can park here at the sports complex. 

It is in the quiet town of Borden and has rubbish bins and toilets, although they may not be accessible by campers. 

There is no signage here with requirements for camping or overnighting in the area.

properties.name: Mambi Island
properties.description: Camp area on the banks of Ord River. Toilet and bin availlable, shade from trees available. There is also a boat ramp and it's a good spot for fishing. Located on Parry Creek Rd, 53km SE of Wyndham via Great Northern Hwy. Signposted access to camp. Dirt road. Steep entry.

properties.name: Bodallin Pioneers Park
properties.description: This is a rest area at Bodallin. There is a large gravel and dirt parking area next to the Pioneer Park. It is suitable for all types of vehicles. There are rubbish bins, picnic tables, a playground, and toilet facilities. There is not much shade. It is a quiet site but there is road noise from the highway.

properties.name: Nillibubbica Rest Area
properties.description: Quite a big rest area, it fits a lot of vehicles. There are three sheltered picnic areas, several bins, a dump station and flush toilets provided. You camp on red dirt. The rest area is surrounded by a barbed wire fence, trees and bush. You're allowed to make a fire. 24 hours maximum stay.

properties.name: Insopher Park Area
properties.description:
This is a parking area 88 km W of Esperance or 19 km E of Munglinup. It is a level dirt highway pullover separated from the highway by a bushy median. 

There are rubbish bins and a covered picnic table here but no other facilities. There is an informational sign about the area. 

All types of vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Kundip Rest Area
properties.description:
This is a very large camping area 19 km S of Ravensthorpe or 30 km N of Hopetoun. 

The surface is dirt and this camp spreads through the bush into many secluded bush campsites. There is a toilet, picnic table, and informational sign talking about the history of the area. 

There is some shade and plenty of seclusion, but some road noise is present. Traffic is light at night. 

All vehicles can access this area.

properties.name: Lake Cowan Rest Area
properties.description: This is a typical highway rest area. It is a medium sized dirt-surfaced area with tracks leading into the bush. There are rubbish bins and fire pits. It is a bush camping site with some shady bush sites and open areas. All types of vehicles can access this area. Because it is next to the highway, it is noisy.

properties.name: Bromus Dam Rest Stop
properties.description: This is a camping area 32 km S of Norseman or 39 km N of Kumarl. It is a large dirt surfaced forested area. There is a picnic table, rubbish bins, fire pit and a historic dam and reservoir. Camp in the open area or follow dirt tracks into denser bush for more secluded spots. All types of vehicles can access this area. It is quiet, shady and secluded.
